title: DSS v. Mother
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Department of Social Services, Respondent,
v.
Mother, Father, and Minor Children under the age of eighteen (18):Â  Child A, born 01.18.1993, Child B, born 02.12.1996, Child C, born 10.02.1997, and Child D, born 11.29.1999, Defendants, Of Whom Father is the
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â James F. Fraley, Jr., Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-268
Heard May 17, 2006 â€“ Filed June 1, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
AndreaÂ  Hawkins, of Spartanburg, for Appellant.
Kenneth Philip Shabel, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This is an appeal of a termination of parental rights.Â  Father argues termination was improper because he remedied the conditions that caused the removal of his children and because there was no evidence that he posed a threat of harm to them.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Father and Mother married in 1991.Â  They have four daughters, who at the time of the final hearing on August 10, 2005, ranged in age from five to twelve. 
The Department of Social Services (DSS) first became involved with the family after receiving a report on October 24, 1997, that Mother and Child C both tested positive for cocaine at the childâ€™s birth.Â  Although the family court initially found probable cause for taking the children into protective custody, the parties agreed at the final hearing on November 24, 1997, that (1) Father would receive legal and physical custody of the children; (2) Mother would be restrained from having unsupervised contact with the children pending her completion of counseling for drug abuse; (3) Father would be restrained from allowing unsupervised contact between Mother and the children until she completed treatment; and (4) both parents would cooperate with DSS in completing treatment.Â  At a subsequent judicial review hearing on March 16, 1998, the family court granted legal and physical custody of the children to both parents.
DSS took the children into emergency protective custody a second time in November 1998, after an allegation of criminal domestic violence.Â  The charges were later dismissed, and by consent order the children were later returned to both Father and Mother.
In October 1999, Mother tested positive for cocaine during the final trimester of her pregnancy with the familyâ€™s fourth child, prompting DSS to take the other three children into protective custody a third time.Â  At the probable cause hearing, the family court found probable cause for the removal due to Motherâ€™s positive drug test; however, following the merits hearing on December 13, 1999, Father, with DSSâ€™s consent, received custody of all four children on the condition that he prevent Mother from having unsupervised contact with the children. 
The day after the merits hearing, Father and Motherâ€™s newborn fourth daughter tested positive for cocaine.Â  Following an emergency hearing on January 20, 2000, the family court left the prior custody arrangement intact, with Father having legal custody of the children and Mother having only supervised contact with them.Â  Following a judicial review hearing on December 11, 2000, the family court lifted the ban on unsupervised contact between Mother and the children and allowed DSS and the guardian ad litem to close their files on the case. 
In July 2002, DSS brought an intervention action alleging Mother had physically abused the children by using excessive corporal punishment.Â  On October 11, 2002, while that action was pending, DSS took emergency protective custody of the children and filed a complaint for removal, alleging additional bruises on the children.Â  After the removal, both parents and two of the children tested positive for cocaine.Â  
At a hearing on October 21, 2002, the family court consolidated the intervention action with the removal case.Â  This time the family court granted custody of the children to DSS; however, it also ordered DSS to perform an expedited homestudy on Father for possible return of the children to his custody â€œupon confirmation that he is no longer living with [Mother].â€ 
Following a permanency planning hearing on March 7, 2003, the family court returned the children to Father.Â  The family court permitted Mother to live in the home with Father and the children; however, it also ordered to her comply with previous court-ordered treatment and submit to random drug screenings.Â  In addition, Motherâ€™s contact with the children was to be supervised until she completed two clean-hair-strand drug tests.Â  
In September 2003, DSS brought a rule to show cause against Mother.Â  The family court ordered her to immediately submit to a drug screen.Â  The test, which was administered September 19, 2003, was positive for cocaine.Â  The other family members were also tested.Â  All four children tested positive for cocaine, with only Father having a negative screen.Â  The children were again removed from their home and have remained in the physical and legal custody of DSS since that time.
At a hearing on January 5, 2004, DSS agreed not to pursue termination of parental rights, proceeding only on its complaint for removal.Â  With all partiesâ€™ consent, the family court adopted a treatment plan, which both Father and Mother agreed to complete without assistance, financial or otherwise, from
DSS. 
At a permanency planning hearing on September 9, 2004, the family court found both parents had made â€œsome, but not substantial progress on their previously ordered treatment planâ€ and allowed DSS to re-institute an action for termination. 
On September 23, 2004, Father filed an action for divorce against Mother on the ground of habitual drunkenness.Â  At a temporary hearing on November 3, 2004, the family court granted Father exclusive use and possession of the marital home and ordered Mother to vacate the residence by November 20, 2004.[1]  
On November 15, 2004, DSS filed a complaint for termination of parental rights against both Father and Mother.Â  Several months later, the family court granted FatherÂ  a divorce on the ground of Motherâ€™s habitual drunkenness. 
The final hearing in the termination action took place August 10, 2005.Â  By order dated September 7, 2005, the family court terminated the parental rights of both Father and Mother.Â  Only Father appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The best interest of the child is the paramount consideration in a termination of parental rights case.[2]Â  The party seeking to terminate anotherâ€™s parental rights must prove the alleged grounds for termination by clear and convincing evidence.[3]Â  Although â€œthis court may review the record and make its own determination whether the grounds for termination are supported by clear and convincing evidence,â€[4] . . . it â€œshould not necessarily disregard the findings of the family court because the family court is in a better position to evaluate the credibility of the witnesses and assign weight to their testimony.â€[5]
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  Father argues on appeal that termination of his parental rights was improper because he remedied the conditions leading to the removal of the children and because there was no evidence that he posed any threat of harm to them.Â  We disagree with these assertions.
The family court concluded there was clear and convincing evidence to terminate the parental rights of both parents, noting it â€œ[was] not reasonably likely that the home [could] be made safe within twelve months.â€[6]Â  In support of this determination, the family court made numerous findings of fact.Â  Particularly significant is the family courtâ€™s finding that both Father and Mother â€œmade no significant progress on providing [a] safe home for the children.â€Â  In so finding, the family court noted (1) there was still domestic violence in the home, although conceding it was unclear as to who was a fault; (2) neither parent completed the counseling sessions as required by previous court order; and (3) neither parent substantially complied with the treatment plan, although acknowledging Father â€œcame close.â€
As to the allegation of domestic violence, Father argues he was never convicted of criminal domestic violence and there was evidence in the record that Mother had falsely accused him of domestic violence in the past and was herself a volatile person.Â  Nevertheless, there was significant circumstantial evidence presented at trial suggesting that Father, despite a clean criminal record and Motherâ€™s instability, had been an abuser.Â  This evidence included (1) a diagnosis from a physician at Vocational Rehabilitation that Mother suffered from spousal abuse syndrome; (2) a psychiatristâ€™s report diagnosing Mother with probable dysthymia disorder â€œsecondary to [a] long history of criminal domestic violenceâ€; and (3) testimony from a marriage counselor that Mother had been in an abusive relationship with Father.Â  In addition, a DSS employee testified about first-hand observations of Motherâ€™s behavior that indicated Mother was afraid of Father.Â  Notwithstanding the concerns presented by all this evidence, Fatherâ€™s testimony at the final hearing suggested he was still in denial about the problem.
Father also argues it was undisputed that he and Mother were not living together at the time of the termination hearing.Â  Whether or not this assertion was true, it would not preclude the family court from considering the fact that, on prior occasions, Father, contrary to court-approved terms, allowed unsupervised contact between the children and Mother.[7]
In response to the family courtâ€™s finding that Father failed to complete counseling and did not comply with the treatment plan, Father presented evidence that he did in fact completed the court-ordered counseling programs.Â  He further characterizes testimony by DSS employees that he did not participate actively in the classes as â€œweakâ€ evidence to support the termination of his parental rights.Â  Although we agree with Father that the evidence indicates he fulfilled the attendance requirement for the treatment programs, we reject his contention that his apparent lack of participation was an improper factor in the family courtâ€™s decision.
According to the terms of the court-approved treatment plan, Father was to not only attend and complete the classes but also to â€œbe able to demonstrate a minimum level of understanding of the material and be able to apply it in the care of [his] children.â€ Â Considering this requirement, along with testimony that Father was only minimally compliant in his attendance,[8] we do not fault the family court for considering Fatherâ€™s level of participation in the counseling programs to determine whether or not the treatment had the desired effect.
2.Â  In his brief, Father does not challenge the finding that the children have been in foster care for fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months and proceeds to argue that termination of his parental rights was not in the childrenâ€™s best interests.Â  It therefore appears uncontested that DSS could proceed with the termination proceeding based on the ground that the children had been in custody of the State for at least fifteen of the past twenty-two months.[9]
3.Â  To the extent that Father has adequately argued to this court that termination of his parental rights was not in the childrenâ€™s best interests,[10] we hold there is sufficient evidence to support the family courtâ€™s finding to the contrary.Â  Although it was apparent that the children â€œdo respect, love and admire their dad,â€ they were excelling in foster care and, according to their volunteer guardian ad litem, did not express a preference to live with either of their parents.Â  The guardian ad litem further testified that she was concerned about domestic violence in the home and believed that what was best for the children would be â€œa solid home situation where they can be sure whatâ€™s going to happen from day to day and month to month.â€Â  In view of this and other evidence, we uphold that family courtâ€™s determination that the best interests of the children warrant the termination of Fatherâ€™s parental rights.[11]
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  DSS was a party to this action because of the related litigation concerning the children.
[2]Â  Charleston County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs v. Jackson, 368 S.C. 87, ___, 627 S.E.2d 765, 770 (Ct. App. 2006) (citing Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 579, 578 S.E.2d 733, 735 (Ct. App. 2003)).
[3]Â  Id. (citing Richberg v. Dawson, 278 S.C. 356, 357, 296 S.E.2d 338, 339 (1982) and S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Parker, 336 S.C. 248, 254, 519 S.E.2d 351, 354 (Ct. App. 1999)).
[4]Â  Id. (citing S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cummings, 345 S.C. 288, 293, 547 S.E.2d 506, 509 (Ct. App. 2001).
[5] Id. (citing Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 452, 477 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. App. 1996)).
[6]Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(1) (Supp. 2005) (listing the likelihood â€œthat the home can be made safe within twelve monthsâ€ as a factor in ordering termination of a parentâ€™s rights).
[7]Â  See id. Â§ 20-7-1572(1) (â€œIn determining the likelihood that the home can be made safe, the parentâ€™s previous abuse or neglect of the child or another in the home may be considered.â€).
[8]Â  For instance, the director of the counseling program testified Father had to make up several unexcused classes and had left a class on one occasion immediately after signing in.
[9]Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-7-1572(8) (Supp. 2005) (including a childâ€™s presence â€œin foster care under the responsibility of the State for the fifteen of the most recent twenty-two monthsâ€ as a ground for termination of parental rights); Jackson, 358 S.C. at ___, 627 S.E.2d at 773 (â€œ[T]he purpose of the statutory ground allowing for termination if a child has been in foster care for fifteen of the last twenty-two months is to ensure children do not languish in foster care when termination of parental rights would be in their best interests.â€) (citing Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 581, 578 S.E.2d 733, 736 (Ct. App. 2003)).
[10]Â  As stated in Fatherâ€™s brief, the sole issue presented in this appeal is as follows:Â  â€œDid the Family Court err in terminating Appellantâ€™s parental rights where Appellant remedied the conditions that caused removal and there was no evidence that Appellant posed any threat of harm to his children whatsoever?â€Â  Although Father includes additional argument in his brief about the best interests of the children, this discussion is not presented under a separate statement of the issue.Â  See Rule 208(b)(1)(B), SCACR (â€œOrdinarily, no point will be considered which is not set forth in the statement of the issues on appeal.â€).
[11] See DSS v. Phillips, 365 S.C. 572, 582, 618 S.E.2d 922, 927 (Ct. App. 2005) (â€œYet, this desire to preserve the natural family bond must be balanced by the always paramount â€“ â€˜controllingâ€™ â€“ concern that the best interest of the child be protected and advanced.â€).

title: Walker v. McLeod
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE. IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
H. Charles Walker and Eloise G. Walker, Appellants,
v.
Patrick McLeod, Barbara McLeod, Marvin G. Rush, Myrtle Rush and Kenneth Baker,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenwood County
Â Donald A. Long, Special Referee

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-269Â Â Â 
Submitted June 1, 2006 â€“ Filed June 5, 2006 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Jon E. Newlon, of Greenwood, for Appellants.
C. Rauch Wise, Albert M. Sparrow, Jr., and Curtis G. Clark, of Greenwood, for Respondents Patrick McLeod, Barbara McLeod, Marvin Rush, and Myrtle Rush.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â This case involves a portion of a shared easement, which runs along the corner of the partiesâ€™ property.Â  Appellants constructed a road along the easement and asserted that respondents had an equitable obligation to pay for it as well as any past and future repair and maintenance.Â  The special referee found appellants were not entitled to restitution or contribution for past repair and maintenance; however, all parties must pay for future repair and maintenance according to the tax value of their properties.Â  Having carefully reviewed the record, we concur in the well-reasoned order of the special referee.[1]
1.Â Â Â Â Â Â  In an equitable action, the appellate court may view the evidence to determine facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Florence County Sch. Dist. No. 2 v. Interkal, Inc., 348 S.C. 446, 450, 559 S.E.2d 866, 868 (Ct. App. 2002); see 
Wallace v. Milliken & Co., 305 S.C. 118, 120, 406 S.E.2d 358, 359 (1991) (restitution is an equitable remedy). Â This broad scope of review, however, does not require an appellate court to disregard the findings below.Â  Florence County Sch. Dist. No. 2, 348 S.C. at 450; 559 S.E.2d at 868. We find the facts in accordance with the findings of the special referee.Â  Â Â 
2.Â Â Â Â Â Â  We find appellants are not entitled to restitution.Â  The special referee correctly determined appellants did not confer a non-gratuitous benefit on respondents.Â  See 
Sauner v. Pub. Serv. Auth. of South Carolina, 354 S.C. 397, 409, 581 S.E.2d 161, 167-68 (2003) (to recover on a theory
of restitution, the plaintiff must show that: (1) he conferred a non-gratuitous benefit on the defendant, (2) the defendant realized some value from the benefit, and (3) it would be inequitable for the defendant to retain the benefit without paying the plaintiff for its value);
Niggel Assocs., Inc. v. Poloâ€™s of North Myrtle Beach, Inc., 296 S.C. 530, 532-33, 374 S.E.2d 507, 509 (Ct. App. 1988) (for benefit to be conferred non-gratuitously, it must be conferred either at the defendantâ€™s request or in circumstances where plaintiff reasonably relies on defendant to pay for benefit and defendant understands or ought to understand that plaintiff expects compensation and looks to him for payment; defendant must have induced plaintiff to confer benefit).Â  There is no evidence in the record that respondents â€œinducedâ€ appellants to confer the benefit of the road on respondents.Â  Respondents consistently refused to pay for the construction.Â  Further, we are not persuaded by appellantsâ€™ contention that they were â€œcorneredâ€ into improving the shared easement.Â  Appellants knew before purchasing the property that they would have to construct access to the property.Â  Moreover, it would be inequitable to allow appellants to force respondents to pay for the improvement when the result would ultimately be a windfall for appellants.Â  Appellantsâ€™ property was inaccessible prior to improving the shared easement, and the purchase price reflected this fact.Â  
3.Â Â Â Â Â Â  We hold appellants are not entitled to contribution for the costs of past repair and maintenance of the shared easement.Â  Respondents were unable to use the improved easement until they constructed a connector road, which was not completed until fall of 1998.Â  This action was commenced in October 1998, and at that point, appellants obstructed the easement so that respondents could not pass through.Â  Accordingly, respondents did not gain any longstanding benefit that would warrant contribution of the costs of past repair and maintenance.Â  See Hayes v. Tompkins, 287 S.C. 289, 294, 337 S.E.2d 888, 892 (Ct. App. 1985) (citing Harris v. Ferguson, 18 S.C.L. (2 Bail.) 397 (1831) (doctrine of contribution founded upon equality of burden and benefit)).
4.Â Â Â Â Â Â  We find the special refereeâ€™s use of property values to compute the partiesâ€™ respective obligation to pay for future repair and maintenance of the shared easement was equitable.Â  The allocation of repair and maintenance costs based upon the partiesâ€™ use of the shared easement is not practical, and would likely lead to continued litigation.Â  Further, property values serve an objective standard that will require those who have a residence on the property to pay more than those who do not.Â  
AFFIRMED.
KITTREDGE, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Elgin v. Kelly
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Donnie Elgin and Elginâ€™s Paint and Body Shop, Inc., Respondents,
v.
Grace Kelly, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Alison Renee Lee, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-270
Heard January 11, 2006 â€“ Filed June 6, 2006
Withdrawn, Substituted and Refiled August 28, 2006

AFFIRMED IN PART AND REVERSED AND REMANDED IN PART


  
    
      
S. Jahue Moore, of W. Columbia, for Appellant.
C. Cantzon Foster, II, of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â Grace Kelly appeals the trial courtâ€™s refusal to grant her a new trial absolute and denial of her requests for appointment of a receiver and an accounting.Â  We affirm in part and reverse and remand in part.
FACTS
In 1986, Donnie Elgin established Elginâ€™s Paint and Body Shop, Inc. in Columbia, SC.Â  He owned and operated the corporation as the sole shareholder.Â  In 1989, while he was going through a divorce, he met Grace Kelly at his lawyerâ€™s office.Â  Kelly, who was the office manager, provided accounting services for several law firms.Â  Elgin hired her to assist with his paint and body shop.Â  Eventually, Elgin and Kelly became romantically involved and began living together. Â When Elgin decided to open another business in Greenville, he needed someone to run the corporation when he was not there.Â  Kelly purchased 50% of the corporation for $70,000.[1]Â  
With Elgin working mainly in Greenville and then in 1994 moving to Florida and running a business there, he essentially became an absentee co-owner.Â  Kelly, along with manager Paul Caughman, ran the day-to-day operations of the corporation.Â  According to Elgin, Kellyâ€™s duties with the corporation included administering payroll, including deductions for the employees and compiling the corporationâ€™s quarterly and yearly federal and state tax returns.Â  This compiled tax information was then to be provided to the corporationâ€™s accountant for filing with the state and federal governments.Â  Elgin claimed that Kelly showed him phony documentation indicating that she had been providing the information to the accountant.Â  Kelly stated that although it was her duty to compile the tax information, she would provide that information to Elgin and he was supposed to provide it to the accountant.Â  
In July of 1998, Elgin discovered under Kellyâ€™s kitchen sink 10-12 bank statements, which revealed discrepancies in the corporate records.[2]Â  Kelly had written checks to herself for amounts exceeding that which she had recorded in the check register.Â  Kelly stated she would cash the checks and the cash would go to Elgin.Â  
On October 6, 1998, after being alerted that Kelly had taken a piece of mail into the restroom, Elgin found a letter from the Internal Revenue Service (IRS), which had been ripped up and put in the restroom trash by Kelly.Â  Elgin brought the IRS letter to his accountant and demanded to know â€œwhat was going on.â€Â  The accountant informed Elgin that he had not filed a tax return for him in years.Â  The accountant discovered that the corporation had not filed a tax return with the IRS since 1990 and owed approximately $572,000 in back taxes and over $1,000,000 in interest and penalties.Â  An employee of the corporation testified and provided documentation that although taxes were withheld from his pay checks, the corporation never paid those taxes on his behalf.Â  In addition, Elgin discovered that the corporation was dissolved by the state in October of 1994 for failure to file proper paperwork.Â  Both parties testified that they were unaware of this dissolution, and they had continued to operate as a corporation.Â  
Elgin brought the present action seeking a temporary restraining order and temporary and permanent injunctions to enjoin Kelly from visiting the business property or taking any actions regarding the finances or business affairs of the business.Â  The court granted the temporary restraining order the day Elgin filed the complaint.Â  Kelly answered and counter-claimed contending Elgin had breached his fiduciary duty to the corporation. She requested an involuntary dissolution of the corporation, an accounting of the corporationâ€™s assets at the time of her ouster, and the appointment of a receiver. [3] Â  
Elgin also filed bankruptcy for the corporation.Â  Once bankruptcy was filed, the bankruptcy court took possession of all of the corporate assets and sold the equipment at auction.[4]Â  The bankruptcy court subsequently discharged the case from bankruptcy because Elgin lacked authority to file the action unilaterally. [5] Â  
Kelly filed an objection to payment of the bankruptcy trusteeâ€™s fees and moved that Elgin be required to pay the trusteeâ€™s fees as a sanction for bringing the action ultra vires.Â  The bankruptcy court found that Kelly did not come before the court with clean hands, failed to cooperate with the trustee, and only objected to the proceeding after the majority of the assets were liquidated.Â  Thus, it held Kelly was estopped and barred by the doctrine of laches from objecting to the payment of the trusteeâ€™s fees.Â  The bankruptcy court further found that although Elginâ€™s unilateral filing for bankruptcy was improper, there was no evidence that he engaged in any act that would rise to a level of contempt and declined to order Elgin to pay the trusteeâ€™s fees.Â  
After court fees and trusteeâ€™s fees were deducted from the proceeds of the sale, the remainder of the money was returned to Elgin.Â  Elgin testified that he utilized approximately $53,000 of the $71,038.08 that was returned to him by the bankruptcy court to pay his accountant and the IRS and to pay the costs of defending the corporation in the bankruptcy proceeding and the present action. Â He also admitted that he used some of this money for moving expenses and to set up his living arrangements in Columbia when he moved from Florida.Â  The remaining $18,000 is now in Elginâ€™s attorneyâ€™s trust account.Â  
After the discharge of the bankruptcy case, the present case came to trial with the legal matters presented to the jury and the equitable claims retained by the trial court.Â  The jury answered a special interrogatory finding that Kelly had an ownership interest in the corporation.Â  In its initial verdict, the jury found for Kelly, on behalf of the corporation, on the claim of breach of fiduciary duty but awarded no damages.Â  The trial court found the verdict was inconsistent and resubmitted the issue to the jury.Â  The jury quickly found in favor of Elgin.Â  Kelly filed a motion for a new trial absolute, which the trial court denied.Â  
In considering the equitable issues, the trial court held Elgin was not entitled to an injunction restraining Kelly from entering the business, finding there was no evidence Kelly had threatened to destroy business records.Â  The court denied the request for appointment of a receiver, finding such an appointment unnecessary.Â  The court also denied Kellyâ€™s request for an accounting, holding that the juryâ€™s determination that Elgin had not breached his fiduciary duty, while not binding as to the resolution of the issue, was supported by the evidence.Â  The court noted both parties had unclean hands but found the assets of the corporation had to be distributed and thus ordered the remaining assets be distributed to each shareholder on a pro rata basis.Â  The court subsequently denied Kellyâ€™s motion to vacate or alter or amend the judgment.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Refusal to Grant a New Trial
Kelly contends the trial court erred in refusing to grant a new trial absolute.[6]Â  We disagree.
The decision to grant a new trial is left to the sound discretion of the trial court and ordinarily will not be disturbed on appeal.Â  Rush v. Blanchard, 310 S.C. 375, 380, 426 S.E.2d 802, 805 (1993).Â  
After deliberating for almost two hours, the jury returned a verdict. Â The jury found that Kelly had an ownership interest in the corporation and that Elgin had breached his fiduciary duty to the corporation, but the jury did not award any damages on behalf of the corporation.Â  The trial court, without comment from the parties, informed the jury that this verdict was inconsistent.Â  The court again explained the charge of breach of fiduciary duty to the jury and instructed them to further deliberate to either find no breach of fiduciary duty or to award damages if there was a breach.Â  The jury returned to the courtroom five minutes later and rendered a verdict in favor of Elgin finding that there was no breach of fiduciary duty.Â  Kelly submitted a post-trial motion requesting a new trial absolute.Â  
Kelly argues that it was improper for the trial court to sua sponte instruct the jury on the inconsistent verdict.Â  After the trial court instructed the jury regarding the inconsistent verdict, it specifically asked the parties if they had any exceptions to the instructions it gave, and both parties stated that they had no objections.Â  Furthermore, in her motion for a new trial absolute, Kelly acknowledged, â€œHere, the Court properly resubmitted the case to the jury.â€Â  Accordingly, this issue is not preserved for appeal.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).Â Â Â  
Kelly further contends that the jury did not follow the trial courtâ€™s instruction to deliberate further.Â  She asserts that only five minutes elapsed between the instruction and the time at which the jury reached its second verdict.Â  
The jury had deliberated for almost 2 hours prior to rendering its first verdict and quickly reached a second verdict after a thorough instruction by the trial court.[7]Â  There is no prescribed length of time for a jury to reach a verdict and such must of necessity be left to the judgment of the jury. Â State v. Dewitt, 254 S.C. 527, 534, 176 S.E2d 143, 147 (1970).Â  Something more must appear, therefore, to warrant interference with a juryâ€™s verdict than the mere brevity of their deliberations.Â  Id.Â  The record contains no indication that the jury â€œshirked its duty to engage in deliberationsâ€ in arriving at this verdict.Â  We find no abuse of discretion by the trial court in accepting the juryâ€™s verdict. 
II.Â  Accounting and Appointment of a Receiver
Kelly contends that the trial court erred by refusing to appoint a receiver and failing to order an accounting with respect to the assets of the corporation at the time of her ouster, and by ordering that only the assets remaining at the time of trial be divided between the parties pro rata.[8]
Legal and equitable actions, when maintained in one suit, each retain
their own identity for purposes of the applicable standard of review on appeal.Â  Jordan v. Holt, 362 S.C. 201, 205, 608 S.E.2d 129, 131 (2005).Â  Dissolution of a corporation, appointment of a receiver, and an accounting are actions in equity. Â Jordan, 362 S.C. at 205, 608 S.E.2d at 131 (dissolution); Rogers v. Salisbury Brick Corp., 299 S.C. 141, 144, 382 S.E.2d 915, 917 (1989) (accounting); Wadsworth Industries, Inc. v. Westgate Knitting, Inc., 264 S.C. 106, 109, 212 S.E.2d 571, 572 (1975) (appointment of receiver). Â Accordingly, this court may find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 85, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976) (in equity case appellate court may take its own view of the preponderance of the evidence).Â  However, we are not required to disregard the findings below nor ignore the better vantage point the trial judge occupied in determining witness credibility.Â  Cherry v. Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 525, 280 S.E.2d 541, 541 (1981).Â  
Elgin asserts Kellyâ€™s claim for an accounting is barred by the doctrine of unclean hands.Â  As the trial court held, Elgin, as well as Kelly, came to this matter with unclean hands.Â  Although Elgin received $71,038.08 from the bankruptcy court, he only had $18,000 remaining to deposit into his lawyerâ€™s trust account.Â  Elgin testified he used a portion of the funds to repay himself for expenses he incurred â€œdefend[ing] these cases.â€Â  However, he submitted no bills or any checks evidencing expenses he legitimately incurred on the corporationâ€™s behalf.Â  He also stated he used a portion of the funds returned by the bankruptcy court to pay the IRS.Â  However, his accountant testified that as far as he knew, no corporate tax liability had been paid.Â  Thus, Elgin may have used a portion of the corporate funds to pay his personal tax liability.Â  In addition, Elgin admitted that he had used a portion of the funds for personal moving expenses and to establish a new residence when he moved from Daytona, Florida back to South Carolina.Â  Because the evidence indicates Elgin used corporate funds for personal expenses, we find Kelly is entitled to an accounting.Â  
We disagree with Kellyâ€™s assertion that the appointment of a receiver is necessary.Â  In a corporate dissolution action, a court may appoint a receiver to â€œwind up and liquidate . . . the business and affairs of the corporation.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-14-320(a) (2005).Â  In this case, the corporation has already been dissolved, there is no business to wind up, and all corporate assets have been liquidated.Â  We agree with the trial court that the appointment of a receiver is unnecessary.Â  
CONCLUSION
We hold the trial court did not abuse its discretion in refusing to grant a new trial.Â  We also affirm the trial courtâ€™s denial of Kellyâ€™s request for appointment of a receiver.Â  However, we REVERSE the trial courtâ€™s denial of Kellyâ€™s request for an accounting and REMAND for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.Â  
AFFIRMED IN PART AND REVERSED AND REMANDED IN PART.
 HEARN, C.J., and HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.Â  

[1] No stock certificate for this transfer in ownership was ever created, and there was no documentation of Kellyâ€™s ownership.Â  
[2] Elgin testified that when he confronted Kelly regarding these discrepancies, she offered no explanation and at one point, signed over her 50% interest in the corporation to him for no consideration.Â  Even after this event took place, both parties admit that they continued to operate as co-owners. 
[3]Kelly also made other claims including assault and battery and illegal wire tapping, but these claims are not relevant to this appeal.
[4]Kelly still possessed a corporately-owned automobile that was not surrendered to the bankruptcy court. 
[5]The bankruptcy court noted the corporate book listed Claude R. Rogers as owner of 500 shares of stock.Â  Elgin explained the listed owner had planned to buy into the corporation prior to Kellyâ€™s co-ownership and Elgin had changed the corporate records.Â  However, the transaction fell through and Rogers never bought into the company.
[6] Elgin asserts Kelly failed to timely file her Rule 59, SCRCP, motion and thus the circuit court and this court lack jurisdiction to consider the issues raised in the motion.Â  We find Kelly in fact timely served and filed her motion and sent a copy of the motion to the trial judge in accordance with Rule 59.Â Â  In addition, we find Kellyâ€™s notice of appeal was sufficient to confer jurisdiction on all issues raised in this appeal.Â  
[7] It should be noted that if the jury quickly reached a second verdict because they felt pressed for time (as Kelly asserts), they could have awarded some amount of damages to Kelly just as quickly as they found for Elgin.
[8] Elgin asserts this issue is not preserved because Kelly did not raise any specific arguments in her post-trial motion.Â  Kellyâ€™s request for appointment of receiver and an accounting were presented to the trial court and ruled on in the order of August 4, 2004.Â  Thus, the issue is preserved. Â See Wilder Corp., 330 S.C. at 77, 497 S.E.2d at 734 (â€œPost-trial motions are not necessary to preserve issues that have been ruled upon at trial; they are used to preserve those that have been raised to the trial court but not yet ruled upon by it.â€).

title: SCDSS v. Long
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
South Carolina Department of Social Services, Respondent,
v.
Crystal Lynn Long, Randy Lee Cox and John Doe, Defendants,
of whom Randy Lee Cox is Appellant.
In the interest of:
Jordan Lee Cox, DOB 10/7/1999
A Minor Under the Age of 18. 
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Timothy L. Brown, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.
2006-UP-271
Heard May 11, 2006 â€“ Filed June 8, 2006Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Amos A. Workman, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Danielle M. Mitchell, of Greenville, for Respondent.
Ann Shipman Miner, of Pickens, for Guardian Ad Litem.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Randy Lee Cox appeals the family courtâ€™s decision to terminate his parental rights.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Jordan Lee Cox, the subject of this termination of parental rights action, was born on October 7, 1999.Â  His parents, Cox and Crystal Long never married, but maintain an ongoing relationship.Â  
Pursuant to an order dated August 29, 2002, Jordan was taken into emergency protective care by the South Carolina Department of Social Services (DSS).Â  Long, the custodial parent, was incarcerated at that time, and Cox and Jordan were living at the home of Coxâ€™s father Randy Cox, who had sexually abused Jordanâ€™s older half-sister.[1]Â  DSS took custody of Jordan due to the risk of sexual abuse.Â  
After a merits hearing in October 2002, the family court, by order dated November 21, 2002, continued custody with DSS and incorporated the treatment plan presented by DSS into the order.Â  After evaluating Cox, DSS had determined that he needed to complete certain goals in order to become a responsible parent.Â  The plan required Cox to participate in drug and alcohol evaluations, attend mental health counseling, attend parenting classes, submit to random drug screens, and secure appropriate housing for Jordan.Â Â  
Cox continued to live at Randy Coxâ€™s residence and did not begin services as required by the treatment plan.Â  On May 27, 2003, DSS filed a contempt action against Cox for failure to comply with the treatment plan.Â  The family court held Cox in contempt, sentencing him to thirty days in jail, suspended upon immediate compliance with the plan.Â  In July 2003, DSS brought a Motion to Enforce the sentence, and Cox began participating in the programs outlined in the plan.Â  Cox was unable to complete the services because his parole (for a previous offense) was revoked for using illegal drugs, and he was returned to prison in December 2003.[2]Â  Before his incarceration, Cox visited with Jordan and made lump sum child support payments when he was able.Â  
On October 16, 2003, DSS filed the present termination of parental rights action.[3] Â After a hearing, at which Cox was present and testified, the family court, by order dated April 1, 2005, found by clear and convincing evidence that Cox failed to remedy the conditions which caused Jordanâ€™s removal by failing to complete the treatment plan and by failing to establish secure and appropriate housing due to his continued residence with his father, Randy Cox.Â  The family court also found Jordan had been in foster care for fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months, and termination of Coxâ€™s parental rights was in Jordanâ€™s best interests.Â  Cox filed a motion to reconsider, or in the alternative, to amend the judgment.Â  The family court denied Coxâ€™s motion and issued a supplemental order finding it had considered the time-frames of Coxâ€™s incarcerations and his conduct when not incarcerated in making the decision to terminate his parental rights.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In a termination of parental rights case (TPR), the best interests of the children are the paramount consideration. Â South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs v. Smith, 343 S.C. 129, 133, 538 S.E.2d 285, 287 (Ct. App. 2000). Grounds for TPR must be proved by clear and convincing evidence. Â Hooper v. Rockwell, 334 S.C. 281, 297, 513 S.E.2d 358, 366 (1999).Â  Furthermore, in a TPR case, the appellate court has jurisdiction to examine the entire record to determine the facts according to its view of the evidence.Â  Richland County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Earles, 330 S.C. 24, 32, 496 S.E.2d 864, 868 (1998). Â This court may review the record and make its own findings whether clear and convincing evidence supports termination.Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Parker, 336 S.C. 248, 254, 519 S.E.2d 351, 354 (Ct. App. 1999). Â However, our broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the findings below or ignore the fact the trial judge was in a better position to assess the credibility of the witnesses. Â Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 452, 477 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. App. 1996).

LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Termination of Parental Rights
Cox argues the family court lacked clear and convincing evidence to terminate his parental rights on the ground he failed to remedy the conditions that caused Jordanâ€™s removal.Â  We disagree.Â Â  
The termination of parental rights is governed by section 20-7-1572 of the South Carolina Code Annotated (Supp. 2005).Â  Pursuant to that section, parental rights may be terminated upon a showing of one or more enumerated grounds and a finding the termination is in the best interests of the child.Â  Under section 20-7-1572(2) parental rights may be terminated where: 

(2) The child has been removed from the parent pursuant to Section 20‑7‑610 or Section 20‑7‑736, has been out of the home for a period of six months following the adoption of a placement plan by court order or by agreement between the department and the parent, and the parent has not remedied the conditions which caused the removal. 

Jordan was removed pursuant to section 20-7-736 of the South Carolina Code Annotated (Supp. 2005), which provides, in pertinent part:

(B) Upon investigation of a report received under Section 20‑7‑650 or at any time during the delivery of services by the department, the department may petition the family court to remove the child from custody of the parent, guardian, or other person legally responsible for the childâ€™s welfare if the department determines by a preponderance of evidence that the child is an abused or neglected child and that the child cannot be safely maintained in the home in that he cannot be protected from unreasonable risk of harm affecting the childâ€™s life, physical health, safety, or mental well‑being without removal. 

Cox concedes he failed to complete the treatment plan, but argues his partial compliance and attendance to his relationship with Jordan mitigates his failure to complete the plan.Â  Specifically, Cox asserts that he provided support for his son, visited with his son, and was working together with Long to build a home.Â  He argues that his ability to find work was stymied by his prison record, parole, and transportation issues. Â He also contends he was not afforded a full and fair opportunity to complete the treatment plan. 
The evidence before us clearly and convincingly demonstrates that Cox failed to remove the impediment to his regaining custody of Jordan.Â  Cox did not begin to participate in the treatment plan until he was held in contempt, and he failed to successfully complete the treatment plan. The plan also obligated Cox to secure an appropriate residence for Jordan, but Cox continued to reside with his father, Randy Cox, where Jordan was at risk for sexual abuse.Â  Although Cox testified he and Long were trying to build a home for Jordan, no evidence was presented that Cox and Long were actively working toward this goal.Â  Accordingly, we agree with the family court that Cox failed to remedy the conditions that caused Jordanâ€™s removal.
The family court also found that clear and convincing evidence existed for terminating Coxâ€™s rights on the ground that â€œ[t]he child has been in foster care under the responsibility of the State for fifteen of the most recent twenty‑two months.â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(8) (Supp. 2005).Â  Cox does not argue the family court erred in terminating his rights on this ground; therefore, he has abandoned this issue in appeal. Â See State v. Hiott, 276 S.C. 72, 86, 276 S.E.2d 163, 170 (1981); Rule 208(b)(1)(B), (D), SCACR (issue not argued in brief is deemed abandoned and precludes consideration on appeal).Â  We note that this ground alone is sufficient to support a termination of parental rights.Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Sims, 359 S.C. 601, 608, 598 S.E.2d 303, 307 (Ct. App. 2004).Â Â  
B.Â  Incarceration
Cox argues the family court erred in not properly weighing his incarceration and the incidents of his incarceration in terminating his parental rights.Â  Specifically, Cox contends that his incarceration limited his ability to complete the treatment plan.Â  We disagree.Â Â  
Cox cites S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Wilson, 344 S.C. 332, 543 S.E.2d 580 (Ct. App. 2001) in support of his position that the trial court did not give sufficient weight to the hardships caused by his incarceration.Â  In Wilson, we held the voluntary pursuit of lawless behavior is one factor which may be considered when determining whether to terminate the parental rights of an incarcerated parent, but it generally is not determinative.Â  344 S.C. at 337, 543 S.E.2d at 583.Â  We also held that the analysis required to determine whether a parent who has been or is currently incarcerated foregoes parental duties requires a comprehensive analysis of all the facts and circumstances beyond the criminal act and its natural circumstances, including the nature of the parent-child relationship during the times the parent was not incarcerated.Â  Id. at 339, 543 S.E.2d at 584 (citing Hamby v. Hamby, 264 S.C. 614, 216 S.E.2d 536 (1975)).Â  
Here, the family court did not terminate Coxâ€™s parental rights based on his incarceration.Â  After careful consideration of how Coxâ€™s incarceration affected his ability to remedy the conditions which required removal, the family court found the ground for termination existed apart from fatherâ€™s incarceration.Â  Although Cox was in prison at the time his parental rights were terminated, he had a period of approximately fifteen months of freedom after Jordan was taken into custody in which he did not complete the treatment plan or find suitable housing for Jordan.Â  Cox took advantage of some of the services offered by the treatment plan, but he did not begin any portion of the plan until more than a year after he was ordered to do so and after he was threatened with jail time for contempt.Â  Cox cannot complain that he was not given the opportunity to complete the treatment plan because his parole was revoked, when he had ample time to complete the treatment plan before he was re-incarcerated.Â  Moreover, section 20-7-1572(2) only requires a showing that the child remained out of the home for a period of six months following the adoption of a placement plan to terminate on the ground that the parent has not remedied the conditions which caused the removal.Â  DSS did not file the TPR action prematurely as Cox asserts, but gave him more time than is statutorily required to remedy the conditions that caused removal.Â  Â 
C.   Â Best Interests 
Cox argues the family court erred in finding TPR is in Jordanâ€™s best interests.Â  We disagree.Â  
After finding one of the grounds for termination exists, section 20-7-1572 of the South Carolina Code Annotated (Supp. 2005) requires a determination that the termination is in the best interest of the child.Â  (â€œThe family court may order the termination of parental rights upon a finding of one or more of the following grounds and a finding that termination is in the best interest of the child. . .â€).Â  In a termination of parental rights case, the best interests of the child is the paramount consideration.Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Parker, 336 S.C. 248, 258, 519 S.E.2d 351, 356 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Termination of parental rights statutes â€œmust be liberally construed in order to ensure prompt judicial procedures for freeing minor children from the custody and control of their parents by terminating the parent-child relationship.Â  The interests of the child shall prevail if the childâ€™s interest and the parental interest conflicts.â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1578 (Supp.Â  2005). The purpose of the termination of parental rights statute is as follows:

[T]o establish procedures for the reasonable and compassionate termination of parental rights where children are abused, neglected, or abandoned in order to protect the health and welfare of these children and make them eligible for adoption by persons who will provide a suitable home environment and the love and care necessary for a happy, healthful, and productive life.Â Â  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1560 (Supp. 2005)
We agree with the family courtâ€™s finding the termination of Coxâ€™s parental rights is in Jordanâ€™s best interests.Â  Jordan has spent more than twenty months in foster care, and it would be in his best interest to be free for adoption, which would end his involvement in the foster care system and provide a stable family.Â  Moreover, Cox has proven unable to provide a secure and adequate environment for rearing a child.Â  See S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cochran, 364 S.C. 621, 632, 614 S.E.2d 642, 648 (2005) (stating the fundamental purpose of terminating parental rights is to provide the greatest possible protection for a child whose parents are unwilling or unable to provide adequate care for the physical and emotional needs of the child).Â  Accordingly, the order terminating Coxâ€™s parental rights is 
AFFIRMED.
KITTREDGE, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Cox previously had been incarcerated from May 16, 2001 until July 15, 2002.Â  
[2] Â Coxâ€™s prison sentence ended in July 2005.Â  
[3] SCDSS filed the action against both Cox and Long, and the family court terminated both parentâ€™s parental rights after a joint hearing; however, Cox is the sole appellant.

title: Montgomery v. Robinson
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Jimmy C. Montgomery; Gloria M. Jenkins; and Judith Allen,
Respondents,
v.
David Robinson, Jr.; Eleanor Coard; Josie M. Griffin; Mary G. Montgomery; Hazel M. Graham; Mary Lee Dingle; Willie W. Montgomery; Theresa M. Robertson; Anthony M. Montgomery; Delores M. Williams; Daryl Montgomery; Cassandra M. Montgomery; Almeta Montgomery; Jacqueline Williams; JoAnn Tilley; Ruth Ann Montgomery; Alvertis Montgomery, Jr.; Willie M. Montgomery; Minnie S. Montgomery; Marilyn Lee Montgomery; David Montgomery; and John Doe and Mary Roe, and all other persons unknown claiming any right, title, estate lien or interest in the real property described in the complaint or any claim adverse to Plaintiffsâ€™ ownership or any cloud on title thereto, Defendants,
of whom Mary G. Montgomery; Hazel M. Graham; Mary Lee Dingle; Willie W. Montgomery; Theresa M. Robertson; Anthony M. Montgomery; Delores M. Williams; and Daryl Montgomery are,
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Clarendon County
William C. Coffey, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-272
Submitted May 1, 2006 â€“ Filed June 8, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
M. M. Weinberg, Jr., of Sumter, for Appellants.Â  
William E. DuRant, Jr., of Sumter, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Appellants challenge the trial courtâ€™s order finding no agreement to subdivide property existed and, if it did, the agreement was insufficient to satisfy the statute of frauds.[1]Â  We affirm.[2]  
FACTS
The late David and Minnie Robinson owned 141.7 acres in Clarendon County. Â During a previous marriage, Minnie had two children, Willie and Alvertis Montgomery.Â  David and Minnie adopted one child, David, Jr.Â  
Minnie died intestate in 1964; Alvertis died in 1974 survived by his wife, Almetta, and eleven children; Willie died testate in 1984 survived by a wife and three children, including Henry Montgomery, Mary Montgomeryâ€™s husband; David died in 1987, and his interest in the property passed to David Jr.Â  
On December 11, 2000, some of the parties with interest in the property met and divided the property on a hand-drawn map with the various parcels color-coded. Â The land was divided into three parcels with one going to David Jr., one to heirs of Alvertis, and one to heirs of Willie.Â  The reverse side of the map contained the following notation: Â â€œAgreed to â€˜colorsâ€™ in division on front of this sheet so that David Jr. receives 22 acres, Almetta [Alvertisâ€™ wife] 20 acres, children of Alvertis 40 acres, Willieâ€™s heirs 60 acres.â€Â  The following notes were handwritten beside the map:

  
    
      
        Total acres: 
         141
      
      
        David
          Jr.   
         22
      
      
        
                           
          * * *
        
      
      
        Alvirtis (sic)
         59.5
      
      
        Willie  
         59.5
      
      
         
        
      
      
        Alvirtis (sic) heirsÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
        
      
      
        4.96 [a]cres each
        
      
    
  

The document was signed by those present.Â  The agreement was confirmed at a subsequent meeting on November 13, 2001.[3]Â 
In addition to the coding and handwritten notes concerning the division of the property, there were some handwritten notes relating to the subdivision of Willieâ€™s share.Â  Next to the map, Gloria Jenkins, one of Alvertisâ€™ eleven children, wrote the following: Â 

  
    
      
        Willie heirs  
         11.9 acres each
      
      
        Henry-Mary[4]
        
      
      
        
          J.C.
        
      
      
        Kitty
        
      
      
        Josie
        
      
      
        Eleanor
        
      
    
  

Appellant Mary Montgomery maintained this handwritten note constitutes a separate agreement among Willieâ€™s heirs. 
By consent order dated September 15, 2003, the parties agreed to the overall, primary division of the property.Â  However, Mary still contended that the notations as to Willieâ€™s share constituted an agreement regarding the subdivision of Willieâ€™s share.Â  The consent order therefore contained a reservation for Mary to â€œbring before the Court and have full opportunity to address and seek a determination of the issue of a settlement agreement existing as to the property allotted to her by agreement purportedly reached in or about December 2000 . . . .â€Â  The 2003 order attached the partiesâ€™ map as an exhibit. Â 
Mary Montgomery moved for a determination that she was entitled to the 11.9 â€œHenry-Maryâ€ acreage and 11.9 additional acres based on a side agreement she allegedly made with another heir, Josie, to purchase 11.9 acres.Â  She further contends that in reliance on the notes written on the map, she purchased the 11.9 acres from Josie and paid a large portion of the fee for the preparation of the survey. Â 
The court declined to further divide the property as requested, finding a failure to prove the existence of a separate agreement to subdivide Willieâ€™s share of the property.Â  The court further ruled any such agreement must be in writing to satisfy the statute of frauds.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
The â€œAgreementâ€
Appellants argue the notation placed by Gloria Jenkins on the agreement proves the existence of a separate contract subdividing Willieâ€™s parcel among his heirs.Â  Appellants also argue the separate contract satisfies the statute of frauds. 
The burden to prove the existence of a binding contract is on the party alleging the contract.Â  Griswold v. Texas Co., 163 S.C. 156, 173, 161 S.E. 409, 414-15 (1931).Â  A contract requires a meeting of the minds of all parties involved.Â  Hughes v. Edwards, 265 S.C. 529, 536, 220 S.E.2d 231, 234 (1975).Â  We find insufficient proof of a contract to subdivide Willieâ€™s property.Â  Gloria Jenkins testified she placed the notations on the agreement, â€œsimply dividing the 141 acres according to the family members.â€Â  Jenkins denied there was any agreement that the acres allotted to Willieâ€™s heirs would be partitioned as noted.Â  The attorneys present at the partiesâ€™ meetings swore in affidavits that the written agreement contained the terms agreed upon as to the primary division, but they were unaware of any agreement reached among the parties for a further subdivision.Â  Finally, only two of the eleven heirs affected by the alleged subdivision were present at the meeting when the notes were written.Â  We find insufficient proof of a contract.Â  
Because no contract existed, we need not reach the issue of whether the statute of frauds[5] would preclude enforcement of the alleged contract. Â See Player v. Chandler, 299 S.C. 101, 105, 382 S.E.2d 891, 894-95 (1989) (the statute of frauds requires a memorandum or note of an agreement relating to real estate to be in writing and signed by the party to be charged); Ruff v. Hudspeth, 122 S.C. 391, 395, 115 S.E. 626, 627 (1923) (the statute of frauds requires the writing to contain all of the essential elements of a contract).
Estoppel
Appellants also argue entitlement to the property based upon promissory estoppel.Â  Mary Montgomery alleges she personally paid more than her fair share of the survey costs in reliance on the alleged agreement. 
The trial court did not specifically rule on promissory estoppel, thus the issue is not preserved for review.Â  Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (an issue not ruled upon by the trial court is not preserved for appellate review).Â  
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, STILWELL, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1]There is some uncertainty whether all the named appellants are indeed appealing the trial courtâ€™s order.Â  It is nevertheless clear that Mary Montgomery is the principal, if not the sole, appellant.Â  We refer to them collectively as Appellants.Â  
[2] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[3] The nonparticipating parties apparently agreed with the division, according to a note on the confirmation.
[4] Mary Montgomery.
[5] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 32-3-10 (1991).

title: Ray v. The Caroline Collection
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Sheila Ray, as Personal Representative of the Estate of Lucille
Veneziani, Respondent,
v.
The Caroline Collection Inc., John Boyd and Caroline Boyd,
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Bamberg County
Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-273
Submitted June 1, 2006 â€“ Filed June 8, 2006

DISMISSED


  
    
      
James D. Mosteller, III, of Barnwell, for Appellants.Â  
Kristina Michelle Anderson, of Aiken, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Lucille Veneziani filed this fraud and negligent misrepresentation action against The Caroline Collection, Inc. and John W. Boyd and Caroline Boyd (collectively referred to as CCI).Â  Veneziani died during the pendency of the action and Sheila Ray, as personal representative of Venezianiâ€™s estate, moved to amend the complaint to request a jury trial and add additional causes of action.Â  CCI moved for summary judgment. Â The trial court denied CCIâ€™s motion for summary judgment and granted Rayâ€™s motion to amend.Â  CCI appeals.[1]
FACTS
In August of 2000, Veneziani became interested in a secretary in CCIâ€™s antique store.Â  The secretary was advertised as having been made in 1822 and formerly owned by â€œGovernor Morris, Ambassador to France.â€Â  The listed price was $20,000. Â 
Veneziani purchased the item for $14,000, paying $10,000 down and agreeing to pay $4,000.Â  She eventually paid $3,700 of the remaining balance.Â  Veneziani later had the item appraised and discovered it was a reproduction worth approximately $3,500. Â 
Veneziani filed this action on April 1, 2003 and did not request a jury trial.Â  Veneziani filed an amended complaint on April 21, 2003 and a second amended complaint by consent order on June 18, 2004.Â  CCI filed a motion for summary judgment on the fraud cause of action.Â  After a hearing on the matter, Veneziani died.Â  CCI moved for dismissal of the fraud cause of action, arguing it did not survive.Â  The trial court denied CCIâ€™s motions.
Ray then moved to amend to change the plaintiff to the estate, to add a claim for unfair trade practices, and to request a jury trial.Â  CCI also moved for summary judgment on the fraud and negligent misrepresentation causes of action, arguing they were personal to Veneziani and did not survive her death.Â  At the hearing, CCI argued the trial court should not allow Ray to amend the complaint as to the unfair trade practices claim, arguing it too was personal to Veneziani.Â  
The parties agreed the fraud cause of action was personal and it was dismissed.Â  The court granted Rayâ€™s motion to amend to add the unfair trade practices action and to include the request for a jury trial.Â  The court denied CCIâ€™s motion for summary judgment on the negligent misrepresentation cause of action. 
APPEALABILITY

CCI claims error on the following three issues:Â  1) the denial of the motion for summary judgment on the negligent misrepresentation claim; 2) allowing amendment of the complaint to add a claim for unfair trade practices; and 3) the grant of a jury trial.Â  We find the appeal of the denial of the motion for summary judgment is not appealable.Â  See Olson v. Faculty House of Carolina, Inc., 354 S.C. 161, 167, 580 S.E.2d 440, 443 (2003) (holding the denial of a motion for summary judgment is not appealable, even after final judgment).Â  We likewise find the appeal of an order allowing amendment of a pleading is not immediately appealable.Â  See Lake City Dev. Corp. v. Gilbert Constr. Co., 283 S.C. 10, 11, 320 S.E.2d 494, 494 (Ct. App. 1984) (finding order granting amendment to add a party interlocutory and not immediately appealable).Â  
As to the appealability of the grant of a jury trial, the issue turns on whether CCI is entitled to a non-jury trial as a matter of right.Â  When a trial courtâ€™s order deprives a party of a mode of trial to which it is entitled as a matter of right, such order is immediately appealable.Â  Hagood v. Sommerville, 362 S.C. 191, 196, 607 S.E.2d 707, 709 (2005).Â  We accordingly must first review whether CCI is entitled to a non-jury trial as a matter of right before determining the appealability of the issue.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A trial courtâ€™s ruling on a partyâ€™s request for a jury trial will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  See King v. Shorter, 291 S.C. 501, 502-03, 354 S.E.2d 402, 403 (Ct. App. 1987) (applying abuse of discretion standard to Rule 38(b) motion).Â  See also Satcher v. Satcher, 351 S.C. 477, 490, 570 S.E.2d 535, 541-42 (Ct. App. 2002) (applying abuse of discretion standard to Rule 39 motion).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS 
  CCI argues the trial court erred in granting Rayâ€™s request for a jury trial.Â  We disagree.

    Rule 38(b) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure provides:Â  
  
    Any party may demand a trial by jury of any issue triable of right by a jury by serving upon the other parties a demand therefor in writing at any time after the commencement of the action and not later than 10 days after the service of the last pleading directed to such issue. Â Such demand may be endorsed upon a pleading of the party.Â  
  

    Rule 38(b), SCRCP.Â  Whether a litigant is entitled to a jury trial on issues presented by an amended pleading, where no prior demand for a jury trial has been made, turns on whether the amended pleadings create new issues of fact.Â  King v. Shorter, 291 S.C. 501, 503, 354 S.E.2d 402, 403 (Ct. App. 1987).
    In this case, the trial court allowed amendment of the complaint to add a claim of unfair trade practices.Â  The court expressly found â€œthat there has been a substantial change in the posture of the case with the death of the Plaintiff such that the requested Amendment would serve the interests of justice and not be prejudicial to the Defendant[s].â€Â  The court further found:Â  â€œGiven the fact that the Plaintiff is . . . add[ing] additional causes of action, the Court finds that Rule 38 . . . would allow this Amended Complaint to contain a jury trial request as a matter of right.â€Â  Although approximately two years passed between the original complaint and the final amended complaint requesting a trial by jury, we likewise find no prejudice to CCI.Â  
    Under the abuse of discretion standard, we find no error.Â  See Hannah v. United Refrigeration Servs., Inc., 305 S.C. 394, 394, 409 S.E.2d 360, 361 (1991) (â€œA partyâ€™s failure to make a timely demand for a jury trial does not mean the opposing party acquires a right to have, as a matter of law, a non-jury trial.â€); Patterson v. McNeill-Patterson & Assocs., 312 S.C. 471, 472 n.2, 441 S.E.2d 328, 329 n.2 (Ct. App. 1994) (finding Rule 39(b) does not limit the courtâ€™s discretion in ordering a trial by jury where a party does not meet the requirements of Rule 38(b)). 
    CONCLUSION
    We find the order denying CCIâ€™s motion for summary judgment is not appealable.Â  We also find the order granting amendment to add the cause of action for unfair trade practices is not immediately appealable.Â  Finally, we find the trial court did not err in granting the motion to amend the complaint as to Rayâ€™s request for a jury trial.Â  Therefore, we find CCI not entitled to a non-jury trial as a matter of right and the order granting a jury trial is therefore not immediately appealable.Â  Accordingly, the appeal is
     DISMISSED.
    HUFF, STILWELL, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
