title: State v. Davis
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Jerry Davis, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â J. Mark Hayes, II, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-274
Heard May 9, 2006 â€“ Filed June 8, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â Jerry Davis appeals his conviction for forgery.Â  He contends the circuit court erred in permitting the State to impeach him with remote prior convictions that were similar to the charge for which he was being tried.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Davis owned and operated a construction business in Spartanburg.Â  Â Â Around November 10, 1995, he reported the theft of a forklift to his insurance company.Â  The insurance company investigated the claim and found the theft had been reported to the police.Â  In turn, the insurance company paid the claim and sent Davis a check in the amount of $35,000 made out to Jerry Davis and the National Bank of South Carolina (NBSC).Â  Â Â Davis attempted to have the check endorsed at Nationsbank in Columbia, but Nationsbank refused because it was not the payee of the check. Â Davis testified he then sent the check to NBSC with a letter in which he asked for an endorsement.Â  Davis claimed the letter was returned with an endorsement.Â  Â Â Subsequently, he instructed his secretary, Teresa Smith, to open an account and deposit the check at Carolina First in Taylors, South Carolina. 
On May 6, 1996, during the course of the investigation of the theft, the police suspected that Davis was driving a truck with a forklift on the back of it on Interstate 26 from Columbia towards Spartanburg.Â  Bobby Shealy, employed with the State Law Enforcement Division, parked in the median of the interstate to watch for Davis.Â  Shealy observed a truck with a forklift on it that matched the description of Davisâ€™s stolen forklift.Â  Shealy followed the truck and radioed for backup.Â  Once backup arrived, Shealy stopped the truck.Â  The driver of the truck informed Shealy he had rented the forklift from Davis and paid him $2,000 by check.Â  Later, the police found in Davisâ€™s possession the check with â€œrentalâ€ written on the subject line.
A Spartanburg County grand jury indicted Davis for making a false statement to an insurer, presenting a false claim for payment of loss, and forgery.Â  At trial, the State elected to proceed with the charges of forgery and presenting a false claim for payment of loss. 
During trial, Smith testified that when Davis initially showed her the check, it did not contain any endorsements.Â  When Smith saw the check again, one or two days later, it contained the signatures of both Davis and Kaye Gaddis, an employee of NBSC.Â  Smith testified Davis instructed her to purchase â€œa â€˜for deposit onlyâ€™ stamp and stamp it over [Gaddisâ€™s] name so that the lady . . . at Carolina First bank couldnâ€™t see whose name was signed.â€Â  Â Â Smith followed Davisâ€™s instructions and deposited the check at Carolina First.
Additionally, Gaddis testified Davis presented the check to her for endorsement.Â  Gaddis checked the bankâ€™s records, but found NBSC had never conducted business with Davis.Â  According to Gaddis, Davis tried to persuade her to endorse the check by explaining the check was made out to the wrong bank.Â  Gaddis refused to endorse the check and testified the signature on the check (â€œKaye Gaddisâ€) was not hers.
As the trial proceeded, the State informed the court that it intended to introduce Davisâ€™s prior convictions which were beyond the ten-year limitation outlined in Rule 609, SCRE.Â  Davis objected to the introduction of any convictions prior to 1977.Â  The trial court ruled the probative value of the convictions outweighed any prejudicial effect.Â  The court then permitted the State to inquire about the following convictions: Â 1976, 1977, and 1985 convictions for grand larceny; 1974, 1975, and 1976 convictions for receiving stolen goods; a 1984 federal conviction for receiving, stealing and selling motor vehicles; and a 1988 conviction for interstate transfer of a stolen vehicle.Â  The court, however, refused to permit the solicitor from inquiring about a 1987 conviction for escape, a 1985 conviction for failure to stop, a 1975 conviction for possession of firearms, and convictions for assault.
Ultimately, the jury found Davis guilty of forgery but deadlocked on the charge of presenting a false claim.Â  
Davis appealed his conviction for forgery, arguing the trial court erred in admitting into evidence his prior convictions that were more than ten years old.Â  State v. Davis, Op. No. 2000-UP-748 (S.C. Ct. App. filed Dec. 6, 2000).Â  On appeal, this court concluded the trial court did not articulate the specific facts and circumstances necessary to overcome the presumption against admissibility provided by Rule 609(b), SCRE.Â  Additionally, we were unable to determine if the trial court properly placed the burden of establishing the admissibility of the convictions on the State.Â  As a result, we remanded the case for the trial court to conduct a hearing on the admissibility of the prior convictions with instructions to apply the proper burden of establishing admissibility.Â  We also instructed the court to carefully weigh the probative value for impeachment with the prior convictions against the prejudice to Davis.Â  
On remand, the trial court found the probative value of the remote convictions outweighed their prejudicial value.Â  In reaching this conclusion, the court reasoned: Â (1) the State met its burden of proof to allow the introduction of the remote convictions and met the factors set forth by
State v. Colf, 337 S.C. 622, 627, 525 S.E.2d 246, 248 (2000); (2) the impeachment value of the past convictions was high; (3) Davisâ€™s criminal record was significant in the interest of justice because of Davisâ€™s â€œvirtually unbroken string of convictions from 1971â€; (4) the convictions admitted were similar to the forgery charge; (5) Davisâ€™s testimony was highly important given he was one of two defense witnesses to testify; and (6) Davisâ€™s credibility was a central issue given his testimony was in direct contradiction to that of the Stateâ€™s witnesses. Â The court also determined that due to the overwhelming evidence in the record, the admission of the prior convictions had little to no prejudicial effect on the outcome of the case.Â  Based on the foregoing analysis, the court affirmed Davisâ€™s conviction.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The admission of prior convictions to impeach the credibility of a defendant is a matter within the sound discretion of the trial judge, and thus, his decision will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion. Green v. State, 338 S.C. 428, 433, 527 S.E.2d 98, 101 (2000); see 
State v. Mansfield, 343 S.C. 66, 77, 538 S.E.2d 257, 263 (Ct. App. 2000)(â€œThe admissibility of evidence is within the sound discretion of the trial judge.Â  Accordingly, evidentiary rulings of the trial court will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion or the commission of legal error which results in prejudice to the defendant.â€)(citation omitted). Â An abuse of discretion occurs when the trial judgeâ€™s ruling is based on an error of law or a factual conclusion that is without evidentiary support.Â  State v. McDonald, 343 S.C. 319, 325, 540 S.E.2d 464, 467 (2000); State v. Walker, 366 S.C. 643, 654, 623 S.E.2d 122, 127 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  The scope of cross-examination is within the discretion of the trial judge, whose decision will not be reversed on appeal absent a showing of prejudice.Â  State v. Sherard, 303 S.C. 172, 174, 399 S.E.2d 595, 596 (1991).
DISCUSSION
I.
Davis argues the remand court erred in finding the similarity of the prior convictions to the current charge weighed in favor of their admissibility pursuant to Rule 609(b), SCRE.Â  We agree.
Rule 609, SCRE, governs the admissibility of convictions â€œ[f]or the purpose of attacking the credibility of a witness.â€ Â Rule 609(a), SCRE.Â  â€œ[E]vidence that an accused has been convicted of [a crime that was punishable by death or imprisonment in excess of one year] shall be admitted if the court determines that the probative value of admitting this evidence outweighs its prejudicial effect to the accused.â€ Rule 609(a)(1), SCRE. Â The admission of a prior conviction pursuant to Rule 609(a)(1) may, however, be limited depending upon the remoteness of the conviction.Â  Specifically, Rule 609(b) provides in pertinent part: 

Evidence of a conviction under this rule is not admissible if a period of more than ten years has elapsed since the date of the conviction or of the release of the witness from the confinement imposed for that conviction, whichever is the later date, unless the court determines, in the interests of justice, that the probative value of the conviction supported by specific facts and circumstances substantially outweighs its prejudicial effect.

Rule 609(b), SCRE.Â  â€œThe party attempting to introduce the prior conviction for impeachment purposes has the initial burden of establishing the basis for its admission.â€Â  State v. Scriven, 339 S.C. 333, 340, 529 S.E.2d 71, 74 (Ct. App. 2000).
In analyzing this rule, we have stated that if remote prior convictions â€œare either similar or identical to the charged offenses . . . the likelihood of a high degree of prejudice to the accused is inescapable.â€Â  Id. at 343, 529 S.E.2d at 76. Â This inherent prejudice occurs because evidence of similar offenses unavoidably suggests to the jury the defendantâ€™s propensity to commit the crime charged. Â State v. Colf, 337 S.C. 622, 628, 525 S.E.2d 246, 249 (2000) (Colf II).Â  â€œTherefore, â€˜[s]ince evidence of any similar offense should be admitted only rarely, a similar conviction already presumptively barred from admission by Rule 609(b) should be admitted even more rarely.â€™â€ Â Id.Â  (quoting United States v. Beahm, 664 F.2d 414, 419 (4th Cir. 1981)).Â  
Our supreme court, however, has espoused that similar prior convictions may be admissible in some situations. Â See Green v. State, 338 S.C. 428, 433, 527 S.E.2d 98, 101 (2000) (analyzing Rule 609(a)(1), SCRE and noting that federal courts have held that â€œprior convictions for the same or similar crimes are highly prejudicial and should be admitted sparingly,â€ but declining â€œto hold similar prior convictions inadmissible in all casesâ€).Â Â  Although similar prior convictions should not be categorically excluded, a trial court should be cognizant that treating prior crimes as if their similarity heightens their probative value is improper given the similarity actually increases the prejudicial effect.Â Â 
Colf II, 337 S.C. at 628, 525 S.E.2d at 249.
Turning to the instant case, the remand court based its decision in part on its finding that â€œthe convictions that the trial judge did admit for use for impeachment purposes were similar to the charges in the current case.â€Â 
In view of this statement, we find the trial court incorrectly applied the factor regarding the similarity of the crimes and erroneously considered the past convictions more probative because they were similar.Â  See 
Green, 338 S.C. at 434, 527 S.E.2d at 101 (â€œAdmission of evidence of a similar offense often does little to impeach the credibility of a testifying defendant while undoubtedly prejudicing him.â€). Â Based on this analysis, we hold the court erred as a matter of law and, thus, abused its discretion.Â  The similarity between the past convictions and the current charge actually made the convictions more prejudicial.Â  Davisâ€™s convictions for similar offenses were especially prejudicial given the jury may have concluded that the prior convictions implied Davis committed the offense with which he was charged.Â  Accordingly, the court erred in finding the similarity of the past convictions weighed in favor of admissibility.
II.
Davis also argues the remand court erred in finding the probative value of his remote convictions outweighed the prejudicial value.Â  We agree.
Under Rule 609(b), SCRE, the trial court must find â€œthat the probative value of the impeachment evidence substantially outweighs the prejudice to the accused.â€ Â Scriven, 339 S.C. at 341, 529 S.E.2d at 75.Â  Because Rule 609(b) raises a presumption against admissibility of remote prior convictions, a finding that the probative value outweighs the prejudice must be â€œsupported by specific facts and circumstances.â€Â  Id.Â  Therefore, when performing a 609(b) analysis, the trial court is required to carefully weigh the
competing â€œinterests involved and articulate for the record the specific facts and circumstances supporting its decision.â€Â  Id.Â 
In Colf II, our supreme court adopted a nonexclusive list of factors employed by federal courts when determining if the probative value of a prior conviction outweighs the prejudicial value. Â Colf II, 337 S.C. at 627, 525 S.E.2d at 248.Â  These factors are as follows:

1. The impeachment value of the prior crime.
2. The point in time of the conviction and the witnessâ€™s subsequent history. 
3. The similarity between the past crime and the charged crime.
4. The importance of the defendantâ€™s testimony. 
5. The centrality of the credibility issue. 

Id. (listing factors and stating that â€œtrial courts should exercise their discretion in light of the facts and circumstances of each particular caseâ€).
In the instant case, the convictions the trial court admitted were remote and similar to the charges for which Davis was being tried.Â  This combination made their admission even more unlikely.Â  See Colf II, 337 S.C. at 628, 525 S.E.2d at 249 (stating â€œâ€˜[s]ince evidence of any similar offense should be admitted only rarely, a similar conviction already presumptively barred from admission by Rule 609(b) should be admitted even more rarelyâ€™â€ (quoting United States v. Beahm, 664 F.2d 414, 419 (4th Cir. 1981))).Â  Further, in determining probative value, the important factor to examine is whether the evidence proves a certain â€œfact, not how important proof of that fact is to the proponentâ€™s case.â€ Â State v. Colf,
332 S.C. 313, 319, 504 S.E.2d 360, 362 (Ct. App. 1998) (Colf I), affâ€™d as modified, 337 S.C. 622, 525 S.E.2d 246 (2000) (Colf II). Â 
The remand court found the Stateâ€™s case against Davis was overwhelming due to the fact that Davisâ€™s testimony denying he forged the signature on the check was the only evidence that the endorsement was not forged.Â  Moreover, the State was able to impeach Davisâ€™s denial with his convictions after 1977.Â  Additionally, Gaddis testified she did not endorse the check and Smith testified how Davis instructed her to stamp over Gaddisâ€™s signature.Â  Therefore, the State presented sufficient evidence to undermine Davisâ€™s testimony without the remote convictions.Â  See  Colf I,
332 S.C. at 320, 504 S.E.2d at 363 (finding when the State has a strong case, â€œthe extrinsic offense may add little and consequently will be excluded more readilyâ€ (quoting United States v. Cathey, 591 F.2d 268, 276-77 (5th Cir. 1979))).Â  No special circumstances justified admission of the remote convictions. Â 
At oral argument, the State contended our decision in State v. Bryant, 356 S.C. 485, 589 S.E.2d 775 (Ct. App. 2003), cert. granted (Apr. 7, 2005), required us to affirm the decision of the remand court.Â  Because we find Bryant distinguishable from the instant case, we reject this contention.Â  In Bryant, the defendant was convicted of murder and unlawful possession of a firearm.Â  The defendant appealed, arguing the trial court erred by admitting evidence of his prior bad acts and convictions.Â  In terms of the prior convictions, Bryant asserted the convictions were inadmissible under Rule 609(a)(1), SCRE, because their prejudicial effect outweighed their probative value.Â  Id. at 489, 589 S.E.2d at 777.Â  We affirmed the trial courtâ€™s decision based on the following grounds:Â  (1) the trial court correctly found â€œtestimony could lead to an inference that Bryant was unworthy of credibility because of his prior convictionsâ€; (2) the court conducted the appropriate Colf analysis and balanced the prejudicial versus probative value of the convictions pursuant to Rule 609(a)(1), SCRE; and (3) evidence existed in the record to support its ruling. Id. at 493, 589 S.E.2d at 779.Â  Unlike the court in Bryant, the remand court in the instant case incorrectly found the similarity of the prior convictions to the charged offense increased the probative value of the convictions.Â  Moreover, the prior convictions in the instant case were extremely remote whereas Bryantâ€™s prior convictions were not given they were only two years old.Â Â Â Â  
Additionally, the State urged this court to find that any error in the admission of the remote prior convictions constituted harmless error.Â  In support of this argument, the State pointed out the admission of the pre-1977 convictions was cumulative to the unchallenged admission of the post-1977 convictions.Â  As will be discussed, we agree with the State and affirm the order of the remand court.[1]
In ruling on the admission of the prior convictions, the remand court not only analyzed their admission under Rule 609, SCRE, but also found â€œthe admission of the prior convictions had very little, if any, prejudicial effect on the outcome of this case.â€Â  The court reached this decision based on the overwhelming evidence in the record and the lack of credibility of one of the defense witnesses.Â  Although we find the remand court erred in its analysis regarding the admission of the prior convictions, we agree with the courtâ€™s ultimate conclusion that their admission was harmless.Â  
â€œAn error is harmless if the defendantâ€™s guilt has been conclusively proven by competent evidence, such that no other result could have been reached.â€Â  State v. Johnson, 363 S.C. 53, 60, 609 S.E.2d 520, 524 (2005).Â  â€œThe circumstances of each individual case are to be considered.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œIn addition, the error is harmless if the error could not have reasonably affected the outcome of the trial.â€Â  Id.
Here, the State presented testimony that investigating officers found in Davisâ€™s possession a check for the rental of the forklift that Davis had reported to his insurance company as stolen.Â  Additionally, Kaye Gaddis, an employee of NBSC, testified that she did not endorse the insurance check because the NBSC bank records revealed that the bank had never conducted business with Davis as he had claimed.Â  She also stated that the signature on the check was not hers.Â  Smith, Davisâ€™s secretary, testified that when she was initially shown the check it did not contain any endorsements.Â  When Davis presented her the check a second time, Smith noticed that it contained the signatures of Davis and Gaddis.Â  Smith testified that Davis instructed her to purchase a â€œfor deposit onlyâ€ stamp and stamp it over Gaddisâ€™s name.Â  In addition to this overwhelming evidence of guilt, we would also note that Davis did not challenge the admission of the post-1977 convictions.Â  Accordingly, we hold the remand court properly found the admission of the convictions did not constitute prejudicial error.Â  See Johnson, 363 S.C. at 60, 609 S.E.2d at 524 (holding admission of prior convictions constituted harmless error where defense counsel introduced defendantâ€™s prior convictions on direct examination to lessen the impact they might have on defendantâ€™s credibility, the record contained other testimony that damaged defendantâ€™s credibility, and there was overwhelming evidence of defendantâ€™s guilt); cf. Scriven, 339 S.C. at 344, 529 S.E.2d at 77 (finding admission of prior convictions was not harmless error where convictions were eight years old at the time of trial, the prior convictions and the charged offenses were similar, and the prior convictions presented â€œa great likelihood of prejudice to the accusedâ€). 
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we hold the remand court improperly determined that because the prior convictions were similar to the charged offense they were more probative given the similarity actually made the prior convictions more prejudicial.Â  Additionally, we find the remand court incorrectly found the probative value of Davisâ€™s remote convictions of similar crimes outweighed their prejudicial value.Â  We find, however, the remand court properly concluded that the admission of the remote convictions was not prejudicial.Â  Because there was overwhelming evidence of Davisâ€™s guilt, we agree with the remand court that the admission of Davisâ€™s prior convictions constituted harmless error.Â  Accordingly, the order of the remand court is
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, STILWELL, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] Because the remand court specifically ruled the admission of the pre-1977 convictions was not prejudicial to Davis, we affirm on this ground appearing in the record on appeal.Â  See State v. Arnold, 319 S.C. 256, 260 n.3, 460 S.E.2d 403, 405 n.3 (Ct. App. 1995) (holding Rule 220(c), SCACR, allows appellate court to affirm on any ground appearing in the record); see also Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 418, 526 S.E.2d 716, 722 (2000) (holding under Rules 208(b)(2) and 220(c), SCACR, a respondent, as a prevailing party in the trial court, may raise on appeal any additional reasons the appellate court should affirm the trial court regardless of whether the reasons were presented to or ruled on by the trial court, provided the respondentâ€™s additional sustaining grounds appear in the record on appeal).

title: State v. Gibson
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Robert Gibson, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â Clifton Newman, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-275
Submitted June 1, 2006 â€“ Filed June 8, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General David A. Spencer, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Warren Blair Giese, of Columbia; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Robert Gibson appeals his convictions for armed robbery and kidnapping.Â  He contends the circuit court erred in declining to grant a mistrial after a witness referred to his status as a parolee.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
At approximately 10:15 p.m. on May 22, 2002, Michael Bethel left work and drove his uncleâ€™s 1990 white Cadillac to Rushâ€™s on Broad River Road in Columbia to get a milk shake.Â  After Bethel returned to his car, he realized that he had left his wallet inside Rushâ€™s.Â  Bethel drove around the parking lot, parked his car, and returned to Rushâ€™s.Â  As Bethel exited his car, he was approached by a male who asked him â€œwhere any weed was at.â€Â  Bethel did not respond and continued walking toward the restaurant. 
After retrieving his wallet, Bethel left Rushâ€™s and called his roommate on his cell phone at approximately 10:26 p.m.Â  When Bethel started the engine of his car, he was approached by an African-American male wielding a gun.Â  Bethel had seen the man exit the passenger side of a nearby parked car.Â  As Bethel got out of his car, the robber ordered him to get back into the car. Â The robber then sat down in the back seat of Bethelâ€™s car and pointed the gun at the back of Bethelâ€™s head.Â  
The robber instructed Bethel to drive to an apartment complex off of Broad River Road. Â As Bethel was driving, he noticed the car which the robber had been in was following him.Â  The robber then directed Bethel to stop and park on a side street.Â  After ordering Bethel to exit the vehicle, the robber demanded the chain that Bethel was wearing as well as his cell phone and pocket money.Â  The robber then drove off in Bethelâ€™s car. Â Bethel immediately called the police at 10:40 p.m.
An investigation by the Richland County Sheriffâ€™s Department revealed that Bethelâ€™s cell phone was used to call Gibsonâ€™s motherâ€™s cell phone at 10:58 p.m., 11:16 p.m., and 11:34 p.m. on the evening of the robbery.Â  June Collier, Gibsonâ€™s former girlfriend who lived in Horry County received a call from Gibson on Bethelâ€™s cell phone at approximately 11:46 p.m. on May 22, 2002, and at 1:21 a.m. the next morning.Â  Collier returned Gibsonâ€™s call and left a voicemail message on Bethelâ€™s phone.Â  As a result of this communication, Collier met Gibson and his passenger, Quinton Sanders, in Conway.Â  Gibson followed Collier back to her home.Â  Gibson and Sanders stayed with Collier and then left after breakfast on May 23, 2002. 
Later in the day, Gibson drove to Florence to visit with his former girlfriend, Tracey Porche. Â Porche testified that Gibson and Sanders arrived in an older model white car.Â  The three then left to pick up lunch at a nearby restaurant.Â  As they drove through town, Porche instructed Gibson to turn down the music in the car when she noticed a police officer.Â  Porche testified Sanders removed a gun from the glove compartment and placed it under his clothes when the officer began to follow them. Â According to the officer, Gibson began to drive in a â€œvery suspiciousâ€ manner.Â  Based on this observation, the officer requested that dispatch run a check on the license plate number.Â  When the license plate check revealed that the car was stolen and had been part of an armed robbery, the officer requested backup officers. Â Â Police officers surrounded the car after Gibson pulled into a McDonaldâ€™s.Â  Ignoring the officersâ€™ orders to the occupants to stop and put their hands in the air, Gibson sped up and a chase ensued.Â  
Gibson led officers on a high-speed chase through commercial and residential areas.Â  Porche testified that Sanders discarded the gun during the chase.Â  Ultimately, Gibson lost control of the car and jumped out while it was still in motion.Â  The officers were able to apprehend Gibson, Sanders, and Porche after the car crashed into a tree and caught on fire.Â  
On May 28, 2002, Bethel was presented with a photographic lineup in which he positively identified Gibson as the robber.
A Richland County grand jury indicted Gibson for armed robbery and kidnapping.Â  A jury convicted Gibson of both of these charges.Â  The trial judge sentenced Gibson to two concurrent terms of fifteen years imprisonment.Â  This appealed followed.
DISCUSSION
Gibson argues the trial judge erred in declining to grant his request for a mistrial after Porche testified regarding his status as a parolee.Â  We disagree.
During direct examination of Porche, the solicitor questioned her regarding the high-speed chase.Â  Specifically, he inquired:

Q.Â  Were they talking at all in the front seat during all this?
A.Â Â  No, there wasnâ€™t much talk.Â  I was asking [Gibson] why he was running?Â  And he says something about parole.Â  And . . . he was asking the passenger was I all right after we went over 52 and the car was airborne.Â  But there wasnâ€™t much of a conversation in the car. 

Without objection, the solicitor continued his direct examination and asked Porche eight more questions.Â  At the conclusion of Porcheâ€™s direct examination, Gibsonâ€™s counsel approached the judge and requested a conference outside the presence of the jury.Â  During this hearing, counsel stated:

At this point in time I move for a mistrial on this case.Â  The basis for the motion is [the solicitor] asked Ms. Porche about any conversation she heard in the car, asked himâ€”asked him why he was running from the police.Â  
And her response was that he indicated something about him being on parole, thatâ€™s a reference to prior criminal conviction.
The record is clear I didnâ€™t jump up at that moment in time and object, but the damage had already been done.Â  I prefer not to ring the bell as loud as possible making an objection at that point in time.Â  I addressed the court in the matter as soon as possible without making a big deal about it in front of the jury.
But it does place his prior criminal history at issue in front of this jury when he has not so placed it himself.Â  It is a valid basis for a mistrial motion in that regard, and I would so move.Â  

In response, the solicitor asserted the testimony was admissible as part of the res gestae of the offenses and that he intentionally elicited testimony.Â Â Â  In the alternative, the solicitor contended the testimony did not constitute hearsay because it was not offered for the truth of the matter asserted.Â  Even if the testimony was inadmissible, the solicitor argued that a mistrial was not warranted given it was a single statement that was â€œfairly vague and innocuous.â€ 
After hearing arguments from counsel, the trial judge determined the testimony improperly placed Gibsonâ€™s character into evidence.Â  Despite this holding, the court found a mistrial was not warranted.Â  Gibsonâ€™s counsel declined the judgeâ€™s offer to give a curative instruction to the jury. 
As a threshold matter, we question whether Gibson properly preserved this issue for appellate review.Â  Gibsonâ€™s counsel did not immediately object to Porcheâ€™s reference to Gibsonâ€™s status as a parolee.Â  Counsel allowed the State to complete its direct examination before any objection to the testimony was verbalized.Â  Instead of contemporaneously objecting to the testimony, counsel moved for a mistrial.Â  Additionally, Gibsonâ€™s counsel refused the trial judgeâ€™s offer to issue a curative instruction. Â In view of these procedural errors, we believe Gibson waived any challenge to Porcheâ€™s statement.Â  See State v. Moultrie, 316 S.C. 547, 555-56, 451 S.E.2d 34, 39 (Ct. App. 1994) (â€œOur courts have held a â€˜failure to contemporaneously objectâ€™ to the introduction of evidence claimed to be prejudicial â€˜cannot be later bootstrapped by a motion for a mistrial.â€™â€ (quoting State v. Lynn, 277 S.C. 222, 226, 284 S.E.2d 786, 789 (1981))); see also State v. Watts, 321 S.C. 158, 164-65, 467 S.E.2d 272, 276 (Ct. App. 1996) (finding defendant waived any argument regarding his denial of a mistrial based on testimony implicating he had a prior record where defense counsel refused trial judgeâ€™s offer to strike the testimony or issue a curative instruction); State v. Hartley, 307 S.C. 239, 244-45, 414 S.E.2d 182, 186 (Ct. App. 1992) (concluding defense counsel failed to preserve any argument concerning the Stateâ€™s attempt to impeach defendant with his prior convictions where counsel refused the trial judgeâ€™s offer to issue a curative instruction). Â Â 
Even if properly preserved, we find Gibsonâ€™s argument to be without merit.Â  The decision whether to grant or deny a motion for a mistrial is within the sound discretion of the trial judge and will not be overturned on appeal absent an abuse of discretion amounting to an error of law.Â  State v. Council, 335 S.C. 1, 12, 515 S.E.2d 508, 514 (1999).Â  â€œThe power of a court to declare a mistrial ought to be used with the greatest caution under urgent circumstances, and for very plain and obvious causesâ€ stated on the record by the trial judge.Â  State v. Kirby, 269 S.C. 25, 28, 236 S.E.2d 33, 34 (1977).Â  
A mistrial should only be granted when â€œabsolutely necessary,â€ and a defendant must show both error and resulting prejudice in order to be entitled to a mistrial.Â  State v. Harris, 340 S.C. 59, 63, 530 S.E.2d 626, 628 (2000).Â  â€œWhether a mistrial is manifestly necessary is a fact specific inquiry.â€Â  State v. Rowlands, 343 S.C. 454, 457, 539 S.E.2d 717, 719 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  â€œ[T]he trial judge should exhaust other methods to cure possible prejudice before aborting a trial.â€Â  Council, 335 S.C. at 13, 515 S.E.2d at 514.
In the instant case, Porcheâ€™s statement was a vague and isolated comment regarding Gibson status as a parolee.Â  Moreover, our appellate courts have found a mistrial was not warranted where a trial judge admitted even more egregious testimony implicating a defendantâ€™s prior record.Â  See, e.g., Council, 335 S.C. at 12-13, 515 S.E.2d at 513-14 (affirming trial judgeâ€™s refusal to grant a mistrial where SLED agent testified that he retrieved defendantâ€™s fingerprint card from SLED records for comparison); State v. George, 323 S.C. 496, 510-11, 476 S.E.2d 903, 912 (1996) (finding mistrial was not warranted where witnessâ€™s reference to defendantâ€™s possible drug dealing was vague and no testimony was presented establishing this behavior); State v. Creech, 314 S.C. 76, 81-82, 441 S.E.2d 635, 638 (Ct. App. 1993) (holding trial judge did not abuse his discretion in denying defendantâ€™s motion for a mistrial where officer testified that he obtained warrants for defendantâ€™s arrest and contacted â€œthe Probation Officerâ€). Â Accordingly, we conclude the trial judge did not abuse his discretion in denying Gibsonâ€™s motion for a mistrial.Â Â  
Even if the judgeâ€™s decision to deny Gibsonâ€™s motion for a mistrial constituted error, we find any error would be deemed harmless.Â  Whether an error is harmless depends upon the circumstances of the specific case.Â  State v. Taylor, 333 S.C. 159, 172, 508 S.E.2d 870, 876 (1998).Â  Error is harmless when it could not have reasonably affected the result of the trial.Â  State v. Key, 256 S.C. 90, 93-94, 180 S.E.2d 888, 889-90 (1971).Â  â€œ[W]here a review of the entire record establishes the error is harmless beyond a reasonable doubt, the conviction should not be reversed.â€Â  State v. Pickens, 320 S.C. 528, 531, 466 S.E.2d 364, 366 (1996). Â 
Here, Bethel positively identified Gibson as the man who robbed him and then stole his car.Â  Cell phone records showed that shortly after the robbery Bethelâ€™s phone was used to contact Gibsonâ€™s mother and his two former girlfriends.Â  After receiving a phone call from Gibson, Porche left a voicemail message on Bethelâ€™s cell phone which Bethel later turned over to the investigating officers.Â  Finally, Gibson was apprehended while driving Gibsonâ€™s car.Â  Thus, there was overwhelming evidence establishing Gibsonâ€™s guilt for the offenses of armed robbery and kidnapping.
Based on the foregoing, Gibsonâ€™s convictions and sentences are
 AFFIRMED.
HUFF, STILWELL, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1]Â Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Hopkins v. Brown
text:
The South Carolina Court of Appeals


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Mildred Brown Hopkins,
Respondent,
v.
Nelle B. Brown; Frances Brown Nachman; Melville P. Brown, Jr.; Lloyd William Brown, Jr.; Marjorie P. Brown; Harriette T. Elrod; Gary
Dolbee; Larry Dolbee; Julie Dolbee Albea; Mary Catherine Tucker Carter; Harriette Jane Tucker, individually and as Personal Representative of the Estate of Harrison Tucker, Jr., Deceased; Harrison Tucker, III; Michael J. Costa; Margaret Costa Baird; Zena Costa Brown; Thomas A. Brown, Jr.; Benjamin Richard Brown; Lawrence Wilton Brown; and, all other persons, both known and unknown, in esse and unborn, claiming or entitled to claim any right, title or interest as an heir or devisee of any of the above named now deceased; also, all other persons, both know or unknown, in esse and unborn, claiming or entitled to claim any right, title or interest in or lien up on the real estate described in the Complaint herein or as an heir at law,
distributee, devisee, legatee or assign of either the foregoing who may be deceased or Lawrence Joseph Costa, Harrison Tucker, Jr., Onie Johnson Brown, Earl
Dolbee, Jr., Earl Dolbee, Sr., Ethel Viola Brown, Sue Brown Tucker, George A. Brown, Myrtle Costa Brown, Thomas A. Brown, Sr., Ben T. Brown, Melville P. Brown, Sr., Lillian Brown
Dolbee, Lillian Roberts Brown and John Wesley Brown, some or all of whom may be deceased; any unknown adults being as a class designated as â€œJohn Doeâ€ and any unknown infants or persons under disability or in the military service of the United States being as a class designated as â€œRichard Roeâ€, Defendants,
Of whom Nelle B. Brown is the, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Anderson County
Ellis B. Drew, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-276
Submitted June 1, 2006 â€“ Filed June 8, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Francis T. Draine, of Columbia, for Appellant.Â  
Harold P. Threlkeld, of Anderson, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Nelle Brown appeals the denial of her motion to vacate the default judgment against her.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
In 1919, John Wesley Brown acquired a house and lot at 703 East Greenville Street in Anderson, South Carolina (the property).Â  Thereafter, Brown lived on the property with his wife, Lillian, and their ten children until his death in 1948.Â  Brown devised the property to his widow for her life, with the remainder to their children.[2]Â  After Lillian Brownâ€™s death, George Brown, Sr., John and Lillianâ€™s son, and his wife Nelle, the appellant in this case, continued to live on the property with the consent and permission of the other owners.Â  As a condition of living on the property rent free, the Browns were required to maintain the property and the house, including paying the taxes and insuring the property.Â  The property was destroyed by fire on April 29, 2001, and shortly thereafter, George, Sr. died from injuries sustained in that fire.Â  As a result of the fire, Nelle and her son, George, Jr., vacated the property, and their whereabouts were generally unknown to other family members.Â  
In December of 2002, the City of Anderson condemned the remains of the burned residence on the property and attempted to notify owners of the condemnation.Â  Mildred Brown Hopkins, granddaughter of John Wesley Brown and a resident of Anderson, was the only co-owner of the property who could easily be located.Â  She was the only family member officially notified of the cityâ€™s demolition requirement.Â  The city would demolish the structure at the ownersâ€™ expense or the owners could arrange for demolition themselves.Â  Hopkins was able to obtain the consent of all co-owners for demolition except for Nelle Brown, whom she was unable to locate.Â  
In March 2003, Hopkins contracted with Millerâ€™s Construction Company to demolish the structure for $21,100, which Hopkins paid.Â  In April, Hopkins filed an action against the co-owners of the property to foreclose on a mechanicâ€™s lien to recover the cost of the demolition and to partition the property and the proceeds of the fire insurance policy.Â  All the co-owners Hopkins was able to serve consented to foreclosure of the mechanicâ€™s lien and the partition action.Â  
Hopkins was unable to ascertain the whereabouts of Nelle Brown in order to serve her.Â  Thereafter, Hopkinsâ€™ attorney contacted an attorney who had represented Nelle in an action related to the property prior to the fire.[3]Â  The attorney indicated the pleadings could be mailed to him for acceptance of service.Â  However, he never actually accepted service, and notified Hopkins in July of 2003 that he no longer represented Nelle, would not accept service on her behalf, and could not disclose her whereabouts.Â  
Hopkins attempted to locate Nelle, but was unable to discern her whereabouts or even confirm if she was living or deceased.Â  The Anderson County Sheriffâ€™s Office could likewise not locate her.Â  Hopkins then petitioned for an Order of Publication for purposes of effecting service on Nelle.Â  The Petition was granted, and notice was published in The Journal, a newspaper published in the town of Williamston, as the newspaper most likely to give notice to Nelle Brown.[4]Â  In addition, pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-9-740, a copy of the pleadings was mailed to Nelle at her last known address, 703 East Greenville Street.Â  
No responsive pleadings were filed by Nelle Brown.Â  Notice of a merits hearing to be held before the master was sent to Nelle Brown at her last known address.Â  
Hopkins testified that she had attempted to contact all of the other family members/co-owners.Â  She further testified that Nelle Brown had been close and on good terms with Hopkinsâ€™ mother until George, Jr. returned to the area from Washington, D.C.Â  After that time, according to Hopkins, George, Jr. and to some degree George, Sr., kept Nelle in seclusion and no longer allowed contact between Nelle and other family members.Â  Hopkins stated that she believed she had acted in the best interests of all the co-owners by having the property demolished.Â  
The court granted foreclosure of the mechanicâ€™s lien and decreed the partition.Â  The property was sold at public sale to Anderson Area Medical Center, Inc. in March 2004, and the proceeds were disbursed in accordance with the courtâ€™s decree.Â  Then, in April, Hopkinsâ€™ attorney was contacted by James Stone Craven, who indicated that he was representing Nelle Brown with regard to the property.Â  Nelle filed an action against Hopkins and the other co-owners regarding the property.Â  It is unclear from the record the exact nature of the action, but the claims arising therefrom were dismissed on summary judgment.Â  Nelleâ€™s portion of the proceeds from the sale of the property, $43,902.18, was forwarded to her attorney.Â  In January of 2005, Nelle Brown moved to have the default judgment as to the mechanicâ€™s lien and partition of the property set aside. Â The denial of her motion is the subject of this appeal.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œWhether to grant or deny a motion under Rule 60(b) lies within the sound discretion of the judge.Â  Our standard of review, therefore, is limited to determining whether there was an abuse of discretion.â€Â  Raby Const., L.L.P. v. Orr, 358 S.C. 10, 17, 594 S.E.2d 478, 482 (2004) (internal citations omitted).Â  Rule 60(b), SCRCP, provides that the court may relieve a party from a final judgment for mistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect, on the basis of newly discovered evidence, for fraud, misrepresentation, or other misconduct of an adverse party, or if the judgment is void or has been discharged.Â  A motion under 60(b) â€œshall be made within a reasonable time.â€Â  Id.  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Nelle contends the trial court erred in failing to set aside the judgment for several reasons.Â  First, she contends the affidavits used to procure the default judgment were fraudulent.Â  She further argues the judgment should have been vacated because she was not served with notice on an unliquidated damages claim and that the service by publication was faulty.Â  Finally, Nelle contends the court erred by ordering that proceeds from the insurance policy on the property be divided among the co-owners.
The crux of Nelleâ€™s contentions seems to be that she was â€œtheâ€ owner of the property and that Hopkins intentionally failed to provide her with notice of any claims or proceedings in order to deprive her of her property and the proceeds related thereto.Â  There is simply no evidence in the record to support these allegations.Â  
The record reveals that Hopkins filed a petition for publication indicating that she could not locate Nelle Brown and believed her whereabouts were being secreted in order to avoid service.Â  An affidavit was filed by the sheriffâ€™s office indicating that it had attempted to serve Nelle but was unable to do so.Â  There is nothing facially defective about these documents nor is there any testimony in the record that would indicate the information contained therein was untrue.Â  
Furthermore, the record shows that notice of the January 20, 2004 hearing was mailed to Nelle Brown at her last known address.Â  She argues that such notice was insufficient.Â  However, the damages prayed for by Hopkins were liquidated, rendering notice of a damages hearing unnecessary.Â  See Thomas & Howard Co., Inc. v. T.W. Graham & Co., 318 S.C. 286, 457 S.E.2d 340 (1995) (holding that when damages are liquidated or a verified complaint for unliquidated damages is sufficient to allow the amount of the claim to be determined, a damages hearing is not required).Â  In any event, according to Rule 5(b), SCRCP, service by regular mail to a defendantâ€™s last known address is all that is required even if the damages in this case are considered to be unliquidated.Â  Therefore, if notice was required, the notice given was adequate.Â  
The nature of the action in this case was in rem as opposed to in personam.Â  Nelle Brown was only a defendant in the case by virtue of her standing as a co-owner of the property.Â  She was not exposed to personal liability for any â€œdamagesâ€ to which Hopkins may have been entitled.Â  Hopkins requested from the court the amount she had expended in demolishing the home and for taxes she had paid.Â  She further sought costs and attorneyâ€™s fees associated with the action, the partitioning of the property and the distribution of insurance proceeds according to the co-ownersâ€™ respective interests set forth in detail in the complaint.Â  These items all relate to the property and do not constitute the type of unliquidated damages frequently at issue in a damages hearing.Â  Even if they were, the amounts at issue were determinable by reference to the complaint.Â  
With regard to service by publication, the record shows that The Journal is a newspaper of general circulation in Anderson County, South Carolina, the county in which Nelle was last known to reside.Â  It is the clerkâ€™s responsibility to select the newspaper â€œmost likely to give notice to the person to be served.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-9-740 (Rev. 2005).Â  There is no evidence that publication in The Journal was faulty.Â  Finally, any issue regarding the distribution of insurance proceeds was neither raised to nor ruled upon by the trial court.Â  Therefore, such issue is not preserved for our review.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (holding that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and rule upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review).Â  
Because we can discern no abuse of discretion in the masterâ€™s denial of the motion to vacate, that judgment is hereby
AFFIRMED.
 HUFF, STILWELL, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Â Â Â Â Â Â  The children of any deceased heirs would receive their parentâ€™s share.Â  
[3] Â Â Â Â Â Â  This action was dismissed for failure to prosecute.Â  
[4] Â Â Â Â Â Â  The Order of Publication appointed E. Alex Turner, III, as guardian ad litem and attorney for Nelle Brown.Â

title: State v. Hunsucker
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Gary Russell Hunsucker, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-277
Heard May 9, 2006 â€“ Filed June 8, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Karen Newell Fryar and M. Celia Robinson, both of Columbia, for Appellant.Â  
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General David A. Spencer, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Edgar Lewis Clements, III, of Florence, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Gary Russell Hunsucker appeals his convictions for first degree burglary, conspiracy, armed robbery, and possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS
Dr. Jim Haswell testified that around 8:30 p.m. on August 25, 2003, a small, thin man forced his way into Haswellâ€™s house, put a gun to his head, and took $160.Â  After robbing Haswell, the assailant fled across the front yard, got in the passenger side of a dark colored sedan, and sped off.Â  Haswell described his assailant as around 140 or 150 pounds and about five feet ten inches tall.Â  Haswell further testified his assailant â€œsmelled heavily of tobacco smoke,â€ was wearing blue baggies or booties over his feet, a blue bandana across his face, a blue cap, and rubber surgical gloves.Â  
Hunsucker was apprehended about a week after the incident.Â  Teresa Hennigan, the officer who booked him, testified that Hunsuckerâ€™s physical characteristics at the time of booking matched Haswellâ€™s description.Â  Hennigan further testified that during the booking process she collected one lighter, one cigarette, and two packs of unopened cigarettes from Hunsuckerâ€™s person.Â  
Matthew Faison was also charged for the robbery.Â  Faison testified that on the day of the robbery Hunsucker asked Faison for a ride because he needed â€œto go pick up some money.â€Â  Faison, who apparently did not have a car, testified he called John Hayes, a/k/a A.J., an acquaintance who did have a car.Â  Soon thereafter, Hayes arrived and Faison and Hunsucker got into Hayesâ€™ car.Â  Hunsucker, according to Faisonâ€™s testimony, was wearing a blue do-rag, â€œdoctor gloves,â€ and trash bags on his shoes.Â  
According to Faison, Hunsucker directed Hayes to drive to Haswellâ€™s house.Â  Upon arriving, Hunsucker went to the front door, knocked on it, and when it opened pointed a gun at the face of the â€œdudeâ€ who answered the door.Â  Following a verbal exchange to which Faison was not privy, Haswell eventually handed something to Hunsucker.Â  Hunsucker returned to the car, and Hayes drove Hunsucker to his home.Â  Faison and Hayes continued on to their respective homes.Â  
The State also called Hayes to testify.Â  Hayes testified he weighed 200 pounds, was six feet tall, and drove a four-door 2001 maroon Pontiac.Â  The State attempted to question Hayes about a statement he gave to the police regarding his knowledge of the robbery.Â  Hayes admitted he gave a statement but refused to comment on the statement and refused to testify about the Haswell robbery.Â  Hayesâ€™ statement was not admitted into evidence.Â  Hunsucker informed the court he did not want to ask Hayes any questions, and Hayes was excused without being cross-examined.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only and is bound by the factual findings of the trial court unless clearly
erroneous. Â State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5-6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  On review, we are limited to determining whether the trial judge abused his discretion.Â  Id.Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the trial courtâ€™s ruling is based on an error of law.Â  State v. McDonald, 343 S.C. 319, 325, 540 S.E.2d 464, 467 (2000).Â  In order for an error to warrant reversal, the error must result in prejudice to the appellant.Â  State v. Wyatt, 317 S.C. 370, 372-73, 453
S.E.2d 890, 891 (1995).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Restriction of Cross-Examination of Testifying Co-Conspirators
Hunsucker contends the trial court committed reversible error in restricting cross-examination of Faison and Hayes regarding the length and nature of the sentences avoided by them through cooperation with the State.Â  We disagree. 
The confrontation clause guarantees a defendant the opportunity to cross-examine a witness concerning bias.Â 
State v. Mizzell, 349 S.C. 326, 331, 563 S.E.2d 315, 317 (2002).Â  â€œConsiderable latitude is allowed in the cross examination of an adverse witness to show bias.â€Â  State v. McFarlane, 279 S.C. 327, 330, 306 S.E.2d 611, 613 (1983).Â  
â€œThe Confrontation Clause does not, however, prevent a trial judge from imposing any limits on defense counselâ€™s inquiry into the potential bias of a prosecution witness.Â  On the contrary, trial judges retain wide latitude insofar as the Confrontation Clause is concerned to impose reasonable limits on such cross-examination . . . .â€Â 
State v. Graham, 314 S.C. 383, 385, 444 S.E.2d 525, 527 (1994).Â  Still, before cross-examination may be limited, the record must clearly show that the cross-examination is somehow inappropriate. Â Id. at 385-86, 444 S.E.2d at 527.Â  â€œThe limitation of cross-examination is reversible error if the defendant establishes he was unfairly prejudiced.â€Â 
State v. Brown, 303 S.C. 169, 171, 399 S.E.2d 593, 594 (1991).Â  
A.Â  Cross-Examination of Matthew Faison
On direct examination, Faison admitted pleading guilty to the armed robbery of Haswell and three separate counts of strong armed robbery.Â  In addition, Faison admitted pleading guilty to various other charges including forgery, financial transaction card fraud, and aggravated assault and battery.Â  Faison testified the State recommended all sentences on the aforementioned charges run concurrent, including a twelve year no parole sentence for armed robbery, in exchange for Faisonâ€™s cooperation with the State in the prosecution of Hunsucker.Â  
On cross-examination, Hunsucker attempted to question Faison regarding the length and nature of the possible sentences he avoided through cooperation with the State.Â  During a proffer, Faison admitted that he faced a potential sentence of ninety-five years if fully prosecuted and convicted of the crimes charged against him.Â  The trial court held Hunsucker could not elicit testimony regarding the possible length of the sentences associated with the various crimes charged against Faison because such information would suggest the potential sentence Hunsucker might face if found guilty.Â  
Generally, the jury is not entitled to learn the possible sentence of a defendant because the sentence is irrelevant to the finding of guilt or innocence.Â  Mizzell, 349 S.C. at 331, 563 S.E.2d at 318.Â  â€œâ€˜The purpose of preventing disclosure of the potential sentence facing the defendant is that such evidence is irrelevant to the jury and could possibly prejudice the Stateâ€™s right to a fair trial.â€™â€ Â State v. Gillian, 360 S.C. 433, 453, 602 S.E.2d 62, 73 (Ct. App. 2004) (citation omitted).Â  â€œHowever, other constitutional concerns, such as the Confrontation Clause, limit the applicability of this rule in circumstances where the defendantâ€™s right to effectively cross-examine a co-conspirator witness of possible bias outweighs the need to exclude the evidence.â€Â  Mizzell, 349 S.C. at 331-32, 563 S.E.2d at 318.Â  
We find the trial court erred in prohibiting Hunsucker from cross-examining Faison regarding the possible punishments avoided through cooperation with the State.Â  In State v. Brown, the supreme court held the trial court erred in not allowing the defendant to cross-examine a key witness who was â€œpermitted to avoid a mandatory prison term of more than three times the duration she would face on her plea . . . .â€Â  303 S.C. at 171, 399 S.E.2d at 594.Â  The court held the witnessâ€™s avoidance of such a punishment was â€œcritical evidence of potential biasâ€ that should be presented to the jury.Â  Id.Â  Similarly, Faisonâ€™s cooperation with the State helped him secure a recommendation of twelve years imprisonment and avoid a possible punishment of more than ninety years.Â  Thus, as in Brown, the trial courtâ€™s denial of meaningful cross-examination of Faison, a key witness, outweighs the Stateâ€™s interest in excluding the evidence because the potential punishment avoided by Faison far exceeded the sentence received.Â  
Nevertheless, a violation of the confrontation clause is subject to a harmless error analysis.Â  State v. Clark, 315 S.C. 478, 481, 445 S.E.2d 633, 634 (1994).Â  â€œWhether an error is harmless depends on the circumstances of the particular case. Â No definite rule of law governs this finding; rather, the materiality and prejudicial character of the error must be determined from its relationship to the entire case.â€Â  State v. Mitchell, 286 S.C. 572, 573, 336 S.E.2d 150, 151 (1985).Â  
We do not believe the error could have reasonably affected the result of the trial.Â  During cross-examination, Hunsucker asked Faison, â€œ[W]hat will happen if you donâ€™t testify for the government here today?â€Â  Faison replied, without objection from the State, â€œI get 30 years added on to my time.â€Â  Thus, Hunsucker established that Faison received a substantially reduced sentence in exchange for his testimony, thereby demonstrating Faisonâ€™s bias and motive.Â  We thus find no reversible error. 
B.Â  Cross-Examination of John Hayes
Hunsuckerâ€™s argument regarding the limitation of cross-examination of Hayes regarding his bias is not preserved.Â  Hunsucker argued that allowing the solicitor to question Hayes about specifics in his statement, when Hayes refused to testify, constituted hearsay and violated Hunsuckerâ€™s due process and confrontation rights. Â However, Hunsucker never attempted to cross-examine Hayes as to his bias.Â  Accordingly, the issue on appeal is not preserved for appellate review.Â  State v. Hudgins, 319 S.C. 233, 237, 460 S.E.2d 388, 390-91 (1995) (finding issue not preserved where not argued at trial).
II.Â  Trial Courtâ€™s Participation in the Examination of a Witness
Hunsucker next argues the trial court committed reversible error in participating in the examination of a witness and improperly commenting on the facts of the case.Â  We disagree.Â  
As part of the Stateâ€™s case, the State presented testimony from Darren Yarborough, a criminal investigator for the Florence County Sheriffâ€™s Department.Â  Yarborough testified about taking the statements of both Faison and Hayes and about searching Hunsuckerâ€™s house.Â  During direct examination of Yarborough, the trial court interrupted and asked Yarborough, â€œ[I]n your interrogation of [Faison and Hayes], that (sic) each of them independently separately incriminate Mr. Hunsucker[?]â€Â  Yarborough responded, â€œYes, sir.â€Â  Hunsucker objected to the trial courtâ€™s question.Â  The trial court granted Hunsuckerâ€™s objection.Â  The trial court then instructed, â€œIgnore the question and the answer, ladies and gentlemen.Â  [At] [s]ome point that question may or may not become relevant.â€Â  Hunsucker made no further objections or motions regarding the trial courtâ€™s question or instruction.Â  
This issue is not preserved for our review.Â  â€œ[P]rejudicial remarks in the course of a trial made by the court must be seasonably objected to and an exception noted, in the absence of which the question will not be ordinarily reviewed on appeal.â€Â 
Lipscomb v. Poole, 247 S.C. 425, 433-34, 147 S.E.2d 692, 697 (1966).Â  â€œ[I]f the objecting party accepts the ruling of the trial judge and does not contemporaneously object to the sufficiency of a curative instruction or move for mistrial, the error is deemed cured, and the issue is not preserved for appeal.â€Â  State v. Moyd, 321 S.C. 256, 263, 468 S.E.2d 7, 11 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  â€œThe fact that counsel may have some hesitancy in making objection during the trial to remarks or conduct of the court, which are considered prejudicial, does not excuse the failure to do so.â€ Â Parks v. Morris Homes Corp., 245 S.C. 461, 470, 141 S.E.2d 129, 134 (1965).Â  
CONCLUSION
We find no reversible error in limiting the cross-examination of Faison.Â  Hunsucker failed to preserve the issues of cross-examination of Hayes regarding bias and whether the trial court erred in directly questioning a witness.Â  The decision of the trial court is accordingly 
AFFIRMED.
 HUFF, STILWELL, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

title: Southern Sales and Marketing Group v. AMCO Construction Co.
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Southern Sales and Marketing Group, Inc. d/b/a Southern Patio,
Appellant,
v.
AMCO Construction Co., Inc., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Orangeburg County
Â James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-278
Submitted June 1, 2006 â€“ Filed June 13, 2006

APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
Richard B. Ness, Daniel W. Luginbill, of Bamberg; for Appellant.
John Whitfield Davidson, of Columbia; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Southern Sales and Marketing Group, Inc., d/b/a Southern Patio (â€œSouthern Patioâ€) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order denying its motion to amend its Complaint.Â  In the motion, Southern Patio sought to add the president of AMCO Construction Company, Inc. (â€œAMCOâ€) as an individual defendant.Â  Because we find the circuit courtâ€™s order is interlocutory and not immediately appealable, we dismiss the appeal. [1]
FACTS
In October 2003, AMCO submitted a bid, which Southern Patio accepted, for the preparation and removal of five transformers from the second floor mezzanine level of a former textile plant that was recently purchased by Southern Patio.Â  During discussions surrounding the project, the parties agreed the oil contained within the transformers needed to Â be pumped out and transported separately in fifty-five gallon drums. 
After the job was awarded, AMCO obtained a Material Safety Data Sheet to determine what type of oil or other substance the transformers contained.Â  A review of this data sheet revealed that the oil contained â€œpolychlorinated biphenyls,â€ or PCBs.Â  As a result, AMCO employees wore protective suits, gloves, eye protection, and respirators during the removal process.Â  During this process, AMCO employees spilled oil on the floor in an area surrounding the transformers.Â  A crane operator, hired to remove the barrels and transformers from the loading dock to the transportation truck, noticed the oil spill and alerted AMCO employees, including James Evans, the president of AMCO.Â  As a result of the oil spill, the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) was contacted to assess the situation.Â  After its inspection, the EPA imposed fines against Southern Patio and required decontamination of all affected areas.Â  Southern Patio contracted with a third-party company to complete the clean-up process.
On April 13, 2004, Southern Patio filed a Complaint against AMCO in which it asserted causes of action for negligence, breach of contract, and equitable indemnity.Â  In its Answer, AMCO generally denied the allegations and counterclaimed for payment of work performed.
During discovery, Southern Patio deposed Evans and Neil Noland, an employee of the clean-up company.Â  Based on these depositions, Southern Patio filed a motion on August 29, 2005, pursuant to Rule 15(a), SCRCP, in which it sought to amend its Complaint to add Evans as an individual defendant. Â In its motion, Southern Patio contended that Evans had â€œtaken several steps individually for which he should be personally liable, in addition to AMCO Constructionâ€™s vicarious liability for the acts of its employees.â€ Â Specifically, Southern Patio claimed Evans did not review the Material Safety Data Sheet â€œuntil after the job was awarded and just hours prior to beginning the process of pumping out the PCB oil.â€Â  Additionally, Southern Patio asserted that Evans made the decision to remove the oil from the transformers, a decision Noland opined was outside the accepted practice in the industry.Â  
AMCO opposed the motion, arguing any action taken by Evans regarding the project was solely â€œin his [corporate] capacity as the president and an employee of AMCO Construction.â€Â  AMCO also expressed its belief that Southern Patio was only attempting to add Evans as a defendant â€œbecause they are concerned about AMCOâ€™s ability to pay a judgment, if one is obtained.â€Â  AMCO contended that the proper procedure would be for Southern Patio to institute an action to pierce the corporate veil if it obtained a judgment.
The circuit court held a hearing on Southern Patioâ€™s motion.Â  By order dated October 20, 2005, the court denied the motion.Â  In ruling on the motion, the court found Southern Patio failed to allege that â€œthe actions of Mr. Evans were undertaken in his personal capacity.â€ The court further found there were no actions complained of that would â€œsuggest any personal duty of Mr. Evans which he owed to the Plaintiff.â€Â  The court also stated, â€œthe torts alleged in the Complaint relate to the spilling of transformer oil and there is no allegation that Mr. Evans personally spilled the oil or directed or sanctioned the spilling of the oil.Â  As such, there is no ground for adding Mr. Evans as a party to this case.â€Â  Finally, the court held AMCO and Evans would be prejudiced by the late amendment given the case was on the roster for the term of court beginning on October 31, 2005.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  This appeal followed.
DISCUSSION
I.
As a threshold issue, Southern Patio argues the circuit courtâ€™s order denying its motion to amend is immediately appealable because â€œit made a determination of the merits of the case and affected a substantial right.â€Â  We disagree.[2]  
â€œThe right of appeal arises from and is controlled by statutory law.Â  An appeal ordinarily may be pursued only after a party has obtained a final judgment.â€Â  Hagood v. Sommerville, 362 S.C. 191, 194, 607 S.E.2d 707, 708 (2005) (citations omitted). Â â€œAn order which does not finally end a case or prevent a final judgment from which a party may seek appellate review usually is considered an interlocutory order from which no immediate appeal is allowed.â€Â 
Id. at 195, 607 S.E.2d at 709.
â€œAbsent some specialized statute, the immediate appealability of an interlocutory or intermediate order depends on whether the order falls within S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-3-330.â€Â  Edwards v. Suncom, Op. No. 26148 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed May 15, 2006) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 19 at 21, 22).Â  This section provides:

(1) Any intermediate judgment, order or decree in a law case involving the merits in actions commenced in the court of common pleas and general sessions, brought there by original process or removed there from any inferior court or jurisdiction, and final judgments in such actions; provided, that if no appeal be taken until final judgment is entered the court may upon appeal from such final judgment review any intermediate order or decree necessarily affecting the judgment not before appealed from;
(2) An order affecting a substantial right made in an action when such order (a) in effect determines the action and prevents a judgment from which an
appeal might be taken or discontinues the action, (b) grants or refuses a new trial or (c) strikes out an answer or any part thereof or any pleading in any action;
(3) A final order affecting a substantial right made in any special proceeding or upon a summary application in any action after judgment; and
(4) An interlocutory order or decree in a court of common pleas granting, continuing, modifying, or refusing an injunction or granting, continuing, modifying, or refusing the appointment of a receiver.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-3-330 (1977 & Supp. 2005) (emphasis added).Â  
In the instant case, Southern Patio contends the circuit courtâ€™s order effectively determined the merits of its cause of action against Evans and affected a substantial right.Â  Thus, we confine our analysis to sections 14-3-330(1) and (2)(a).
In terms of these specific sections, our supreme court has explained what constitutes an intermediate order involving the merits and affecting a substantial right as follows:

An order which involves the merits is one that â€œmust finally determine some substantial matter forming the whole or a part of some cause of action or defense.â€Â  Mid-State Distribs., Inc., 310 S.C. at 334, 426 S.E.2d at 780.Â  Interlocutory orders affecting a substantial right may be immediately appealed pursuant to Â§ 14-3-330(2). Â Orders affecting a substantial right â€œdiscontinue an action, prevent an appeal, grant or refuse a new trial, or strike out an action or defense.â€ Id. at 335 n.4, 426 S.E.2d at 780 n.4. 

Ex Parte Wilson, 367 S.C. 7, 13, 625 S.E.2d 205, 208 (2005).
In analyzing this case, we find guidance from the above-outlined principles as well as our supreme courtâ€™s decision in Baldwin Construction Company, Inc. v. Graham, 357 S.C. 227, 593 S.E.2d 146 (2004).Â  In Baldwin, the construction company filed suit against the Grahams for foreclosure of a mechanicâ€™s lien as well as related causes of action.Â  The Grahams sent a letter to the construction company in which they responded to the allegations.Â  After retaining counsel, the Grahams moved for permission to file an amended Answer with set-offs and counterclaims.Â  In conjunction with this motion, the Grahamsâ€™ counsel also requested a jury trial.Â  The circuit court denied the motions on the ground the relief requested would be â€œunduly prejudicial.â€Â  Id. at 229, 593 S.E.2d at 147.Â  Our supreme court dismissed the appeal on the ground that it was interlocutory and not immediately appealable.Â  Id. at 230, 593 S.E.2d at 147.Â  In reaching this conclusion, the supreme court found the circuit court â€œdid not rule on the substantive contents of the answer, nor did the order strike a pleading.â€Â  Id.Â  Instead, our supreme court found the circuit court merely refused to allow the Grahams to file the answer.Â  In light of this procedure, our supreme court concluded the denial of the Grahamsâ€™ motion to amend their Answer was not immediately appealable because the Grahams would still be able to appeal the decision at the conclusion of the trial.Â  Id. at 230, 593 S.E.2d at 147-48.Â  
Although we recognize the facts of the instant case are slightly different from those in Graham, we nevertheless find the decision instructive.Â  We believe the two cases differ in that the circuit court in this case appeared to rule on the â€œsubstantive contentsâ€ of the amended complaint whereas the circuit court in Graham only refused to allow the filing of the amended Answer.Â  This distinction does not dissuade us from relying on the analysis in Graham.Â  In the present case, the circuit court may have gone a step further than the court in Graham in that it discussed the allegations against Evans.Â  However, the ultimate result in the two cases was the same, i.e., the courtâ€™s decision, like the court in Graham, refused Southern Patioâ€™s request to file an amended pleading.Â  Thus, the order neither finally determined a â€œsubstantial matter forming the whole or part of a some cause of action or defenseâ€ nor â€œdiscontinue[d] an action, prevent[ed] an appeal . . . or [struck] out an action or defense.â€ Â Ex parte Wilson, 367 S.C. at 13, 625 S.E.2d at 208. Â Accordingly, we conclude the circuit courtâ€™s order is not immediately appealable.Â  See Tatnall v. Gardner, 350 S.C. 135, 138, 564 S.E.2d 377, 379 (Ct. App. 2002) (holding trial courtâ€™s order denying defendantâ€™s motion to amend her answer to assert third-party claims was not immediately appealable because order â€œneither determine[d] a substantial matter â€˜forming the whole or part of some cause of action,â€™ nor prevents â€˜a judgment from being rendered in the actionâ€™ from which [defendant] could then seek reviewâ€); cf. Collins v. Sigmon, 299 S.C. 464, 466, 385 S.E.2d 835, 836 (1989) (â€œAn order permitting amendment of pleadings is interlocutory and generally is not appealable until final judgment.â€). 
II.
Although we decline to rule on Southern Patioâ€™s remaining issues, we deem it necessary to address Southern Patioâ€™s legitimate concern that it will be barred in the future from alleging any individual action against Evans in light of the circuit courtâ€™s rulings. Â 
Based on our review of the order, we find the circuit court did not make a final determination regarding the merits of the action alleged against Evans in his individual capacity.Â  Instead, we believe the language used by the court indicated that it focused exclusively on the allegations in Southern Patioâ€™s Complaint and did not delve into the merits.Â  In addition to the specific language in the order, we also find significant that the court made its decision based on a scant record and did not have before it any conclusive evidence regarding Evansâ€™s individual capacity.[3]Â  Furthermore, the court did not deny the motion solely on the allegations against Evans but also found the late amendment would be prejudicial to AMCO.Â  Therefore, we find Southern Patio is not precluded from alleging, at the procedurally appropriate time, a cause of action against Evans in his individual capacity.Â  See Collins, 299 S.C. at 466, 385 S.E.2d at 836 (â€œA motion to amend an Answer should be contested primarily by procedural arguments, not arguments concerning the substance and merits of the counterclaims and/or defenses proposed . . . It follows that the trial judge should generally not consider these substantive arguments at the mere amendment stage.â€); Pruitt v. Bowers, 330 S.C. 483, 488, 499 S.E.2d 250, 253 (Ct. App. 1998)(declining to rule on interlocutory order where trial court had not had an opportunity to rule on the sufficiency of the allegations in the pleadings and stating â€œ[a]rguments going to the legal merits of the proposed pleadings are better taken up in the context of a Rule12(b) motion to dismiss or a Rule 56, SCRCP, motion for summary judgmentâ€).
Based on the foregoing, Southern Patioâ€™s appeal is dismissed without prejudice.
 APPEAL DISMISSED.Â Â  
HUFF, STILWELL, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.Â  

[1]Â Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â Â  Southern Patio raises two other issues on appeal.Â  Because we believe the first issue is dispositive, we address only that issue.Â  
[3]Â Â  Southern Patio appears to recognize the limited record given it informed this court that several depositions were not submitted to the circuit court based on the procedural posture of its motion to amend pursuant to Rule 15, SCRCP.Â
