title: Williamson v. Bermuda Run Investor Development Group, Inc.
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Anna Belle Williamson, Appellant,
        v.
        Bermuda Run Investor Development Group, Inc.; Bermuda Run Horizontal Property Regime, now or formerly; Richard S. Clayton, Treasurer of the Board of Directors of Bermuda Run Horizontal Property Regime, now or formerly; Darrel C. Myers, President of the Board of Directors for Bermuda Run Investor Development Group, Inc., now or formerly; Alfred H. Agnew, Secretary/Treasurer of the Board of Directors for Bermuda Run Investor Development Group, Inc., now or formerly;
        O.D. Murray, Jr., Richard S. Clayton, Darrell C. Myers, and Alfred H. Agnew, individually,
        Defendants, 
        of whom Bermuda Run Investor Development Group, Inc. and Bermuda Run Horizontal Property Regime are,
        Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â J. Stanton Cross, Jr., Master in Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-279
Heard May 9, 2006 â€“ Filed June 13, 2006Â Â 

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
Irby E. Walker, Jr., of Conway, and George Thomas Samaha, III, of Little River, for Appellant.
Michael S. Hopewell and C. Pierce Campbell, of Florence, for Respondent Bermuda Run Horizontal Property Regime; and Reynolds Williams, of Florence, for Respondents Bermuda Run Investor Development Group, Inc. and Bermuda Run Horizontal Property Regime.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Anna Belle Williamson, the owner of a condominium at Bermuda Run, brought this action alleging her homeownersâ€™ association, Bermuda Run Horizontal Property Regime (â€œBermuda Runâ€), entered into an unauthorized transaction to transfer a common element to the Bermuda Run Investor Development Group (â€œBRIDGâ€).Â  Bermuda Run and BRIDG (collectively, â€œRespondentsâ€) brought counterclaims against Williamson for, among other things, slander of title and tortious interference with economic relations.Â  The master in equity ruled in favor of Respondents on all claims.Â  Williamson appeals.Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part.
FACTS
Bermuda Run is a condominium complex in Horry County consisting of common elements and forty-four separate units.Â  Williamson is the owner of a condominium at Bermuda Run.Â  She purchased her unit in August 1985.Â  
At an annual meeting on May 16, 1998, the board of directors of Bermuda Run adopted a resolution authorizing Bermuda Run to execute the necessary documents to trade its existing driveway to BRIDG, a South Carolina corporation, in exchange for Bermuda Run receiving title to two tracts of property owned by BRIDG that were contiguous to Bermuda Run and obtaining a non-exclusive easement for purposes of ingress and egress.Â  The resolution stated BRIDG and Bermuda Run also agreed that each would have the use of the otherâ€™s amenities, such as parking areas and other common elements.Â  Of the four directors of Bermuda Run, only one member, O.D. Murray, voted in favor of the resolution.Â  The remaining three members, Alfred Agnew, Richard Clayton, and Larry Maust, abstained from voting.[1]Â Â Â  
On June 3, 1999, Bermuda Run recorded a deed transferring title to BRIDG for the driveway leading into Bermuda Run.Â  Thereafter, on December 30, 1999, Williamson filed a lis pendens and a complaint seeking damages against Bermuda Run, BRIDG, and members and officers of each for allegedly conveying a common element, i.e., the driveway, without the approval of all the Bermuda Run homeowners.Â  
On June 5, 2000, Williamson filed an amended complaint that included three causes of action:Â  (1) negligence as to Bermuda Run board members Murray and Clayton, (2) fraudulent conveyance as to all defendants, and (3) ultra vires acts as to Bermuda Run and to Murray and Clayton, individually and as members of the Bermuda Run board of directors.Â  BRIDG, Agnew, and Myers asserted counterclaims for slander of title and tortious interference with economic relations.Â  Bermuda Run asserted counterclaims for slander of title, tortious interference with economic relations, and abuse of process.Â Â Â  
The defendants filed motions to dismiss Williamsonâ€™s claims.Â  By order dated January 19, 2001, the circuit court, Judge J. Michael Baxley presiding, dismissed the fraudulent conveyance claim as to all defendants, but allowed Williamsonâ€™s claims based on negligence and ultra vires acts to survive.Â  Judge Baxley apparently vacated the lis pendens on the property by order on February 5, 2001.[2]Â  
By order filed June 11, 2001, Judge B. Hicks Harwell of the circuit court ordered Williamson to pay BRIDG, Myers (President of BRIDG), and Agnew (Secretary/Treasurer of BRIDG) attorney fees, costs, and expenses in the amount of $25,000.Â  Judge Harwell granted the fees â€œpursuant to the South Carolina Frivolous Proceedings Sanctions Act and Rule 11 SCRCP.â€Â  He further stated he was granting â€œBRIDGâ€™s Motion for Partial Summary Judgment upon liability and for an entitlement to attorney[] fees under its slander of title counterclaim.â€Â  Judge Harwell referred to a master in equity the other issues raised in the motion submitted by BRIDG, Agnew, and Myers, including:Â  (1) whether BRIDG was entitled to partial summary judgment as to liability on its counterclaim for tortious interference with economic relations and (2) whether BRIDG suffered additional damage above its attorney fees for slander of title and, if so, the extent thereof.Â  
Williamson immediately appealed only the award of attorney fees.Â  We affirmed on the ground that the issue she raised regarding the fees was not preserved because it was not argued at trial.Â  See Williamson v. Bermuda Run, 2002-UP-594 (S.C. Ct. App. filed Sept. 26, 2002).Â Â Â  
Williamson, through her attorney, abandoned her negligence claim at the beginning of the proceeding before Master in Equity J. Stanton Cross, Jr. in December 2004.Â  The master noted that Williamson was proceeding solely on her ultra vires claim and the only other issues before the court were the counterclaims of Respondents.Â  
At the conclusion of the hearing, the master found Williamson had not established her claim regarding ultra vires acts and had not proved damages.Â  As to BRIDGâ€™s counterclaims, the master applied the law of the case doctrine and found Judge Harwellâ€™s order precluded Williamsonâ€™s defense of the slander of title counterclaim.Â  The master further found BRIDG had proved each element its counterclaim for tortious interference with economic relations, but â€œsuch finding [was] not necessary to [his] decision because the damage[s] arising from the tortious interference with BRIDGâ€™s economic relations are identical to the damages [caused] by [Williamsonâ€™s] slander of BRIDGâ€™s title.â€Â  The master awarded BRIDG a judgment of $70,185.24 for the slander of title and tortious interference claims, plus $17,500 in attorney fees and costs.Â  
As to Bermuda Runâ€™s counterclaims for slander of title, tortious interference, and abuse of process, the master granted Bermuda Run a judgment of $445,000.Â  In finding for Bermuda Run, the master did not specify which cause of action he was basing the award on, but stated, â€œI found the testimony of Dr. Kenneth Eugene Lehrer to have been well-considered, authoritative, probative, and convincing.Â  Bermuda Run was damaged by the Plaintiff and those damages equal $445,000.â€[3]Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Under the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure, summary judgment is appropriate only if â€œthe pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; see also Standard Fire Ins. Co. v. Marine Contracting & Towing Co., 301 S.C. 418, 421, 392 S.E.2d 460, 462 (1990).
When reviewing the grant of a motion for summary judgment, an appellate court applies the same standard applied by the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 567 S.E.2d 857 (2002); Ferguson v. Charleston Lincoln Mercury, Inc., 349 S.C. 558, 564 S.E.2d 94 (2002); see also Baird v. Charleston County, 333 S.C. 519, 529, 511 S.E.2d 69, 74 (1999) (â€œSummary judgment is appropriate when it is clear that there is no genuine issue of material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€).Â  
â€œIn determining whether any triable issue of fact exists, the evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably drawn therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.â€Â  Summer v. Carpenter, 328 S.C. 36, 42, 492 S.E.2d 55, 58 (1997).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Ultra Vires Acts
Williamson contends the master erred in finding her allegation of ultra vires acts was not properly brought as a derivative action as required by section 33-31-304 of the South Carolina Code.Â  We disagree.
Bermuda Run was formed as a South Carolina nonprofit corporation.[4]Â  Article II of its Articles of Incorporation clearly states â€œthe Corporation shall be conducted as a non-profit organization for the benefit of its members.â€Â  Article III of the Articles of Incorporation goes on to state â€œ[t]he Corporation shall have all of the powers and privileges granted to corporations not for profit under the law pursuant to which this Corporation is chartered.â€Â  
Section 33-31-304 of the South Carolina Nonprofit Corporation Act specifically governs ultra vires actions.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-31-304 (2006).Â  It generally provides that a nonprofit corporationâ€™s power to act may not be challenged as ultra vires unless brought in a specific manner as follows:

(a) Except as provided in subsection (b), the validity of corporate action may not be challenged on the ground that the corporation lacks or lacked power to act. 
(b) A corporationâ€™s power to act may be challenged in a proceeding against the corporation to enjoin an act where a third party has not acquired rights.Â  The proceeding may be brought by the Attorney General, a director, or by a member or members in a derivative proceeding. 
(c)Â  A corporationâ€™s power to act may be challenged in a proceeding against an incumbent or former director, officer, employee, or agent of the corporation.Â  The proceeding may be brought by a director, the corporation, directly, derivatively, or through a receiver, a trustee, or other legal representative, or in the case of a public benefit corporation, by the Attorney General. 

Although subsection (b) states the â€œproceeding may be brought by the Attorney General, a director, or by a member or members in a derivative proceeding,â€ the way in which Williamson brought this action does not satisfy any of these options.Â  It is clear neither the Attorney General nor a director brought the action; therefore, as noted by the master, the only available alternative was for a member or members to bring the action in a derivative proceeding.Â  Williamson failed, however, to comply with the requirements for bringing a derivative action.Â  
Rule 23 of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure outlines the requirements for bringing a derivative action as follows:

(b)(1) Derivative Actions by Shareholders. In a derivative action brought by one or more shareholders or members to enforce a right of a corporation or of an unincorporated association, the corporation or association having failed to enforce a right which may properly be asserted by it, the complaint shall be verified and shall allege that the plaintiff was a shareholder or member at the time of the transaction of which he complains or that his share or membership thereafter devolved on him by operation of law. Â The complaint shall also allege with particularity the efforts, if any, made by the plaintiff to obtain the action he desires from the directors or comparable authority and, if necessary, from the shareholders or members, and the reasons for his failure to obtain the action or for not making the effort. Â The derivative action may not be maintained if it appears that the plaintiff does not fairly and adequately represent the interests of the shareholders or members similarly situated in enforcing the right of the corporation or association. The action shall not be dismissed or compromised without the approval of the court and notice of the proposed dismissal or compromise shall be given to shareholders or members in such manner as the court directs.

Rule 23, SCRCP.
A derivative action that does not meet the pleading requirements of Rule 23(b)(1), SCRCP, is properly dismissed pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP.Â  See generally Carolina First Corp. v. Whittle, 343 S.C. 176, 539 S.E.2d 402 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Williamson did not plead the necessary information in her complaint to bring a derivative action.Â  A reading of Williamsonâ€™s complaint and her testimony at trial shows that she did not bring the action on behalf of the corporation, a group of shareholders, or anyone other than herself.Â  When specifically asked for whom the lawsuit speaks, Williamson answered she did not speak for any of the other Bermuda Run homeowners.Â  Williamson did not allege in her complaint that it is a derivative action, and she asked for personal damages in excess of $1.5 million dollars.Â  She also did not allege in the complaint that a demand was made on the board as required by Rule 23, SCRCP.Â  Williamson failed to properly plead her derivative claims.Â  Consequently, she failed to state a claim for ultra vires acts and the master did not err by denying relief on this basis. 
II.Â  Slander of Title 
Williamson next contends the master erred in ruling slander of title was the â€œlaw of the caseâ€ as to BRIDG and in finding for both BRIDG and Bermuda Run on their counterclaims for slander of title.
A.Â  Law of the Case
In considering BRIDGâ€™s counterclaim for slander of title, the master stated BRIDG â€œhas been granted judgment on its counterclaim for slander of titleâ€ based on Judge Harwellâ€™s order of June 11, 2001 and â€œ[t]hat is the law of this case.â€Â  Williamson contends this was error as Judge Harwellâ€™s ruling on this point was not the â€œlaw of the case.â€Â  
â€œThat a decree from which no appeal is taken becomes the law of the case in all subsequent proceedings involving the same parties and the same subject matter is the well-settled law in this state . . . .â€Â  Matheson v. McCormac, 187 S.C. 260, 263, 196 S.E. 883, 884 (1938).Â  â€œLaw of the case,â€ as a term of art, technically was not the correct term to be used here, as the masterâ€™s comments could be taken to indicate Judge Harwellâ€™s order could no longer be appealed.Â  In Link v. School District of Pickens County, 302 S.C. 1, 6, 393 S.E.2d 176, 179 (1990), however, our supreme court held that when a trial court declares summary judgment on one of several issues in a case, a party can wait to appeal from the final judgment disposing of all issues.Â  Accordingly, an appeal of the issue of slander of title as it pertains to BRIDG is timely.Â  
What the master probably intended to convey is that he was not at liberty to reconsider Judge Harwellâ€™s 2001 ruling as to summary judgment because his mandate as to BRIDG was to consider damages only.[5]Â  See, e.g., Binkley v. Burry, 352 S.C. 286, 295, 573 S.E.2d 838, 843 (Ct. App. 2002) (â€œGenerally, one circuit court judge may not reverse or modify the order of another circuit court judge.â€).Â  Any challenge to the grant of summary judgment to BRIDG was properly to be made via an appeal.Â  We note, however, that to the extent Judge Harwellâ€™s order awarded $25,000 in attorney fees to BRIDG, the ruling is final because that issue was immediately appealed by Williamson in a prior proceeding and we affirmed the award solely on error preservation grounds.Â Â Â  
B.Â  Merits
The case of Pond Place Partners, Inc. v. Poole, 351 S.C. 1, 18-19, 567 S.E.2d 881, 890 (Ct. App. 2002) defines slander of title as follows:

â€œThe term â€˜slander of titleâ€™ is defined as a false and malicious statement, oral or written, made in disparagement of a personâ€™s
title to real or personal property, causing him injury.â€ Â 50 Am.Jur.2d Libel & Slander Â§ 548 (1995). Â Generally, an action under slander of title may only be maintained by one who possesses an estate or interest in the affected property. Â See generally Jeffrey F. Ghent, Slander of Title: Sufficiency of Plaintiffâ€™s Interest in Real Property to Maintain Action, 86 A.L.R.4th 738 (1991). Â â€œThe tort of slander of title is almost identical to the tort of product disparagement, the only difference being that the former tort involves aspersing the quality of oneâ€™s title to property and the latter tort involves aspersing the quality of oneâ€™s property.â€Â  Wendyâ€™s of South Jersey, Inc. v. Blanchard Mgmt. Corp. of N.J., 170 N.J.Super. 491, 406 A.2d 1337, 1338 (Ch.Div.1979).

In Huff v. Jennings, 319 S.C. 142, 459 S.E.2d 886 (Ct. App. 1995), we set forth for the first time in South Carolina a six-point test that a plaintiff must satisfy to maintain an action for slander of title:Â  

(1) the publication (2) with malice (3) of a false statement (4) that is derogatory to plaintiffâ€™s title and (5) causes special damages (6) as a result of diminished value of the property in the eyes of third parties. Â 

Id. at 149, 459 S.E.2d at 891. 
Though the master found Williamson was liable for slander of title, this was predicated on his determination that Bermuda Run was authorized to enter into the transaction to convey a common element and thus had not committed an ultra vires act.Â  Williamson purportedly committed slander of title by alleging the transaction was unauthorized.Â Â  
â€œ[A] corporation may exercise only those powers which are granted to it by law, by its charter or articles of incorporation,
and by any bylaws made pursuant thereto; acts beyond the scope of the powers so granted are ultra vires.â€Â  Seabrook Island Property Owners Assâ€™n v. Pelzer, 292 S.C. 343, 347, 356 S.E.2d 411, 414 (Ct. App. 1987).
The master found Respondents did not act beyond the powers granted to them by law and the governing documents of Bermuda Run because the sale of property was an authorized transaction.Â  In so doing, the master relied upon section 33-3-102 of the South Carolina Code, which states in pertinent part:Â  â€œUnless its Articles of Incorporation provide otherwise, every corporation . . . has the same powers as an individual to do all things necessary or convenient to carry out its business and affairs, including without limitation the power to . . . sell, convey, mortgage, pledge, lease, exchange, and otherwise dispose of all or any part of is property . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-3-102 (2006).Â  The master also relied upon the Articles of Incorporation, finding Article 3 expressly allowed Bermuda Run to have all the powers and privileges granted to non-profit corporations.Â  Â Â 
Although these provisions generally authorize Bermuda Run to buy, sell, or transfer its land, these provisions do not expressly authorize Bermuda Run to sell property that it does not own.Â  Both the express language of the Master Deed and the South Carolina Horizontal Property Act, in fact, appear to preclude the actions taken by the board. 
Under the Master Deed, the property at issue is a common element owned solely by the condominium owners.Â  Any transfer of that property requires the approval of all of the homeowners. Â 
Paragraph V of the Master Deed for Bermuda Run expressly states:Â  â€œThe percentage of undivided interest in the COMMON ELEMENTS assigned to each UNIT shall not be changed except with the unanimous consent of all the owners of all the units.â€Â Â Â  
Paragraph VI of the Master Deed prohibits the separate conveyance of the common elements:Â  â€œThe undivided interest in the COMMON ELEMENTS declared to be an appurtenance to each UNIT shall not be conveyed, devised, encumbered or otherwise dealt with separately from said UNIT . . . .â€Â  See also 4 S.C. Juris. Condominiums Â§ 18 (1991) (â€œCommon elements may neither be conveyed nor encumbered except as an appurtenance to an apartment. . . .Â  The apartment owners hold title to the regime common elements under a unique arrangement of concurrent ownership, which is neither a simple joint tenancy, since survivorship provisions are absent, nor a tenancy in common, since partition is prohibited.â€).Â Â Â  Â 
Paragraph X of the Master Deed further provides:Â  â€œRecognizing that the proper use of a UNIT by any owner or owners is dependent upon the use and enjoyment of the common elements . . . and that it is in the interest of all owners of UNITS that the ownership of the COMMON ELEMENTS be retained in common by the owners of UNITS in the CONDOMINIUM, it is declared that the percentage of the undivided interest in the COMMON ELEMENTS appurtenant to each UNIT shall remain undivided . . . .â€Â Â Â  Â 
Moreover, the South Carolina Horizontal Property Regime Act states the common elements shall not be divided.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 27-31-70 (1976) (â€œThe common elements, both general and limited, shall remain undivided and shall not be the object of an action for partition or division of the co-ownership.Â  Any covenant to the contrary shall be void.â€).Â  It is undisputed that the resolution adopted by Bermuda Run purported to transfer a portion of the common elements to BRIDG without the consent of the owners.Â  Neither the master nor Respondents cite to any authority expressly authorizing a homeownersâ€™ association to transfer title to the common elements without the consent of the owners.Â  
Based on the foregoing, we find the element which requires a false statement cannot be satisfied because Williamson never made false statements concerning the actions of Bermuda Run or BRIDG.Â  Bermuda Runâ€™s transaction was contrary to the provisions of the Master Deed and the Horizontal Property Act.Â  Thus, we hold the master erred in finding Williamson liable for slander of title and reverse that finding as to both BRIDG and Bermuda Run.
III. Tortious Interference with Economic Relations and Abuse of Process
Williamson also contends the master erred in finding her liable on Respondentsâ€™ counterclaims for tortious interference with economic relations and abuse of process.Â  We agree.
A.Â  Tortious Interference
Randy Drew entered into an option agreement to purchase property from BRIDG and purportedly signed a Joint Use Agreement with Bermuda Run in 1999.Â  Later that year, Drew terminated his option, stating he had only recently become aware that some of the residents objected to the transaction.Â  Drew was given copies of legal opinions obtained by BRIDG concluding there would be problems in enforcing the agreement in light of the failure to obtain the consent of all of the homeowners.Â  Drewâ€™s decision to not exercise his option to purchase was the basis for the counterclaims alleging tortious interference with economic relations.
As to BRIDGâ€™s claim, the master found â€œthat BRIDG has proven each element of this cause of actionâ€ because BRIDGâ€™s sale of its property to Drew for $595,000 â€œwas [] cancelled as a direct and proximate result of [Williamsonâ€™s] conduct.â€Â  The master found the sale probably would have closed on August 1, 2000, but BRIDG had mitigated its damages and sold the property on October 21, 2002 for a net price of $642,100.[6]Â  The master ultimately concluded BRIDG was entitled to statutory interest of 8.75% from August 1, 2000 to October 21, 2002 for the loss of the use of its $595,000, but this amount was mitigated by the more favorable sales price, for net damages of $70,185.24, plus attorney fees.Â  
In finding for Bermuda Run, the master did not specify which cause of action he was basing the award on, but summarily stated, â€œI found the testimony of Dr. Kenneth Eugene Lehrer to have been well-considered, authoritative, probative, and convincing.Â  Bermuda Run was damaged by the Plaintiff and those damages equal $445,000.â€[7] Â Â Â 
â€œThe elements of a cause of action for tortious interference with contract are: (1) existence of a valid contract; (2) the wrongdoerâ€™s knowledge thereof; (3) his intentional procurement of its breach; (4) the absence of justification; and (5) resulting damages.â€Â  Camp v. Springs Mortgage Corp., 310 S.C. 514, 517, 426 S.E.2d 304, 305 (1993).Â  Again, although the master found Williamson liable for tortious interference with economic relations, this conclusion was predicated on his finding that Bermuda Run had not committed an ultra vires act.Â  The first element of the claim for tortious interference with economic relations is missing here.Â  As has been demonstrated above, Bermuda Run did not have the ability to enter into the contract with BRIDG because both the Master Deed and the Horizontal Property Act prohibited it.Â  Furthermore, for reasons similar to those in deciding the issue of slander of title, the master erred in finding Williamson is liable for tortious interference with economic relations because Williamsonâ€™s assertion of an ultra vires act has merit and the requisite element of â€œabsence of justificationâ€ is not present.Â  Drewâ€™s business decision to terminate the transaction because of the uncertainty as to ownership does not support the claim alleged here for tortious interference.
B.Â  Abuse of Process
â€œThere are two essential elements required for an abuse of process action: Â (1) an ulterior purpose, and (2) a willful act in the use of the process not proper in the regular conduct of the proceedings.â€Â  Broadmoor Apartments of Charleston v. Horwitz, 306 S.C. 482, 486, 413 S.E.2d 9, 11 (1991).Â  Â â€œ[T]he issuance of the process may be justified in itself; it is the malicious misuse or perversion of the process for an end not lawfully warranted by it that constitutes the tort known as abuse of process.â€Â  Huggins v. Winn-Dixie Greenville, Inc., 249 S.C. 206, 209, 153 S.E.2d 693, 695 (1967).Â  â€œ â€˜[A]n abuse of process is the employment of legal process for some purpose other than that which it was intended by the law to effect--the improper use of a regularly issued process.â€™ â€Â  Id. at 210, 153 S.E.2d at 695 (citation omitted).
Some definite act or threat is required; there is no liability where the party has done nothing more than carry out the process to its authorized conclusion, even though with bad intentions.Â  Id. at 208, S.E.2d at 694.Â  The improper purpose usually takes the form of coercion; there is, in other words, a form of extortion, and it is what is done in the course of negotiation, rather than the issuance of the process itself, which constitutes the tort.Â  Id.Â  In the current appeal, Williamson could not be found liable for abuse of process when her actions were legitimate.Â  Though she pled her action incorrectly, the fact that she filed suit cannot support an abuse of process claim.
IV. Â Attorney Fees and Costs
Williamson lastly contends the master erred in awarding BRIDG $17,500 in attorney fees and costs.Â  We agree.
The master found BRIDG was entitled to a total award of attorney fees and costs in the amount of $17,500.Â  An award of attorney fees will be reversed when the substantive results achieved by counsel are reversed on appeal.Â  Camburn v. Smith, 355 S.C. 574, 581, 586 S.E.2d 565, 568 (2003); see also Sexton v. Sexton, 310 S.C. 501, 503, 427 S.E.2d 665, 666 (1993).Â  Accordingly, because we are reversing the award to BRIDG on its counterclaims, we likewise reverse the masterâ€™s award of $17,500 for attorney fees and costs.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we affirm the masterâ€™s decision to deny Williamsonâ€™s claim alleging an ultra vires act due to her failure to properly plead the claim as a derivative one.Â  We reverse the judgments in favor of Respondents on all counterclaims.Â  
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ., concur.

[1] Agnew was also an officer of BRIDG.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
[2]Â  This order is referred to, but not included, in the record on appeal.
[3]Â  Lehrer submitted an affidavit setting forth an â€œEconomy Summaryâ€ dated December 2, 2004, showing a total of $445,986 in damages.Â  It included line items for a loss on a purchase option and construction losses.Â  The largest component in the total was $240,700 for the net present value of future losses from 2003/04 to 2038/39.Â Â Â  
[4]Â  The record contains a master deed establishing The Bermuda Run Horizontal Property Regime in August 1985.Â  In addition, the record contains the Articles of Incorporation for the Bermuda Run Property Owners Association, Inc. creating a nonprofit corporation in August 1986.Â  The parties refer to these organizations interchangeably as â€œBermuda Runâ€ in their briefs.Â Â Â  
[5]Â  In her brief, Williamson also contends the master erred in finding his mandate was to determine whether BRIDG suffered any damages above and beyond its expenses and attorney fees from her slander of BRIDGâ€™s title.Â  The trial courtâ€™s June 11, 2001 order clearly mandated that one of the issues to be addressed by the master was â€œ[w]hether BRIDG has suffered additional damage, above and beyond its expenses and attorney[] fees, for the Plaintiffâ€™s slander of its title . . . .â€Â  
[6]Â  The master refers to both October 1, 2002 and October 21, 2002; the date of sale appears to be October 21, 2002.Â  The master further indicated his finding as to tortious interference was â€œnot necessary to [his] decision . . . because the damage arising from the tortious interference [action is] identical to the damages [from slander of title].â€Â Â Â  
[7]Â  In their briefs the parties seem to assume the master awarded damages to Bermuda Run based on all of the claims.Â  Since the parties read the order as being based on all three claims and we find, in any event, that all of the claims fail on their merits, we address them all here.

title: Ingram v. SC Probation, Parole & Pardon Services
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(D)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Willie Ray Ingram, Appellant,
v.
South Carolina Probation, Parole & Pardon Services,
Respondent
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â J. Ernest Kinard, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-280
Submitted June 1, 2006 â€“ Filed June 15, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Willie Ray Ingram, of McCormick, for Appellant.
J. Benjamin Aplin, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Willie Ray Ingram appeals the dismissal of his petition for writ of mandamus, arguing the circuit court should have ordered the South Carolina Department of Probation, Parole, and Pardon Services to provide him with all files considered by the parole board in determining his parole status.Â  Ingram is particularly interested in receiving all victim statements made in opposition to his parole.Â  Specifically, he argues that he is entitled to these documents under the South Carolina Freedom of Information Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 30-4-10 through -110 (1991 & Supp. 2004), and that failing to disclose the records constitutes a violation of his rights to due process and confrontation at his parole hearing.
 We affirm the circuit courtâ€™s dismissal of Ingramâ€™s petition pursuant to Rule 220, SCACR, and the following authority:Â  Redmond v. Lexington Co. Sch. Dist., 314 S.C. 431, 437, 445 S.E.2d 441, 445 (1994) (â€œTo obtain a writ of mandamus . . . the applicant must show . . . a duty of respondent to perform the act . . . .â€); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 30-4-40(a)(4) (1991) (exempting matters from FOIA requests which are specifically exempted by other state law); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-21-290 (Supp. 2005) (â€œAll information and data obtained in the discharge of his official duty by a probation officer is privileged information . . . and may not be disclosed directly or indirectly to anyone other than the judge or others entitled under this chapter to receive reports . . . .â€); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-21-50 (Supp. 2005) (â€œNo inmate has a right of confrontation at the [parole] hearing.â€); Sullivan v. S.C. Dept. of Corrections, 355 S.C. 437, 443 FN. 4, 586 S.E.2d 124, 127 FN. 4 (2003) (â€œ . . . parole is a privilege, not a right.â€); and Furtick v. SCPPPS, 352 S.C. 594, 598 FN. 4, 576 S.E.2d 146, 149 FN. 4 (2003) (confirming that an inmate has no liberty interest sufficient to trigger due process rights in parole). 
 AFFIRMED.[1]
KITTREDGE, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur. 

[1] We decide this case without oral arguments pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Johnson v. Sonoco Products Company
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Francis Ike Johnson, Respondent/Appellant,
v.
Sonoco Products Company, and GAB Robins, Inc., Appellants/Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Darlington County
Â J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-281
Heard April 6, 2006 â€“ Filed June 15, 2006
Withdrawn, Substituted and Refiled September 20, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Michael A. Farry and David A. Wilson, both of Greenville, for Appellant-Respondents.
Vernon F. Dunbar, of Greenville, for Respondent-Appellant.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this Workersâ€™ Compensation case, Sonoco Products Company (Sonoco) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order reversing the Full Commission and affirming the Single Commissionerâ€™s order awarding benefits to Francis Ike Johnson.Â  The circuit court found the Full Commission failed to comply with a regulation requiring it to vote within ten days and thereby affirmed the Single Commissioner by default.Â  We affirm.[1]  
FACTS
Francis Ike Johnson worked at Sonoco from 1971 to 1994.Â  Johnson stopped working at Sonoco in January 1994 after he was hospitalized for pulmonary problems.Â  In 1999, Johnson filed a workersâ€™ compensation claim against Sonoco, which Sonoco denied.Â  
At a hearing before the Single Commissioner, Johnson argued his exposure to the chemical Perlite aggravated his pulmonary problems which rendered him permanently and totally disabled.Â  In May 2002, the Single Commissioner issued an order, finding Johnson sustained an accidental pulmonary injury as a consequence of his contact with harmful chemicals, including Perlite, while working at Sonoco.Â  The Single Commissioner ordered Sonoco to pay Johnson permanent and total disability compensation.Â  
In June 2002, Sonoco appealed the decision to the Full Commission, and the Full Commission held a hearing on October 30, 2002.Â  The following day, October 31, 2002, one of the three commissioners on the Full Commission wrote Johnsonâ€™s and Sonocoâ€™s legal counsel to inform them that a vote on the matter would be delayed.Â  On May 28, 2003, almost seven months after the hearing on the matter, the Full Commission issued its order reversing the Single Commissioner, finding Johnson failed to prove he sustained a compensable injury while working at Sonoco.Â  Johnson appealed the Full Commissionâ€™s order. Â 
In September 2004, both parties appeared before the circuit court.Â  On the day of the hearing, Johnson argued the Full Commission violated a regulation requiring it to vote within ten days of the hearing.Â  Johnsonâ€™s attorney recounted that after the Full Commission rendered its opinion, he asked for the vote sheets showing each commissioner registered his or her vote within the ten day time period, but the vote sheets could not be found.Â  Johnson submitted to the circuit court affidavits from two former commissioners and employees of the Full Commission attesting to the voting procedure employed by the Full Commission.Â  Sonoco objected to these affidavits as outside the record and not properly before the circuit court.Â  
After the hearing, the circuit court wrote Johnsonâ€™s and Sonocoâ€™s legal counsel to inform them that it would accept Johnsonâ€™s affidavits but also open the record to accept additional extrinsic evidence on the issue of whether there were procedural irregularities below.Â  Sonoco sought to depose Johnsonâ€™s affiants, which the trial judge allowed, but with some limitations.Â  The circuit court allowed Sonoco to depose both former commissioners and one of two Full Commission employees, but did not allow Sonoco to depose Johnsonâ€™s legal counsel, who was a former commissioner.Â  Sonoco deposed both former commissioners and a former general counsel for the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission, which the circuit court entered into evidence.Â  The record also contained an â€œaffidavitâ€ from the three commissioners on the Full Commission.[2]Â  The commissioners stated that two of them had recorded their votes as of November 7, 2002, which constituted a majority reversal of the Single Commissioner.Â  Even though a notary signature block appeared at the bottom of the document, the document was not notarized.Â  Therefore, the circuit court found it did not comply with Rule 11(c), SCRCP and refused to give it any weight. 
In March 2005, the circuit court issued a final order vacating the Full Commissionâ€™s order and reinstating the Single Commissionerâ€™s order.Â  The circuit court held that the only proper evidence before it was that the vote was not timely taken as Sonoco failed to prove that the Full Commission voted within the proscribed time period.Â  Because the Full Commission violated the regulation requiring it to vote within ten days of the hearing, the Full Commission did not have jurisdiction to issue the May 28, 2003 order.Â  The circuit court then affirmed the Single Commissionerâ€™s order awarding Johnson benefits, finding the Full Commission affirmed the Single Commissioner by default.Â  Sonoco appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The scope of judicial review of agency decisions is governed by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (2005); Brown v. South Carolina Dept. of Health and Envtl. Control  348 S.C. 507, 515, 560 S.E.2d 410, 414 (2002).Â  The appellate court will not generally substitute its judgment for that of the agency as to the weight of evidence on questions of fact, but may reverse or modify the decision if substantial rights of the appellant have been prejudiced because the administrative findings, inferences, conclusions or decisions are made upon unlawful procedure or affected by other error of law.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(c) and (d) (2005).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Sonoco argues the circuit court erred in accepting extrinsic evidence to assist it in determining whether the Full Commission violated a regulation requiring it to vote within ten days of the hearing.Â  Sonoco further argues the circuit court erred in concluding the Full Commission violated this regulation.Â  We disagree. 
The first issue is whether the circuit court is entitled to consider extrinsic evidence in determining whether the Full Commission voted within ten days of the hearing.Â  The South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act (APA) establishes the standard for judicial review of decisions of the workersâ€™ compensation
commission.Â  Bass v. Kenco Group, 366 S.C. 450, 456-57, 622 S.E.2d 577, 580 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Section 1-23-380(A)(5) of the APA provides that judicial review of an administrative proceeding should be â€œconducted by the court without a jury and shall be confined to the record,â€ with the caveat that â€œ[i]n cases of alleged irregularities in procedure before the agency, not shown in the record, proof thereon may be taken in the court.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A) (2005).Â  In Ross v. Medical University of South Carolina, 317 S.C. 377, 380, 453 S.E.2d 880, 882 (1994), the supreme court held that this section expressly authorizes the circuit court to accept proof of alleged irregularities in an agency proceeding, explaining â€œ[t]he language â€˜proof thereon may be taken in the courtâ€™ does not require the court itself to â€˜take proofâ€™ but, rather, to allow such proof to be entered at the circuit court level, at the courtâ€™s discretion.â€
Here, the circuit court only considered extrinsic evidence relating to the issue of whether the Full Commission properly adhered to a procedural rule proscribed by its own regulations.Â  The circuit court did not consider any new evidence related to the factual basis of the underlying action.Â  Therefore, under section 1-23-380(A)(5), the circuit court properly exercised its discretion by considering extrinsic evidence pertaining to an alleged procedural irregularity in the Full Commissionâ€™s proceeding.Â Â  
The second issue is whether the circuit court properly handled the way in which it accepted this extrinsic evidence.Â  Sonoco argues the circuit court unfairly limited Sonocoâ€™s ability to develop and present its side of the case.Â  As discussed above, section 1-23-380(A)(5) allows the circuit court, in its discretion, to order discovery and admit extrinsic evidence in APA cases involving an alleged irregularity in the proceeding.Â  Id. at 381, 453 S.E.2d at 883.Â Â  The admission of evidence is within the sound discretion of the circuit court and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion amounting to an error of law.Â  Vaught v. A.O. Hardee & Sons, Inc., 366 S.C. 475, 480, 623 S.E.2d 373, 375 (2005).Â  The circuit court allowed Sonoco to depose most of Johnsonâ€™s affiants.Â  The circuit court did not allow Sonoco to depose Johnsonâ€™s legal counsel for fear counsel would be disqualified.Â  Although the circuit court prevented Sonoco from deposing Johnsonâ€™s legal counsel and some members of the Full Commission staff, the circuit court nevertheless provided the parties additional time to submit affidavits, deposition testimony, and legal memoranda.[3]Â  In light of the opportunity the circuit court afforded both parties to develop the issue of whether a procedural irregularity occurred below, the circuit court did not err in the manner in which it oversaw the introduction of extrinsic evidence.Â Â Â  
The final issue is whether the circuit court erred in concluding the Full Commission violated a regulation requiring it to vote within ten days of the hearing.Â  â€œRegulations authorized by the legislature have the force of law.â€Â  Goodman v. City of Columbia, 318 S.C. 488, 490, 458 S.E.2d 531, 532 (1995).Â  An administrative agency can only exercise the powers which have been conferred upon it by the South Carolina General Assembly and must follow its own regulations and the provisions of the APA.Â  Triska v. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 292 S.C. 190, 194, 355 S.E.2d 531, 533 (1987).Â  â€œAny action taken outside of its statutory and regulatory power is null and void.â€Â  Id.Â  Section 42-3-30 of the South Carolina Code (1976) authorizes the commission to create regulations related to workersâ€™ compensation laws of this State.Â  It provides that the commission â€œshall promulgate all regulations relating to the administration of the workersâ€™ compensation laws of this State . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-3-30 (1976).Â  Regulation 67-709(C) provides: â€œThe Commissioners reviewing the case may confer and shall vote within ten days of the date of review.â€Â  25A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 67-709(C) (1976) (emphasis added).Â  Regulation 67-709(F) provides: â€œIf a Commissioner fails to register a vote within the periods referred to above, the Commissioner is deemed to have registered a vote affirming the Hearing Commissioner and may not vote otherwise.â€Â  25A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 67-709(F) (1976). Â Â 
The Full Commission hearing occurred on October 30, 2002.Â  The next day, one of the three commissioners on the Full Commission wrote Johnsonâ€™s and Sonocoâ€™s counsel and informed them that the Full Commission needed more time to review the case.[4]Â  More than six months later, the Full Commission issued its order.Â  When Johnsonâ€™s attorney requested the Full Commissionâ€™s vote sheets, the vote sheets could not be found.Â  At the circuit court, Johnson and Sonoco introduced evidence related to the issue of whether the Full Commission voted within the ten day period mandated by Regulation 67-709(C).Â  The circuit court considered all admissible evidence and concluded the Full Commission did not vote within the ten day period required by Regulation 67-709(C).Â  
The circuit court considered the testimony of former commissioners Thomas Marchant and William Clyburn.Â  Both testified that during their tenures they voted after each hearing on a vote sheet and that the judicial director would make certain the vote sheets were turned in before the ten day period expired.Â  Pursuant to Rule 11(c), SCRCP, the circuit court properly excluded the â€œaffidavitâ€ from the three commissioners who comprised the Full Commission because the document was not notarized.Â  Rule 11(c), SCRCP (Affidavits or verifications authorized or permitted under these Rules shall be written statements or declarations by a party or his attorney of record or of a witness, sworn to or affirmed before an officer authorized to administer oaths, that the affiant knows the facts stated to be true of his own knowledge, except as to those matters stated on information and belief and as to those matters that he believes them to be true.).Â  Moreover, the admission or exclusion of evidence in general is within the sound discretion of the trial court and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion. Â Fields v. Regional Medical Center Orangeburg, 363 S.C. 19, 25-26, 609 S.E.2d 506, 509 (2005).Â  We find no abuse of discretion in the circuit courtâ€™s exclusion of the affidavit.[5]Â  
Because there was no credible evidence showing the members of the Full Commission voted within the ten day time period, the circuit court did not err in finding the Full Commission violated Regulation 67-709(C).Â  Accordingly, pursuant to Regulation 67-709(F), the order of the Single Commission is reinstated and affirmed.Â  The circuit courtâ€™s order is 
 AFFIRMED.
BEATTY, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Johnson also appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order to the extent it does not address the findings of the Full Commission.Â  Because we affirm the circuit courtâ€™s order, we do not address his cross-appeal.Â  Â 
[2] It appears that this â€œaffidavitâ€ was entered into the record by the Commission. 
[3]Â  There is no indication in the record Sonoco requested the circuit court entertain oral arguments, though section 1-23-380(A)(5) entitled it to do so. (â€œThe court, upon request, shall hear oral argument and receive written briefs.â€). 
[4]Â  Sonoco also argues the circuit court erred in refusing to find Johnson waived his right to object to the extension of the ten day period or that Johnson is estopped from asserting the Full Commission erred in not registering its votes within the ten day period.Â  The Full Commission was bound by Regulation 67-709(C) and had no authority to deviate from its requirement that the Full Commission vote within ten days.Â  Triska, 292 S.C. at 194, 355 S.E.2d at 533.Â  (holding that an agency must follow its own regulations).Â  Therefore, neither the Full Commission nor the respective parties could waive it.Â  Johnson also cannot be estopped for taking the position the Full Commission erred in not registering its votes within the ten day rule because that position was untenable as a matter of law.
[5]Â  Perplexingly, Sonoco did not seek to depose any of the three commissioners who comprised the Full Commission even though the circuit court allowed both parties to take additional depositions.Â Â

title: Burgess v. SC Department of Corrections
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
A. Charles Burgess, Jr., Appellant,
v.
South Carolina Department of Corrections, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Â S. Jackson Kimball, III, Special Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-282
Submitted June 1, 2006 â€“ Filed June 15, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
John D. Elliott, of Columbia, for Appellant.
David L. Morrison and Andrew F. Lindemann, both of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Charles Burgess appeals the trial courtâ€™s order granting summary judgment in favor of the South Carolina Department of Corrections (SCDC).Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
FACTS
The facts in this case are undisputed.Â  Burgess was incarcerated under the supervision of SCDC from February 1985 until April 1998.Â  While Burgess was incarcerated, he pleaded guilty to perjury charges in federal court and received a sentence to be served under the supervision of the Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP).Â  As a result, the BOP lodged a retainer with SCDC requiring Burgess to be transferred to federal custody once he completed the state sentence.Â  
In 1981, the South Carolina General Assembly enacted legislation providing for a supervised furlough program for prisoners, excluding prisoners who had committed specified crimes.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-13-710 (Supp. 1981).Â  Subsequently, the General Assembly enacted section 24-13-720 mandating that a prisoner be released on supervised furlough six months prior to the expiration of his sentence, provided he was not serving a life sentence and had no disciplinary infractions within the last six months.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-13-720 (1989).Â  This section did not address whether inmates who were excluded from participation in the supervised furlough program under section 24-13-710 were also excluded from the mandatory program in section 24-13-720.Â  On June 14, 1993, the General Assembly amended section 24-23-720 to incorporate the eligibility requires of section 24-13-710 and make the program permissive rather then mandatory.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-13-710 (Supp. 1993).Â Â Â  Â Â 
In Plyler v. Evatt, the South Carolina Supreme Court construed the meaning of section 24-13-720.Â  313 S.C. 405, 438 S.E.2d 244 (1993).Â  The court held that the amendment constituted a change in the law and that individuals who met the requirements before the 1993 amendment was enacted were entitled to participate in the program, but that individuals who were not eligible for release prior to June 14, 1993 could participate in the program only if qualified under the amended statute.Â  Id. at 407 n.1, 438 S.E.2d 245 n.1.Â  The court reasoned that the amended statute could be applied to an inmate who was sentenced before its effective date because the program was not a part of his sentence.Â Â Â Â  
On October 16, 1997, the Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit interpreted section 24-13-720 in a habeas corpus action. Plyler v. Moore, 129 F.3d 728 (4th Cir. 1997).Â  The Fourth Circuit ruled that the 1993 amendment could not be applied to inmates convicted prior to 1993 because the amendment had the effect of increasing the length of their incarceration and such a retroactive application of the law violates the Ex Post Facto Clause.Â  Id. at 735.Â  The Fourth Circuit then effected a stay until the State of South Carolina could petition the Supreme Court for a writ of certiorari.Â  The Supreme Court denied the petition on June 22, 1998, and the stay was lifted.Â  Moore v. Cummings, 524 U.S. 945 (1998) denying cert. to Plyler v. Moore, 129 F.3d 728 (4th Cir. 1997).Â  
Meanwhile, Burgess was serving his state sentence.Â  Burgess asserts he was interviewed for the supervised furlough program in October, 1997 and was told he would be released to his federal retainer at that time.Â  Burgess did not participate in the furlough program, but was detained pending the outcome of South Carolinaâ€™s petition for certiorari. Â Burgess completed his state sentence and was released to federal authorities in April 1998.[2]Â  
After the Supreme Court denied certiorari in 1998, Burgess, who was in the midst of serving his federal sentence, claims the BOP informed him it would credit his federal sentence with six months if the SCDC would verify he would have been eligible for the furlough program but for the stay issued in the Plyler decision. Â In 1999, Burgess contacted SCDC and requested a letter attesting he was eligible for the furlough program.Â  SCDC wrote a letter to the BOP, stating Burgess was â€œeligibleâ€ for the furlough program, but â€œnot approvedâ€ for participation.Â  Burgess contends this letter was inadequate to convince the BOP to credit his sentence. Â Â Â 
Burgess was placed on supervised release by the federal authorities in June 1999.Â  Burgess violated the terms of his release, and the district court imposed a sentence, beginning June 7, 2001 and ending March 4, 2003.Â  On May 16, 2002, while he was serving his second federal sentence, Burgess again contacted SCDC and requested a letter stating he would have been released under the supervised furlough program.Â  When SCDC failed to send the letter he requested, Burgess filed suit in the United States District Court for the District of South Carolina, alleging SCDC violated his rights under 42 U.S.C.A Â§ 1983.Â  The district court dismissed the suit, finding Burgess alleged only a state claim and did not state facts sufficient to trigger a section 1983 claim.Â  
Burgess then filed suit under the South Carolina Tort Claims Act alleging SCDC was negligent in failing to confirm his eligibility for the furlough program to the BOP, which caused him to serve an additional six months in the federal penitentiary.Â  SCDC filed a motion for summary judgment.Â  The trial court granted summary judgment in SCDCâ€™s favor, finding, among other things, Burgessâ€™s negligence action was barred by the two year statute of limitations.Â  This appeal followed.Â  Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œWhen reviewing the grant of summary judgment, the appellate court applies the same standard applied by the trial court pursuant to Rule 56(c), SCRCP.â€Â  Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 494, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002). â€œSummary judgment is appropriate when it is clear that there is no genuine issue of material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€ Baird v. Charleston County, 333 S.C. 519, 529, 511 S.E.2d 69, 74 (1999).Â  â€œIn determining whether any triable issue of fact exists, the evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably drawn therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.â€ Summer v. Carpenter, 328 S.C. 36, 42, 492 S.E.2d 55, 58 (1997).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Burgess argues the trial court erred in granting summary judgment in favor of SCDC.Â  We disagree.[3]Â  
Burgess brought his negligence claim under the South Carolina Tort Claims Act.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-10 to 220 (2005). The Tort Claims Act is a limited waiver of governmental immunity, and sets forth a two-year statute of limitations in which negligence actions may be brought against the state.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-110 (2005)Â  (â€œExcept as provided for in Section 15‑3‑40, any action brought pursuant to this chapter is forever barred unless an action is commenced within two years after the date the loss was or should have been discovered;Â  provided, that if the claimant first filed a claim pursuant to this chapter then the action for damages based upon the same occurrence is forever barred unless the action is commenced within three years of the date the loss was or should have been discovered.â€) 
Under the discovery rule, the statutory limitations period begins to run from the date when the injury resulting from the wrongful conduct either is discovered or may be discovered by the exercise of reasonable diligence.Â  Cline v. J.E. Faulkner Homes, Inc., 359 S.C. 367, 370-71, 597 S.E.2d 27, 28 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  The statute of limitations, therefore, runs from the date the injury is discoverable by the exercise of reasonable diligence. Graniteville Co. v. IH Servs., 316 S.C. 146, 148, 447 S.E.2d 226, 228 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  An injured party must act promptly when the facts and circumstances of the injury
would place a reasonable person on notice that a claim against another party might exist.Â  Republic Contracting Corp. v. South Carolina Dept. of Highways and Public Transp., 332 S.C. 197, 207, 503 S.E.2d 761,766 (Ct. App. 1998). That an injured party may not comprehend the extent of the injuries is immaterial.Â  Id. at 207, 503 S.E.2d at 767.
Burgess attempts to avoid the application of the statute of limitations by asserting that he has two distinct claims against SCDC for failing to write an adequate letter to the BOP.Â  He contends his first cause of action accrued when he made the initial request in 1999, and SCDC failed to send a letter adequate to convince the BOP to credit his sentence.Â  Burgess concedes the statute of limitations bars his claim in regard to the 1999 request.Â  However, Burgess argues that his second request in June 2001, made when he was re-incarcerated after his federal supervised furlough was revoked, gave rise to a new claim.Â  
The trial court ruled the second refusal of the same request that SCDC write a letter to the BOP, constituted one cause of action for negligence and did not â€œbegin the running of the statute of limitations anew.â€Â  We agree with the trial courtâ€™s reasoning.Â  Burgessâ€™s complaint alleges one cause of action for negligence based on SCDCâ€™s failure to write a letter to the BOP in order that his federal sentence could be credited by six months.Â  Therefore, the statute of limitations began to run when Burgess first requested such a letter. The statute of limitations clock did not restart each time Burgess made an additional request and SCDC failed to write the requested letter.Â  Because SCDC first failed to a write the letter in 1999 adequate to convince the BOP to credit Burgessâ€™s sentence, and Burgess did not serve his action on SCDC until January 2004, the two year statute of limitations bars his claim.Â  Accordingly, the order of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.
KITTREDGE, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur. 

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Â It is unclear from the record whether Burgess was detained pending the outcome of South Carolinaâ€™s petition for certiorari or because of the detainer which required him to be transferred to BOP custody to be begin serving his federal sentence; however, Burgess asserts SCDC informed him he would be released to his federal retainer when he was interviewed in October 1997.
[3] Â Because we affirm on this issue, we decline to address Burgessâ€™s remaining arguments.Â  Rule 220(c), SCACR; see also Whiteside v. Cherokee County School Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 341, 428 S.E.2d 886, 889 (1993) (holding an appellate court need not address remaining issues when the resolution of a prior issue is dispositive).

title: Kneedler v. Griffin
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(D)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Alexis Kneedler, Respondent,
v.
Shawn R. Griffin, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Â Robert E. Guess, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-283
Submitted June 1, 2006 â€“ Filed June 15, 2006

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
Thomas F. McDow, for Appellant.
Robert M. P. Masella, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Shawn R. Griffin (Husband) appeals a family court order adopting and modifying a Florida divorce order.Â  We affirm with modification.[1]
FACTS
Husband and Alexis Kneedler (Wife) married in May 1996 and divorced February 14, 2000, in Pinellas, Florida.Â  One child, Shiann Rose Liegh Griffin (Child), was born of the marriage on May 29, 1997.Â  
The Florida divorce order granted the parties joint custody, with Wifeâ€™s home designated as Childâ€™s primary residence.Â  After the divorce, Husband moved to Massachusetts.Â  Wife and Child subsequently relocated to York County, South Carolina.Â  In October 2002, Wife filed the present complaint, seeking to domesticate the Florida order, recalculate Husbandâ€™s child support payments and obtain arrearages, gain sole custody of Child, alter Husbandâ€™s visitation schedule, require Husband to post a security for future child support, and attorneyâ€™s fees.
Prior to a hearing on Wifeâ€™s complaint, the parties settled several issues by way of consent order, which resolved some issues temporarily and others permanently.Â  The parties agreed to domesticate the Florida order, give Wife sole custody of Child, and finalize Husbandâ€™s child support obligation and payment schedule for his arrearages.Â  As to Husbandâ€™s visitation schedule, the consent order reads as follows:

[Husband] shall have temporary visitation to include 9:00 a.m. December 26 through six p.m. January 2 each year; Easter vacation or spring break each year from the end of school until 6:00 p.m. the day before school resumes, four weeks during the summer of 2003 and six weeks every summer thereafter provided there are no major difficulties during the summer of 2003, and such other times as the parties may agree, including weekends when [Father] may be [in] the York County area.Â  This provision is intended to be permanent as well as temporary. (emphasis added)

A hearing on the partiesâ€™ remaining issues was held in February 2004.Â  Husband did not appear, but his counsel was present.Â  The family courtâ€™s final order required Husband to obtain a $56,703 life insurance policy to secure future child support payments.Â  The family court also awarded Wife $1,095 in attorneyâ€™s fees accrued since the consent orderâ€™s entry.Â  Husbandâ€™s summer visitation with Child was stated in the order simply as â€œfour weeks during the summer.â€Â  This appeal followed the denial of Husbandâ€™s motion to reconsider.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court has authority to find the facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence. Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996).Â  This broad scope of review, however, does not require us to disregard the findings of the family court.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  We remain mindful that the family court judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 91, 561 S.E.2d 610, 613 (Ct. App. 2002).
DISCUSSION
I. Husbandâ€™s Visitation
Husband argues the family court erred in modifying his summer visitation schedule from six to four weeks because the issue was not properly before the family court to determine.Â  We agree and modify the terms of Husbandâ€™s summer visitation to those agreed upon in the partiesâ€™ consent order.
As stated in Heins v. Heins, 344 S.C. 146, 543 S.E.2d 224 (Ct. App. 2001):

It is well settled that ordinarily a party may not receive relief not contemplated in his pleadings.Â  While it is true that pleadings in the family court must be liberally construed, this rule cannot be stretched so as to permit the judge to award relief not contemplated by the pleadings.Â  Due process requires that a litigant be placed on notice of the issues which the court is to consider.

Id. at 152, 543 S.E.2d at 227 (internal citations omitted).Â  
Although the issue of Husbandâ€™s visitation was discussed in Wifeâ€™s initial pleadings, the 2003 consent order between the parties specifically states that its resolution of the visitation issue is permanent.Â  As stated above, Husbandâ€™s summer visitation was agreed upon to be six weeks, contingent only upon â€œmajor difficultiesâ€ arising during Childâ€™s 2003 summer visit.Â  
At the outset of the hearing on Wifeâ€™s remaining issues, the following colloquy took place between the family court judge and both partiesâ€™ counsel:

Wifeâ€™s Counsel:Â  The temporary [consent order] dealt with some matters on a permanent basis, your honor and I donâ€™t know if you would just like to know what they are because there are some issues are really not â€“ 
The Court:Â  Well, tell me â€“
Wifeâ€™s Counsel:Â  There are some issues in the complaint that are not really before you, your honor.
The Court:Â  Well, tell me what issues are to be tried today.
Wifeâ€™s Counsel:Â  Okay, your honor, [Wifeâ€™s Counsel gives lengthy discussion on Childâ€™s transportation to and from visitation, child support and arrearages, the life insurance policy, and attorneyâ€™s fees] . . .
The Court:Â  Do you agree, [Husbandâ€™s Counsel]?
Husbandâ€™s Counsel:Â  Let me make sure I understand.Â  I understand that to be transportation, child support, insurance arrearage, life insurance, and attorneyâ€™s fees.
Wifeâ€™s Counsel:Â  Correct.

During the hearing, Childâ€™s 2003 summer visitation was addressed only once and referenced only in regard to Wifeâ€™s counselâ€™s fee affidavit.Â  When questioned by the court about Childâ€™s visitation schedule, Wifeâ€™s counsel replied:

Your honor, it says it is December 26th through January 2nd of each year, spring break, and four weeks during the summer and six weeks if there were no major difficulties, but I think there was, and that may be conceded, reflected in my affidavit, and other terms that they can agree on when he is in the area the child lives.

Wifeâ€™s counselâ€™s fee affidavit vaguely references an incident during which Child was injured while playing with Husbandâ€™s girlfriend and her child.Â  At no other time during the hearing was the Childâ€™s 2003 summer visit with Husband mentioned.
We conclude the above allegations insufficient to properly bring the visitation issue before the family court.Â  Accordingly, the family court erred in altering Husbandâ€™s visitation when such relief was not requested and the issue was permanently resolved by a prior consent order.Â  As agreed by the parties in the consent order, we modify the family court order to read as follows:
HOLIDAY AND SUMMER VISITATION

The minor child has three scheduled visits with Father each year: Christmas from December 26th through 6:00 p.m. January 2nd; Easter vacation or spring break each year from the end of school until 6:00 p.m. the day before school resumes; and four weeks during the summer of 2003 and six weeks every summer thereafter provided there are no major difficulties during the summer of 2003. [remaining section of family court order affirmed]

II. Life Insurance Policy
Husband argues the family court erred in requiring him to maintain a declining balance term life insurance policy to secure the payment of child support.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe family court is within its legal authority to require a supporting spouse to maintain a life insurance policy naming the child as beneficiary to insure the continued support of the minor child.â€Â  Ivey v. Ivey, 286 S.C. 315, 318, 334 S.E.2d 123, 125 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  The decision to require the maintenance of a life insurance policy for the benefit of a minor child must be justified by compelling reasons, such as failure to pay child support in the past.Â  Id.
In the present case, Husband conceded he has a history of failing to make child support payments.Â  Furthermore, Husbandâ€™s sole income consists of monthly unemployment benefits, making the potential for future payment failures a reasonable concern.Â  Because Husband demonstrated a past reluctance to comply with child support orders and an unstable financial history, the family court did not err in requiring Husband to maintain a life insurance policy for the benefit of Child.
III. Attorneyâ€™s Fees 
Husband argues the family court erred in awarding Wife $1,095 in attorneyâ€™s fees accrued since entry of the partiesâ€™ consent order.Â  We disagree.
An award of attorneyâ€™s fees and costs is a discretionary matter not to be overturned absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Patel v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 533, 599 S.E.2d 114, 123 (2004).Â  As did the family court, we have reviewed the applicable factors set forth in Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 403 S.E.2d 313 (1991), and E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 415 S.E.2d 812 (1992).Â  See Shirley v. Shirley, 342 S.C. 324, 341, 536 S.E.2d 427, 436 (Ct. App. 2000) (outlining the applicable factors in determining whether to grant attorneyâ€™s fees and the proper fee amount).Â  Under the facts and circumstances of this case, particularly the charitable payment schedule granted Husband to repay Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees, we find no abuse of discretion in the award.
For the foregoing reasons, the family courtâ€™s order is AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED in section one of this opinion.
KITTREDGE, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Spane v. Rentway
text:
PREHEARING REPORT


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Michael J. Spane, Employee/Claimant, Respondent,
v.
Rentway, Inc./Americaâ€™s Best Security, Employers, And Employers Insurance of Wassau and Capital City Insurance Co., Carriers,
Of Whom Rentway, Inc., Employer, and Employers Insurance of Wausau, Carrier, are
Appellants,
And Americaâ€™s Best Security, Employer, and Capital City Insurance Co., Carrier, are
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â J. Mark Hayes, II, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-284
Submitted June 1, 2006 â€“ Filed June 19, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Darryl D. Smalls, of Columbia, for Appellants.
Donald L. Van Riper, J. Marvin Mullis, Jr., of Columbia, for Respondents.Â  
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Rentway, Inc. and Employerâ€™s Insurance of Wassau (Rentway) appeal the circuit courtâ€™s order affirming the decision of the appellate panel of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (appellate panel) awarding benefits to Michael J. Spane.Â  Rentway argues that the appellate panel erred in ruling that Spaneâ€™s present medical condition was the sole responsibility of Rentway and that Spaneâ€™s new accident did not arise out of or during the course of his employment with Rentway.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
FACTS
On May 15, 1999, Spane suffered a work-related injury to his back lifting a television while employed by Rentway, Inc.Â  Over the following months, the back injury worsened, and as of December 1999 Spane had been diagnosed with a back injury as a result of the lifting accident.Â  Rentway admitted Spane injured his back in the lifting incident.Â  Shortly after the injury, Spane left his employment with Rentway and worked for other employers, including A.T. Services, John A. Defede Law Firm, Verizon Wireless, and Americaâ€™s Best Security. 
Americaâ€™s Best hired Spane to do light duty security work. Â Spane disclosed his pre-existing, continuing back condition, and as a result, Americaâ€™s Best assigned him to work in a low traffic area.Â  However, in August of 2000, Spane suffered an injury to his groin when he jumped a small ditch in an attempt to avoid gunfire at a club where he provided security for Americaâ€™s Best.Â  While receiving treatment for the groin injury at Lexington Medical Center, Spane also complained of lower back pain.Â  Spane testified the back pain he complained of was not a new injury but rather was the continuing pain from the Rentway injury.Â  Spane further testified the continuing back pain was not a result of the new groin injury, explaining that the back pain continued in the same manner even after the groin injury had fully healed.Â  
In May of 2001, Spane underwent surgery for the continuing back pain. Â During surgery, a disk ruptured and a nerve was damaged in his right foot.Â  After the operation, Spaneâ€™s back condition did not improve and continued treatment was required. 
Spane filed a form 50 seeking temporary benefits and further medical care as a result of his back injury suffered while employed by Rentway.Â  Rentway did not deny the back injury but argued that the back injury was aggravated by the subsequent groin injury sustained while Spane was employed by Americaâ€™s Best. Â Rentway argued Americaâ€™s Best should be responsible for some portion of the benefits due to Spane.Â  Americaâ€™s Best denied any responsibility for Spaneâ€™s back injury.Â  
After a hearing, the commissioner found the following: (1) that the claimant sustained injury from an accident arising out of and in the course of his employment with Rentway, (2) that the plaintiff was a covered employee at the time of the accident, (3) that the plaintiff was entitled to temporary total benefits for his leg and back conditions, and (4) that Rentway was responsible for the continuing causally related medical care of the claimant.Â  The commissioner found Americaâ€™s Best was responsible only for the costs associated with the emergency room visit for Spaneâ€™s groin injury.Â  
The appellate panel and the circuit court affirmed the decision of the commissioner.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Rentway argues the appellate panel erred in finding it was solely responsible for Spaneâ€™s back injury.Â  Specifically, Rentway argues the evidence suggests Spane suffered a new back injury while employed with Americaâ€™s Best.Â  We disagree.Â  
The South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act applies to appeals from decisions of the appellate panel.  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 134-35, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).  In an appeal from the appellate panel, neither this court nor the circuit court may substitute its judgment for that of the appellate panel as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact but may reverse when the decision is affected by an error of law.  Corbin v. Kohler Co., 351 S.C. 613, 617, 571 S.E.2d 92, 95 (Ct. App. 2002).  â€œAny review of the [appellate panelâ€™s] factual findings is governed by the substantial evidence standard.â€  Lockridge v. Santens of Am., Inc., 344 S.C. 511, 515, 544 S.E.2d 842, 844 (Ct. App. 2001).  Accordingly, we limit review to deciding whether the appellate panelâ€™s decision is unsupported by substantial evidence or is controlled by some error of law.  Corbin, 351 S.C. at 617, 571 S.E.2d at 95.  
â€œSubstantial evidence is evidence that, in viewing the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the same conclusion that the [appellate panel] reached.â€  Lockridge, 344 S.C. at 515, 544 S.E.2d at 844.  â€œThe â€˜possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent an administrative agencyâ€™s finding from being supported by substantial evidence.â€™â€  Lee v. Harborside Cafe, 350 S.C. 74, 78, 564 S.E.2d 354, 356 (Ct. App. 2002) (quoting Palmetto Alliance, Inc. v. South Carolina Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 282 S.C. 430, 432, 319 S.E.2d 695, 696 (1984)).
Substantial evidence supports the appellate panelâ€™s decision that Spaneâ€™s back condition was caused solely by the admitted accident at Rentway.Â  The medical evidence in the record supports the appellate panelâ€™s finding that the back injury was caused by the 1999 lifting injury, not the August 2000 groin pull.Â  During his medical evaluations from 1999 to 2001, Spane has consistently complained of constant low back pain that radiates down his right leg and foot.Â  Even the medical records from eight months after the 2000 groin pull only reference the 1999 back injury.Â  The medical records do not indicate that the back injury causally resulted from or were aggravated by the ditch-leaping event.Â  In 2001, Dr. Ross D. Lynch specifically notes that the injury stemmed from the 1999 lifting injury and that the condition had progressively gotten worse.Â  In January of 2000, before the groin injury, Dr. Scott B. Boyd wrote, â€œMr. Spane returns today for evaluationâ€¦ again he says he is miserable with pain.Â  He is unable to work, and he feels like he is getting worse.Â  Again he describes his pain as radiating from his back down into his hip and leg.â€Â  Approximately eighteen months after the groin injury, the medical records indicate that Spane still suffered from the same pain Dr. Boyd recorded before the groin injury.Â  Moreover, Spane testified the continuing back pain was not a result of the new groin injury, explaining that the back pain continued in the same manner even after the groin injury had fully healed.Â  While it might be possible to reach a different conclusion, substantial evidence exists to support the findings of the appellate panel.Â Â Â Â  
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, the decision of the circuit court is hereby
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ. concur.Â Â  

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
