title: State v. Scott
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(D)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Brian William Scott, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-285
Heard May 31, 2006 â€“ Filed June 19, 2006Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Symmes Watkins Culbertson, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargn McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., Office of the Attorney General, of Columbia, Robert M. Ariail, 13th Circuit Solicitorâ€™s Office, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Brian William Scott appeals the circuit courtâ€™s denial of his motion for a new trial, arguing the State violated his due process rights by failing to comply with Rule 5, SCRCrimP, and the mandates of Brady v. Maryland, 373 U.S. 83 (1963).Â  We affirm. 
FACTS
In February 1997, a jury found Brian Williams Scott guilty of murder and sentenced him to life imprisonment.Â  At his trial, the State relied heavily on the testimony of James Johnson and Tyrone Adams, both present at the alleged murder of Tyrone
Longino.
According to James Johnsonâ€™s trial testimony, he met Scott while working at a local restaurant a couple of weeks prior to the incident in question.Â  Johnson testified he left work around 10:30 p.m. on the night of February 14, 1992.Â  While walking to a friendâ€™s house, Johnson ran into Scott, Adams, Longino, and another coworker.Â  He was introduced to Adams and Longino for the first time.Â  The group then went to an apartment shared by Scott and Logino and proceeded to consume alcohol and smoke marijuana.Â  At some point, Johnsonâ€™s other coworker left.Â  The remaining four then spent some time driving around in Longinoâ€™s car and making phone calls in an attempt to purchase drugs.
Following several failed attempts to secure a drug purchase, the group pulled into a gas station.Â  Adams exited the vehicle and walked to a nearby phone to page a potential seller.Â  Johnson testified that an argument then ensued between Scott and Longino over the roommateâ€™s apparent lack of enthusiasm for the drug purchase.Â  According to Johnson, Scott became increasingly aggravated at Longino and eventually began strangling him with an unknown object from his position in the seat directly behind Longino.Â  Once Longino was rendered unconscious, Scott ordered Adams and Johnson to help him move the victim into the front passenger seat.Â  He instructed Adams to drive as he and Johnson returned to the back seat.Â  Johnson testified that shortly thereafter Scott suddenly pulled out a large kitchen knife and, reaching around from the back seat, stabbed Longino in the chest.
According to Johnson, Scott then directed Adams to drive to a nearby park, where Scott and Adams placed Longinoâ€™s body in a dumpster. Afterward, Scott returned to his apartment.Â  Adams and Johnson drove Longinoâ€™s car to Adamsâ€™ apartment and smoked crack until Johnson reported to work the following morning.Â  
On February 15, Greenville police received a call reporting a parked car at a local apartment complex that appeared to have a bloodstained interior.Â  Officers located the vehicle and checked the suspected driverâ€™s apartment.Â  In the apartment, officers found Adams, who claimed he borrowed the car from Longino and explained the blood stains as the result of an unfortunate nosebleed.Â  Adams admitted to partially cleaning out the car and revealed the location of his bloodstained clothing.Â  He was arrested for an outstanding warrant and the car was impounded.Â  Police verified that the car belonged to
Longino.
The police then attempted to locate Longino at his apartment to verify Adamsâ€™ nosebleed claim.Â  At Longinoâ€™s apartment, officers encountered Scott for the first time.Â  Scott had a large knife stuck in the back of his belt, which was taken by the police.Â  He claimed he hadnâ€™t seen Longino in days, but acted nervous around the investigating officers. Â After Scott refused to consent to a search of his apartment, the officers returned the knife and left the residence.
At approximately 11:30 p.m. that night, the Greenville City Police received a call from county authorities reporting that a body was found in a dumpster at a local park.Â  The body was identified as Longino.Â  Injuries to the body confirmed he was strangled and stabbed once in the chest.
Officers then interrogated Adams a second time regarding the events of February 14.Â  At this point, Adams submitted a written statement claiming Scott strangled and stabbed Longino and the group then helped him hide the body in the park dumpster.Â  Pursuant to Adamsâ€™ revised statement, an arrest warrants was issued for Scott.Â  Through an anonymous tip, Scott was located hiding under a bed at his girlfriendâ€™s apartment, the large knife still in his possession.Â  After his arrest, Scott refused to answer questions concerning the death of his roommate.Â  On February 18, Johnson turned himself in to police after seeing a story about the murder on the local news.Â  Johnson then submitted a written statement consistent with Adamsâ€™ recollection of Longinoâ€™s death.
Scott, Adams, and Johnson were indicted for Longinoâ€™s murder.Â  In 1992, the charges against Scott were dismissed, presumably due to an issue concerning the location of witnesses.Â  In 1996, however, Scott was re-indicted for murder and tried before a jury.Â  Scottâ€™s trial took place prior to any prosecution of Adams or Johnson regarding Longinoâ€™s death.
As previously stated, the State relied heavily on Adamsâ€™ and Johnsonâ€™s testimony concerning the events in question.Â  Adamsâ€™ trial testimony regarding Longinoâ€™s murder was consistent with that of Johnson, reviewed above.Â  Particularly germane to this appeal, Adams testified he returned to the car from the gas station pay phone to find Scott strangling Longino with what appeared to be a piece of rope.Â  Adams also testified he witnessed Scott stab Longino from the rear seat.Â  The jury found Scott guilty of murder and he was sentenced to life imprisonment.Â  Adams eventually pled guilty to obstruction of justice and received a seven year sentence with credit for time served.
In 2000, Scott retained counsel and initiated a post conviction relief action (PCR).Â  Scottâ€™s PCR counsel filed a Freedom of Information Act request with the 13th Circuit Solicitorâ€™s Office seeking all information in any way related to the death of Longino.Â  After an extended, often heated, exchange of phone calls and letters between Scottâ€™s counsel and the solicitorâ€™s office, the requested documents were eventually turned over.Â  
Included in these documents was a certified written statement signed by Adams entitled â€œNotice of Intended Pleaâ€ and dated May 20, 1994.Â  In this document, Adams avers the following:

3. Defendant [Adams] was, consistent with prior statement(s), talking on the telephone in the area of the crime having no knowledge of the act until he entered the vehicle in which he was a passenger, finding the body of the victim.
4. Relative to the actual perpetrator of the crime, Defendant could only speculate as to whom the actual perpetrator was as he (Defendant) did not witness the act.
. . . . 
6. Defendant freely admits that he drove the car belonging to the victim, that he was merely present during the commission of the crime, with that presence being out of sight of the crime and without the knowledge of the act being in progress.

The signed â€œverification/certification of serviceâ€ block to this document reads â€œI have placed the original and one copy of this document in the U.S. Mail at the Lee Correctional Institution at Bishopville, SC, addressed to the; CLERK OF COURT, GREENVILLE COUNTY COURT HOUSE, GREENVILLE, SC: OFFICE OF THE SOLICITOR, GREENVILLE COUNTY, GREENVILLE, SC.â€ (emphasis in original)
This document was not provided to Scott pursuant to his Rule 5, SCRCrimP, and Brady motions prior to his murder trial.Â  According to Scottâ€™s former PCR counsel, the document was present in the Greenville County Clerk of Courtâ€™s Office in Adamsâ€™ file numbered 98-GS-23-2330, which is the enumeration for Adamsâ€™ obstruction of justice case.Â  Although the document also relates to Adamsâ€™ murder charge and is numbered accordingly (92-GS-23-7889), Scottâ€™s former PCR counsel stated in writing that the document was not present in Adamsâ€™ murder charge case file when she searched it in January 2000.
Scott filed a Rule 29(b), SCRCrimP, motion for a new trial in the circuit court, arguing that the Stateâ€™s withholding of this document violated his due process rights by failing to comply with Rule 5, SCRCrimP, and the mandates of Brady v. Maryland, 373 U.S. 83 (1963).Â  The circuit court denied the motion, concluding the document, filed with clerk of court, was a matter of public record; thus, available to a diligent defendant and not within the scope of a Brady motion.
DISCUSSION
Scott argues the circuit court erred in denying his motion for a new trial because the Stateâ€™s failure to provide Adamsâ€™ sworn statement to the defense violated his due process rights by failing to comply with Rule 5, SCRCrimP, and the mandates of Brady v. Maryland, 373 U.S. 83 (1963).[1]Â  We disagree.
It is a violation of a defendantâ€™s due process rights for the prosecution to withhold evidence favorable to the defendant.Â  Brady, 373 U.S. at 87.Â  The prosecutionâ€™s obligation to turn over evidence favorable to the defense applies to both exculpatory and impeachment evidence.Â  Gibson v. State, 334 S.C. 515, 524, 514 S.E.2d 320, 324 (1999). However, in Anderson v. Leeke, 271 S.C. 435, 438, 248 S.E.2d 120, 122 (1978), our supreme court held that the Brady rule â€œapplies only to favorable evidence which the prosecution has but which is unavailable to the defendant.â€Â  Accordingly, matters of public record available to a diligent defendant do not fall within the scope of a Brady motion.Â  Id.; see also State v. Allen, 276 S.C. 412, 414, 279 S.E.2d 365, 366 (1981); State v. Penland, 275 S.C. 537, 540, 273 S.E.2d 765, 766-67 (1981);Â  State v. Cox; 274 S.C. 624, 629, 266 S.E.2d 784, 787 (1980).
In the present case, Adamsâ€™ statement was filed with both the prosecution and the Greenville County Clerk of Court prior to Scottâ€™s trial.Â  Court filings are a matter of public record; thus, were available to Scott and his counsel through due diligence.Â  Accordingly, the document does not fall within the Brady rule.
Furthermore, a Brady claim is valid only if the accused can demonstrate the evidence was material to guilt or punishment.Â  Gibson, 334 S.C. at 525, 514 S.E.2d at 324.Â  When a defendant files a general Brady request, as Scott did in the present case, â€œfavorable evidence is material, and constitutional error results from its suppression by the government, [only] if there is a reasonable probability that, had the evidence been disclosed to the defense, the result of the proceeding would have been different.â€Â  Id. at 525, 514 S.E.2d at 325 (quoting Kyles v. Whitley, 514 U.S. 419, 432-36 (1995)).Â  â€œA reasonable probability of a different result is . . . shown when the Governmentâ€™s evidentiary suppression undermines confidence in the outcome of trial.â€ Id.  
Here, the evidence in question merely attacks the credibility of a witness whose varying versions of the events surrounding the victimâ€™s murder were made apparent to the jury at trial.Â  Moreover, Adamsâ€™ statement contradicting his trial testimony does nothing to refute the testimony of the Stateâ€™s star witness, Johnson, who was seated next to Scott during both the strangling and stabbing of Longino.Â  We conclude, after thorough review of the record on appeal, that had Adamsâ€™ contradictory written statement been presented at trial, Scottâ€™s jury would have reached an identical result.Â  While we are troubled by the prosecutionâ€™s failure to disclose Adamsâ€™ statement, we do not feel it undermines confidence in the outcome of Scottâ€™s trial in light of Johnsonâ€™s testimony.Â  See Porter v. State, __ S.C. __, 629 S.E.2d 353, 357 (2006) (holding impeachment evidence was not material to guilt or punishment when the failure to disclose did not undermine confidence in the outcome of defendantâ€™s trial).Â  
In reaching this conclusion, we are aware of the recent South Carolina Supreme Courtâ€™s opinion in Riddle v. Ozmint, __ S.C. __, __ S.E.2d __, 2006 WL 1389541 (2006), reemphasizing the consequential nature of the Stateâ€™s Brady obligation and the grave impact on justice when the prosecution fails to comply.Â  However, given the facts of the present case, namely Johnsonâ€™s consistent testimony and the thorough impeachment of Adams at Scottâ€™s trial, we find Scottâ€™s appeal comports much more soundly with factual scenario in Porter.
The circuit courtâ€™s denial of Scottâ€™s motion for a new trial is therefore
 AFFIRMED.
KITTREDGE, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur. 

[1] Scott also argues that these documents prove Adams was offered leniency in exchange for his testimony in Scottâ€™s trial, an assertion which further belies Adamsâ€™ trial testimony.Â  Although the documents do reference attempts by the prosecution to illicit a guilty plea from Adams, they do not reflect that Adams was offered leniency for his testimony against Scott.

title: SCDSS v. McKinley
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
SCDSS, Respondent,
v.
Wanda McKinley, Jeffrey McKinley and Robert Chappell (deceased), Defendants, of whom Wanda McKinley is the,
Appellant.
In the interest of:Â  
Travis Tabias Martin, DOB: 7/10/90
Antrai Lama Martin, DOB: 11/12/92
Doris Virginia Martin, DOB 5/2/94
Jeffrey Benjamin McKinley, DOB: 11/24/00
Sallie Amanda McKinley, DOB 10/8/98
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â R. Kinard Johnson, Jr., Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-286
Submitted June 1, 2006 â€“ Filed June 19, 2006Â Â Â 

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Jeffrey Falkner Wilkes, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Danielle Metoyer Mitchell, of Greenville, for Respondent.
Ann Shipman Miner, for Guardian Ad Litem.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â This is an appeal from a termination of parental rights (TPR) action.Â  DSS sought to terminate Motherâ€™s parental rights on several grounds based on Motherâ€™s drug use, as evidenced by positive drug test results.Â  Mother argues the drug tests were unreliable; therefore, the South Carolina Department of Social Services (DSS) did not prove the grounds for termination by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Mother also contends TPR is not in the childrenâ€™s best interests.Â  We reverse and remand.[1]Â Â  Â Â 
FACTS
On May 14, 2002, DSS removed Motherâ€™s five children from her custody. Â After a merits hearing on October 22, 2002, the family court made a finding of threat of harm of physical abuse and a threat of physical neglect by Mother as to all of the children.Â  The family court also adopted and incorporated the treatment plan DSS formulated for Mother, which required her to submit to random hair strand drug tests, discontinue her use of illegal drugs and alcohol, and secure and maintain appropriate housing.Â  
On October 13, 2004, DSS initiated the current termination of parental rights action, alleging sections 20-15-1572(1), (2), (6), and (8) as grounds for termination.Â  A hearing was held on March 31, 2005. The parties stipulated to the fact the children had been in DSS custody for the past fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months. Â DSS presented evidence that Mother had a long history of drug abuse dating back to the mid 1990â€™s and had participated in inpatient and outpatient drug treatment programs, but had relapsed each time.Â  DSS proffered drug screen results showing Mother tested positive for cocaine eleven times since the children entered foster care and had tested positive as recently as October 2004.Â  Additionally, all of the DSS case workers and the guardian ad litem testified TPR was in the childrenâ€™s best interests.Â  
Mother presented evidence that she made great strides educationally and vocationally while the children were in foster care.Â  Mother successfully completed a program at Greenville Technical College and was working at Greenville Memorial Hospital as a unit secretary.Â  Mother was taking additional classes at Greenville Technical College so that she could be certified as a medical assistant and receive a significant pay raise.Â  She also had a part-time job cleaning the vice president and professorsâ€™ offices at Greenville Technical College, and she was entrusted with a key to the building.Â  In regard to housing, Mother lived in a one bedroom apartment and made arrangements to move into a larger one if she regained custody of her children.Â  She also visited with the children and paid child support on a regular basis.Â  
Mother admitted to using illegal drugs in the past but asserted that she had been drug free since July 21, 2003. Â Mother argued the drug tests were unreliable because the results of her drug screens were inconsistent.Â  Jenkins, the only witness who testified for DSS regarding the test results administered under DSS supervision, stated that the test result patterns were odd and sometimes conflicted with one another.Â  Additionally, Motherâ€™s case manager at Share Homeless Services[2], Melinda Seigler, testified Mother was required to undergo regular urine drug screens as a prerequisite for participating in the program.Â  Seigler stated Mother underwent testing at least once every other week and had not tested positive since she entered the program in February 2004.Â  Steigler also noted after Mother tested positive for cocaine in a DSS administered test in July 2004, Share required Mother to undergo a hair strand drug test at its expense, and she tested negative.Â  
Sharon Wilson also testified on Motherâ€™s behalf.Â  Wilson met Mother through her work with an outreach ministry organization, and had become very close to her.Â  Wilson testified that she does not believe Mother is currently using drugs or alcohol, that Mother attends church on a regular basis, and that she believed Mother would do what she â€œwas supposed to doâ€ if the children were returned to her.Â  She also stated that Mother joined the ministry and was working with abused women.Â  
Although the family court commended Motherâ€™s progress, it found that clear and convincing evidence existed to terminate Motherâ€™s parental rights on all four grounds.Â  Mother made a motion to alter or amend the judgment, and the family court denied the motion.Â  This appeal follows. Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In a termination of parental rights case, the best interests of the children are the paramount consideration. Â South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs v. Smith, 343 S.C. 129, 133, 538 S.E.2d 285, 287 (Ct. App. 2000). Grounds for TPR must be proved by clear and convincing evidence. Â Hooper v. Rockwell, 334 S.C. 281, 297, 513 S.E.2d 358, 366 (1999).Â  Furthermore, this Court may make its own conclusions of whether DSS proved by clear and convincing evidence that parental rights should be terminated. Â South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cochran, 364 S.C. 621, 626, 614 S.E.2d 642, 645 (2005).

  LAW/ANALYSIS
1.     Grounds for Termination of Parental Rights 
Mother argues the trial court erred in granting TPR because DSS failed to prove the statutory grounds.Â  Mother asserts the family court terminated her parental rights based on DSSâ€™s allegation that she continued to use drugs, which DSS failed to prove by clear and convincing evidence.Â  We agree. 
The termination of parental rights is governed by section 20-7-1572 of the South Carolina Code Annotated (Supp. 2005).Â  Pursuant to that section, parental rights may be terminated upon a showing of one or more enumerated grounds and a finding the termination is in the best interests of the child.Â  Here, the family court found the following statutory grounds applied to Mother and her children:

(1) The child or another child in the home has been harmed as defined in Section 20‑7‑490, and because of the severity or repetition of the abuse or neglect, it is not reasonably likely that the home can be made safe within twelve months.Â  In determining the likelihood that the home can be made safe, the parentâ€™s previous abuse or neglect of the child or another child in the home may be considered; 
(2) The child has been removed from the parent pursuant to Section 20‑7‑610 or Section 20‑7‑736, has been out of the home for a period of six months following the adoption of a placement plan by court order or by agreement between the department and the parent, and the parent has not remedied the conditions which caused the removal; 
(6) The parent has a diagnosable condition unlikely to change within a reasonable time including, but not limited to, alcohol or drug addiction, mental deficiency, mental illness, or extreme physical incapacity, and the condition makes the parent unlikely to provide minimally acceptable care of the child. It is presumed that the parentâ€™s condition is unlikely to change within a reasonable time upon proof that the parent has been required by the department or the family court to participate in a treatment program for alcohol or drug addiction, and the parent has failed two or more times to complete the program successfully or has refused at two or more separate meetings with the department to participate in a treatment program; 

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (Supp. 2005).
Other than the evidence DSS presented to show Mother continues to use illegal drugs, the record shows Mother did everything possible to better herself and her living conditions to regain custody of her children.Â  Mother acquired adequate and stable living conditions for the children, secured two jobs in order to support the children, and completed a treatment program for drug addiction.Â  Therefore, it appears the family court relied on Motherâ€™s alleged drug use to terminate her parental rights.Â  Our review of the record indicates the conflicting and unexplainable results of the drug tests were insufficient to establish Mother was using drugs.Â  DSSâ€™s own witness, Jenkins, the representative from the drug screening facility that performed the tests, could not explain the results and was â€œbaffledâ€ by the inconsistency in the drug screens.Â  Moreover, independent tests conducted through the Share program showed Mother tested negative for drugs.Â  Absent clear and convincing evidence Mother was using drugs, the state failed to carry its burden in proving the grounds for TPR under Â§ 20-7-1572(1)(2) and (6).Â  
Under section 20-7-1572(1), DSS is required to prove the children were harmed as defined in Section 20‑7‑490, and because of the severity or repetition of the abuse or neglect, it is not reasonably likely that the home can be made safe within twelve months.Â  Additionally, section 20-7-1572(2) requires DSS to show that Mother failed to remedy the conditions which caused the childrenâ€™s removal.Â  The cause for the childrenâ€™s removal from Motherâ€™s custody was that she was abusing drugs and had physically neglected the children.Â  As discussed above, DSS did not prove Mother was still using drugs, and Mother had acquired adequate housing prior to the trial.Â  Mother made arrangements to move into a larger apartment if the children were returned to her. Mother also had plans to buy a house through Shareâ€™s home buying program, and Steigler, Shareâ€™s representative, testified that Mother would begin the home buying process within the next month. Â Mother improved her education and was working two jobs where she enjoyed positions of trust. Therefore, we find DSS failed to prove it was not reasonably likely Motherâ€™s home could be made safe within twelve months or that Mother did not remedy the conditions which caused removal. Â Â Â 
Furthermore, although it is undisputed Mother has a diagnosable condition under section 20-7-1572(6), DSS did not prove the condition makes the Mother unlikely to provide minimally acceptable care of the children or that Motherâ€™s condition is unlikely to change within a reasonable time. The suspect nature of the drug test results coupled with Motherâ€™s completion of a drug treatment program and obvious advancement in obtaining education, employment and housing indicates Mother has the ability and inclination to provide acceptable care for the children.
Mother next argues the trial court erred in terminating her parental rights on the ground that the children had been in foster care under the responsibility of the State for fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(8) (Supp. 2005).Â  Mother argues termination on this ground absent a showing she was at fault for DSSâ€™s refusal to return the children violates her due process rights.Â  Mother raised this issue for the first time in a Rule 59(e) motion; therefore, we find this issue is not preserved for our review. See Patterson v. Reid, 318 S.C. 183, 185, 456 S.E.2d 436, 437 (Ct. App. 1995) (holding a party may not use a post-trial motion to raise an issue that could have been raised at trial). At trial, Mother stipulated that the children had been in foster care for fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months; therefore, we affirm the family courtâ€™s finding that this ground for termination exists.Â  This ground alone, coupled with a finding termination is in the childâ€™s best interests is sufficient to grant TPR.Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Sims, 359 S.C. 601, 608, 598 S.E.2d 303, 307 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  However, we decline to terminate Motherâ€™s parental rights because we do not find termination is in the childrenâ€™s best interests.
2.     Best Interests 
Mother argues TPR is not in the childrensâ€™ best interests.Â  We agree.[3]  
After finding one of the grounds for termination exists, section 20-7-1572 requires a determination that the termination is in the best interests of the child.Â  (â€œThe family court may order the termination of parental rights upon a finding of one or more of the following grounds and a finding that termination is in the best interest of the child. . .â€). Â Our supreme court has recognized â€œthe termination of parental rights to be one of most severe actions a state can take against its citizens.â€Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cochran, 364 S.C. 621, 626, 614 S.E.2d 642, 645 (2005).Â  In cases involving the termination of parental rights, the court must balance two often competing interests, those of the parent and those of the child.Â  Id.Â  â€œIn balancing these interests, the best interest of the child is paramount to that of the parent.â€Â  Id. at 626-27, 614 S.E.2d at 645.
The fundamental purpose of terminating parental rights is to provide the greatest possible protection for a child whose parents are unwilling or unable to provide adequate care for the physical and emotional needs of the child and to protect the health and welfare of these children and make them eligible for adoption by persons who will provide a suitable home environment and the love and care necessary for a happy, healthful, and productive life.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1560 (Supp. 2005); Cochran, 364 S.C. at 632, 614 S.E.2d at 648.Â  
We are cognizant that a child has a â€œfundamental interest in terminating parental rights if the parent-child relationship inhibits establishing secure, stable, and continuous relationships found in a home with proper parental care.â€Â  Cochran, 364 S.C. at 626, 614 S.E.2d at 645.Â  However, our review of the record does not indicate that the parent-child relationship in the instant case inhibits establishing a proper home for the children.Â  Â Â 
The record indicates the caseworkersâ€™ testimony that TPR is in the childrenâ€™s best interests was based on Motherâ€™s positive drug screens and her previous problems with drugs.Â  Teresa Jeter, a caseworker who worked directly with Mother, testified that DSS was going to return the children to Mother at one point, but decided against reunification after Mother tested positive for cocaine.Â  Another caseworker, Chrisite Chalmers, testified TPR was in the childrenâ€™s best interest because there was no â€œ100 percent proofâ€ Mother would not relapse again.Â  
The guardian ad litem, who also testified that TPR was in the childrenâ€™s best interests, testified she derived her recommendation only from the drug screens and Motherâ€™s single statement that the children did not need counseling.Â  In her report, the guardian asserted that Mother â€œseems to genuinely want to regain custody of her children and has shown exemplary improvement in changing her life around and becoming self sufficient with the exception of the positive drug screens.â€Â  The caseworkersâ€™ and the guardian ad litemâ€™s recommendation that TPR is in the childrenâ€™s best interest was based on Motherâ€™s positive drug screens and her previous problems with drugs. Therefore, we weigh the caseworkersâ€™ and guardianâ€™s recommendation in accordance with our finding the drug evidence in this case was unreliable.Â  
Instead, we give deference to the testimony, by DSS caseworkers, the guardian, and Motherâ€™s witness demonstrating reunification is in the childrenâ€™s best interests.Â  The caseworkersâ€™ and the guardian testified Mother visits with the children at every opportunity and pays child support.Â  Additionally, a DSS caseworker testified that Mother had to intervene to help the foster parent when one of Motherâ€™s special needs children had severe behavioral episodes, and Motherâ€™s intervention had positive results.Â  This testimony indicates TPR would not be in the childâ€™s best interest.Â  Moreover, Mother made laudable efforts in turning her life around so that she could provide a secure and stable home for the children.Â  Seigler, who worked with Mother as part of the Share program and who had seen Mother once a week for over a year, testified that Mother is â€œvery much ready, willing, and able to take her children back and is eager to have them back in the home with her.â€Â  (R.81)Â  Seigler also opined that Mother has never given any indication that she is on the verge of relapsing.Â  Additionally, Wilson, who met Mother through an outreach program, stated that she did not believe Mother was using drugs, and she thought Mother would be a â€œgood Momâ€ if the children were returned to her.Â  
Based on these facts, we find terminating Motherâ€™s parental rights would not be in the childrenâ€™s best interests because the fundamental purpose of the TPR statue is not met.Â  There is no need to free the children for adoption and force them to wait in foster care for a suitable adoptive placement, considering they are bonded with their natural mother who is willing and able to provide adequate care for their physical and emotional needs and is capable of providing a suitable home environment.Â  We reverse the family courtâ€™s decision to grant TPR and remand the case so that the family court can formulate a permanent plan for reunification.Â  Accordingly, the order of the family court is
REVERSED and REMANDED.
KITTREDGE, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Share Homeless Services is an independent program that assists individuals in acquiring housing and by providing supportive services.Â  Share helped Mother acquire her education, job, and housing.Â  
[3] Â Because we reverse on this issue, we decline to address Motherâ€™s remaining arguments.Â  Rule 220(c), SCACR; see also Whiteside v. Cherokee County School Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 341, 428 S.E.2d 886, 889 (1993) (holding an appellate court need not address remaining issues when the resolution of a prior issue is dispositive).

title: Geiger v. Funderburk
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Eartha M. Geiger, Appellant,
v.
M. Stewart Funderburk and Orangeburg Surgical Associates, P.A., Defendants, Of whom Orangeburg Surgical Associates, P.A. is the
Respondent,
      
    
  


Appeal From Orangeburg County
Â Diane Schafer Goodstein, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-287
Heard May 9, 2006 â€“ Filed June 20, 2006

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Charles L. Henshaw, Jr. and Charles J. Bridgmon, both of Columbia, for Appellant.
Andrew F. Lindemann, of Columbia and Marian W. Scalise, of Myrtle Beach, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:  Eartha Geiger appeals the circuit courtâ€™s decision to grant Orangeburg Surgical Associatesâ€™ motion to dismiss or in the alternative to quash service of process.Â  We reverse.Â Â Â  
FACTS
On February 25, 1999, Geiger underwent a procedure to have her gallbladder removed by Dr. M. Stewart Funderburk of Orangeburg Surgical Associates, P.A.Â  Thereafter, Geiger commenced this action against Dr. Funderburk and Orangeburg Surgical, alleging Dr. Funderburk, as an agent or employee of Orangeburg Surgical, committed medical malpractice during the procedure to remove her gallbladder. 
Geiger filed her complaint with the clerk of court and enlisted Sylvander Blue, a private investigator and process server, to serve her summons and complaint on Dr. Funderburk and Orangeburg Surgical. Blue visited the address Orangeburg Surgical had filed with the Secretary of State as its registered office, and spoke with a secretary regarding service of the papers.Â  Blue informed the secretary that he needed to see Dr. Funderburk and Dr. Randolph Smoak.Â  Dr. Smoak was the individual listed on file with the Secretary of State as the registered agent for the corporation.Â  Dr. Smoak had ceased his employment with Orangeburg Surgical sometime prior to May of 2000, but his name remained on file as registered agent for the corporation.[1]Â  When the secretary informed Blue that neither of these men was present, Blue asked to speak with the office manager. 
Blue was led to the office of Elizabeth Arant, who described herself as the â€œpractice manager.â€Â  Blue informed Arant that he had papers for Dr. Smoak and Dr. Funderburk to sign and that the matter was urgent.Â  Arant signed for Dr. Funderburk as the â€œbusiness office manager,â€ but she refused to sign for Dr. Smoak, as registered agent for Orangeburg Surgical, because he was â€œnot employed by the practice.â€Â  Moreover, Dr. Babb, president of Orangeburg Surgical, was present during the time Arant spoke with Blue regarding service and specifically instructed her not to sign anything for Dr. Smoak.Â  Arant also stated that Dr. Babb refused to sign anything himself.Â  
Thereafter, Dr. Funderburk and Orangeburg Surgical filed answers to Geigerâ€™s complaint, and they moved jointly to dismiss or in the alternative to quash service of process, alleging service of process on them was not effected according to applicable statutes and rules.Â  On March 31, 2003, the circuit court found service of process on Dr. Funderburk to be effective, but found service of process on Dr. Smoak in his capacity as the registered agent for Orangeburg Surgical to be ineffective.Â  Consequently, the circuit court denied the motion as it pertained to Dr. Funderburk but granted the motion as it pertained to Orangeburg Surgical and dismissed the corporation from the suit.Â  No Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion was filed with the circuit court.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The circuit court determines questions of fact arising on a motion to quash service
of process for lack of jurisdiction over the defendant.Â  Brown v. Carolina Emergency Physicians, P.A., 348 S.C. 569, 583, 560 S.E.2d 624, 631 (Ct. App. 2001) (citing Lawson v. Jeter, 243 S.C. 103, 106, 132 S.E.2d 276, 277 (1963)).Â  â€œThe findings of the circuit court on such issues are binding on the appellate court unless wholly unsupported by the evidence or manifestly influenced or controlled by error of law.â€Â  Moore v. Simpson, 322 S.C. 518, 524, 473 S.E.2d 64, 67 (Ct. App. 1996).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Service of Process
Initially, Orangeburg Surgical asserts the circuit court never undertook an analysis of whether Arant was a managing agent capable of receiving process on behalf of the corporation, and therefore, this issue is not preserved for appeal.Â  We disagree. 
Issues and arguments are preserved for appellate review only when they are raised to and ruled on by the circuit court.Â  Elam v. South Carolina Dept. of Transp., 361 S.C. 9, 23, 602 S.E.2d 772, 779-80 (2004); see also Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).Â  No Rule 59(e) motion is required when a circuit court explicitly ruled on an argument raised.Â  Noisette v. Ismail, 304 S.C. 56, 58, 403 S.E.2d 122, 124 (1991).Â  
At the March 31, 2003 hearing, Geiger raised the issue of whether service of process on Arant as a â€œmanaging agentâ€ was effective as service on Orangeburg Surgical.Â  Geiger stated: 

I think the stronger argument, to be quite honest, is that we effected service over the corporation, and I think that itâ€™s a stronger argument for two reasons: number one, [Orangeburg Surgical] did not meet their responsibility to have a registered agent in that place of business for purposes of receiving this; and number two, the rule simply states that it needs to be a managing or general agent that has to be served with the process.Â  And so, the question does become whether or not Ms. Arant filled that role as managing or general agent on that day.â€ 

Additionally, the court, Geiger, and Orangeburg Surgical engaged in a lengthy colloquy pertaining to the case law relevant to Geigerâ€™s argument that Arant was the managing agent pursuant to Rule 4(d)(3).Â  Both Geiger and Orangeburg Surgical cited cases to the circuit court to support their respective arguments, and the court questioned the parties on this issue.Â  It is clear, therefore, that the issue of whether Arant was a managing agent under Rule 4(d)(3), SCRCP, was raised to the circuit court.
In the order, the circuit court explicitly cites Rule 4(d)(3), SCRCP, in its entirety.Â  Moreover, the court addressed the service issue as to Dr. Funderburk and Orangeburg Surgical separately.Â  In the section applicable to Orangeburg Surgical, the court made, as a finding of fact, the following conclusion:

In the present case, no officer, managing or general agent, or any other agent authorized by the corporation or by law to receive service of process was served with the summons and complaint.Â  

Additionally, the court, in rejecting Geigerâ€™s argument that service on Orangeburg Surgical was perfected when Arant accepted papers on behalf of Dr. Funderburk, found â€œthis argument to be contrary to Rule 4(d)(3)â€ and again quoted that rule in its entirety.Â  While the courtâ€™s ruling does not specifically find that Arant was not a managing agent under Rule 4(d)(3), the order is sufficiently explicit in its findings of facts and law to constitute a ruling on the managing agent issue as raised by Geiger.[2]Â  Therefore, we find this issue preserved for our review.Â  Â Â Â Â 
Turning to the merits, Geiger contends the circuit court erred in finding service was not properly effected on Orangeburg Surgical.Â  Geiger argues the service of process on a managing agent of the corporation was accomplished when Arant accepted and signed for the summons and complaint on behalf of Dr. Funderburk.Â  We agree.
Â â€œThe principal object of service of process is to give notice to the defendant corporation of the proceedings against it.â€Â  Burris Chem., Inc. v. Daniel Constr. Co., 251 S.C. 483, 487, 163 S.E.2d 618, 620 (1968).Â  The South Carolina Supreme Court does not require â€œexact complianceâ€ with the rules effecting service of process, but rather inquires whether the plaintiff has sufficiently complied with the rules such that the court has personal jurisdiction over the defendant and the defendant has notice of the proceedings.[3]Â  Roche v. Young Bros., Inc. of Florence, 318 S.C. 207, 209-10, 456 S.E.2d 897, 899 (1995).Â  
Rule 4(d)(3), SCRCP, delineates the requirements for effecting service of process upon a corporation as follows:

Upon a corporation . . . Â by delivering a copy of the summons and complaint to an officer, a managing or general agent, or to any other agent authorized by appointment or by law to receive service of process and if the agent is one authorized by statute to receive service and the statute so requires, by also mailing a copy to the defendant.

(emphasis added).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
The trial court found that service of Arant was not effective service of Orangeburg Surgical because â€œDr. Smoak was the authorized agent listed at the Secretary of Stateâ€™s Office, not Elizabeth Arant.â€Â  Use of this rationale to decide the effectiveness of service of process would constitute an error of law because service on a corporationâ€™s registered agent is not the only means by which service can be properly effected on the corporation.Â  See Renney v. Dobbs House, Inc., 275 S.C. 562, 565, 274 S.E.2d 290, 291 (1981) (holding that service of process upon an agent other than the registered agent is a proper method of service upon a corporation under South Carolina law).Â  Rule 4(d)(3), SCRCP, permits service of process on â€œa managing or general agentâ€ of the corporation.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â  
â€œNo case has been found in South Carolina defining â€˜managing agentâ€™ under Rule 4(d)(3), SCRCP.â€Â  Schenk v. Natâ€™l Health Care, Inc., 322 S.C. 316, 320, 471 S.E.2d 736, 738 (Ct. App. 1996), cert. denied (Dec. 5, 1996).Â  In Schenk, this court found an office manager to be a â€œmanaging agentâ€ under Rule 4(d)(3), and found that service on her in lieu of the retired and hence unavailable registered agent was effective.Â  Id.Â  Whether a particular agent is a managing agent of a corporation must depend upon the peculiar facts involved in each case.Â  71 A.L.R.2d 178 (2006).
Although Arant did not assure the process server that she was authorized to accept service as did the office manager in Schenk, she did accept service for Dr. Funderburk and signed for the summons and complaint as the â€œbusiness office manager.â€Â  Moreover, her duties with Orangeburg Surgical are sufficient for her to qualify as the managing agent of the corporation.Â  Arant managed and supervised the employees of the corporation except for the partners, was involved in the hiring and firing processes, wrote the employee handbook, was a member of several professional management groups, was a certified legal assistant, and stated that she would respond if someone requested to meet with the â€œoffice manager.â€Â  For these reasons, we find Arant to be a â€œmanaging agentâ€ as contemplated by Rule 4(d)(3). Service on Arant was effective service upon Orangeburg Surgical.Â  Â 
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the circuit courtâ€™s order is
 REVERSED AND REMANDED. [4]
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ., concur.

[1] From the date that Dr. Smoak left the practice to the date of service in this matter, which was almost two years, Orangeburg Surgical failed to comply with section 33-5-101 of the South Carolina Code (2006) which requires that a corporation continuously maintain a registered agent â€œwhose business office is identical with the registered office.â€ 
[2] Orangeburg Surgical argues Geiger conceded this issue was not preserved in her appellate brief.Â  In Geigerâ€™s brief, she admits the circuit court never determined â€œwhether a â€˜business office managerâ€™ is an officer, a managing or general agent, or another type of agent authorized by appointment or by law to receive service of process.â€Â  However, we are not bound by a partyâ€™s characterization of an issue when the record reflects differently.Â  See Rim Associates v. Blackwell, 359 S.C. 170, 177-78, 597 S.E.2d 152, 156 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œ[A]n appellate court is not bound by a partyâ€™s characterization of the actions.â€); Klippel v. Mid-Carolina Oil, Inc., 303 S.C. 127, 129, 399 S.E.2d 163, 164 (Ct. App. 1990); see also Ariail v. Ariail, 295 S.C. 486, 491, 369 S.E.2d 146, 149 (Ct. App. 1998).
[3] Importantly, it is evident that both Dr. Funderburk and Orangeburg Surgical had notice of the proceedings against them as evidenced by their timely filing of separate answers. 
[4] Because we reverse on this issue, we decline to address Geigerâ€™s remaining arguments.Â  See Whiteside v. Cherokee County School Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 428 S.E.2d 886 (1993) (holding an appellate court need not address remaining issues when the resolution of a prior issue is dispositive).

PER CURIAM: Â This appeal arises from the termination of Tina Garyâ€™s parental rights to her minor child, Faith.Â  The court based its decision on three grounds:Â  1) harm to the child from Garyâ€™s severe or repetitious neglect; 2) the parent has a diagnosable condition unlikely to change within a reasonable time; and 3) the child has been in DSS custody for 15 of 22 months.Â  See S.C. title: Waterford Place Homeowners Association of Lexington v. Barnes
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(D)(2), SCACR.  
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Waterford Place Homeowners Association of Lexington, Inc.,
Respondent,
v.
Richie D. Barnes, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Lexington County
Â Marc H. Westbrook, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-289
Submitted June 1, 2006 â€“ Filed June 21, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Richie D. Barnes, pro se, of Columbia; for Appellant.
Walter B. Todd, Jr., of Columbia; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Richie D. Barnes appeals the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in an action to foreclose his property for unpaid assessments.Â  We affirm. [1] Â Â 
FACTS
Waterford Place Homeownerâ€™s Association of Lexington, Inc. (Waterford) is a corporation that manages and maintains the planned unit development of Waterford Place.Â Â  Richie D. Barnes is the owner of a residential unit in Waterford Place.Â  Pursuant to the Declaration of Covenants, Conditions, and Restrictions of Waterford Place, each owner agrees to pay Waterford assessments to be determined by the association.Â Â Â  Failure to pay the assessment may result in interest accruing or a foreclosure action.Â  
Waterford brought this action to foreclose on its lien for unpaid assessments by Barnes.Â  Â Waterford claims Barnes failed to pay assessments representing Barnesâ€™ share of common expenses.Â  According to his own testimony, Barnes stopped paying the monthly assessments on June 3, 2002, and now owes $5,700.00 in unpaid assessments.Â  Barnes counterclaimed alleging breach of express warranty, negligence and fraud.Â  In essence, Barnes claimed he should not have to pay the assessments because Waterford was not maintaining the common areas, specifically those places around his property.Â  
After serving interrogatories on Barnes and finding his answers unsatisfactory, Waterford filed a motion to compel and a motion for summary judgment.Â  The trial court sympathized with Barnes, but found that he was nonetheless liable for the assessments.Â  The trial court granted Waterfordâ€™s motion for summary judgment as to Barnesâ€™ liability for foreclosure for unpaid assessments, granted Waterfordâ€™s motion for summary judgment without prejudice as to Barnesâ€™ counterclaims, and referred the matter to the master-in-equity for further proceedings as to the foreclosure.Â  The trial court went on to say that the appropriate action for Barnes would be to file an action seeking specific performance.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Barnes contends the trial court erred in granting summary judgment in an action to foreclose his property due to unpaid assessments.Â  We disagree.Â  
When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, appellate courts apply the same standard which governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP, which states that summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Helms Realty, Inc. v. Gibson-Wall Co., 363 S.C. 334, 340, 611 S.E.2d 485, 488 (2005).Â  On appeal from an order granting summary judgment, the appellate court will review all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence in a light most favorable to the non-moving party below.Â  Willis v. Wu, 362 S.C. 146, 150-51, 607 S.E.2d 63, 65 (2004); see also, Schmidt v. Courtney, 357 S.C. 310, 316-17, 592 S.E.2d 326, 330 (Ct. App. 2003) (stating all ambiguities,
conclusions, and inferences arising from the evidence must be construed most strongly against the moving party).
Summary judgment is not appropriate when further inquiry into the facts of the case is desirable to clarify the application of the law. Â Gadson v. Hembree, 364 S.C. 316, 320, 613 S.E.2d 533, 535 (2005); Montgomery v. CSX Transp., Inc., 362 S.C. 529, 542, 608 S.E.2d 440, 447 (Ct. App. 2004). Â Even when there is no dispute as to evidentiary facts, but only as to the conclusions or inferences to be drawn from them,
summary judgment should be denied. Â Nelson v. Charleston County Parks & Recreation Commâ€™n, 362 S.C. 1, 5, 605 S.E.2d 744, 746 (Ct. App. 2004). Â However, when plain, palpable, and indisputable facts exist on which reasonable minds cannot differ,
summary judgment should be granted.Â Â  Ellis v. Davidson, 358 S.C. 509, 518, 595 S.E.2d 817, 821 (Ct. App. 2004).
It is undisputed the Covenants of Waterford Place provide that each owner by acceptance of the deed agrees to pay the assessments and a failure to do so may result in a foreclosure.Â  Barnes readily admits he failed to pay the assessments since June 3, 2002.Â  The trial court was correct in concluding that regardless of Waterfordâ€™s failure to make repairs as required by the Covenants, Barnesâ€™ duty to pay remains.Â  His admitted failure to pay the assessments triggered the foreclosure provision of the Covenants.Â  As for Barnesâ€™ counterclaims, he does not make an argument in his brief concerning these issues.Â Â  We therefore, find it unnecessary to reach the merit of his counterclaims.Â  Â Â 
Barnes also argues that by granting summary judgment, the trial court violated his â€œconstitutional right to have trial by jury.â€Â  Barnes cites Rule 38(a), SCRCP, as the basis for his argument.Â  Though Rule 38(a) does provide for a trial by jury in certain cases, Rule 56, SCRCP, provides for summary judgment if there is no genuine issue of material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  In essence, Rule 56 allows for an efficient disposition of a case when there is no need for it to go to a jury.Â  Barnesâ€™ right to a jury trial was not violated by the granting of summary judgment.Â  To hold otherwise would mean that whenever a jury demand is made, summary judgment is no longer an option.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated herein, the trial courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED.Â  
SHORT, WILLIAMS, JJ., AND CURETON, A.J., CONCUR.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument, pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Jennie Wright Taylor, by and through Margaret Derrick, her Attorney in Fact, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Bank of America Corporation f/k/a The Citizens and Southern National Bank of South Carolina, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â Roger L. Couch , Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-290
Heard May 31, 2006 â€“ Filed June 22, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        William Stevens Brown, of Greenville, for Appellant.
        James C. Cothran, Jr., Robert M. Holland, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: In this breach of contract case, Bank of America Corporation (the Bank) appeals the trial courtâ€™s order, arguing the trial court erred in failing to hold the statute of limitations barred Derrickâ€™s claim and in shifting the burden of proof to the Bank.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On April 11, 1990, Taylor deposited $15,000.00 with the Citizens and Southern National Bank of South Carolina (C&S) through a certificate of deposit (the CD).Â  Every thirty days, the CD matures and automatically renews.Â  The CD contains several disclosures, one of which provides that the owner â€œwill want to keep [his or her] CD in a safe place, since receiving a replacement will require [the owner] to give [C&S] satisfactory proof of loss and/or security.â€Â  
In 1994, Derrick, Taylorâ€™s daughter, became Taylorâ€™s attorney-in-fact, in response to Taylorâ€™s erratic actions after the death of her husband.Â  In 1995, Taylor moved to a nursing facility.Â  By 1997, Derrick handled almost all of Taylorâ€™s financial transactions, including her federal income tax returns.Â  
In the meantime, C&S, through a series of mergers, became Bank of America.Â  In 2001, Derrick discovered the CD.Â  Derrick presented the CD to the Bank for redemption, and the Bank refused to pay, asserting it had no information on the account.Â  On February 18, 2002, Derrick filed a complaint alleging the Bank breached its contract with Taylor by refusing to pay pursuant to the terms of the CD.Â  The Bank answered, denying the allegations in the complaint, arguing the statute of limitations barred Derrickâ€™s cause of action, and asserting several other affirmative defenses.Â  
The trial court held a non-jury trial on August 24, 2004. Â Loubell Graham, the Bankâ€™s employee, testified that a microfiche printout produced from the Bankâ€™s corporate offices indicated the CD was â€œclosed outâ€ on December 7, 1990.[1]Â  She also testified that it was the Bankâ€™s practice to send monthly statements and annual tax documents to CD holders. Â Derrick testified she had not received any statements or tax documents regarding this CD.Â  Additionally, Graham explained that a customer could redeem a CD by presenting an affidavit stating the customer lost the CD and by posting a bond to protect the Bank against fraudulent redemptions.Â  The Bank could not produce an affidavit from Taylor showing the CD was redeemed, and Graham noted federal law only required the Bank to hold records, including such affidavits, for ten years after the CD closed.[2]Â  
The trial court held Derrick proved a debt, the Bank failed to prove payment of the debt, the statute of limitations did not bar Derrickâ€™s cause of action, and the Bank failed to establish any affirmative defenses.Â  The Bank made a motion to reconsider, which the trial court denied.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A breach of contract action seeking damages is an action at law.Â  Conway v. Charleston Lincoln Mercury, Inc., 363 S.C. 301, 305, 609 S.E.2d 838, 841 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  â€œWhen reviewing an action at law, on appeal of a case tried without a jury, the appellate courtâ€™s jurisdiction is limited to correction of errors at law.â€ Â Epworth Childrenâ€™s Home v. Beasley, 365 S.C. 157, 164, 616 S.E.2d 710, 714 (2005).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS

I. Statute of Limitations
The Bank contends the trial court erred in failing to apply the statute of limitations to bar Derrickâ€™s cause of action.Â  We disagree.
A plaintiff must bring a breach of contract action within three years of the breach.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-530(1) (Supp. 2005); see Maher v. Tietex Corp., 331 S.C. 371, 376, 500 S.E.2d 204, 207 (Ct. App. 1998) (â€œAn action for breach of contract must be brought within three years from the date the action accrues.â€).Â  The discovery rule determines the date of accrual for a breach of contract action. Santee Portland Cement Co. v. Daniel Intâ€™l Corp., 299 S.C. 269, 273, 384 S.E.2d 693, 695 (1989), overruled on other grounds by Atlas Food Sys. and Servs., Inc. v. Crane Natâ€™l Vendors Div., 319 S.C. 556, 462 S.E.2d 858 (1995).Â  â€œPursuant to the discovery rule, a breach of contract action accrues not on the date of the breach, but rather on the date the aggrieved party either discovered the breach, or could or should have discovered the breach through the exercise of reasonable diligence.â€ Â Maher, 331 S.C. at 376, 500 S.E.2d at 207.
Bank argues the contract was breached, if at all, when it â€œclosed outâ€ the account on December 7, 1990.Â  A bank employee testified Bankâ€™s current normal practice is to send bank statements and tax forms depicting interest earned for open accounts.Â  Bank maintains Taylor and Derrick had notice of the breach because they would not have received statements or tax forms after the Bank closed the account; therefore, they should have discovered the breach through the exercise of reasonable diligence.Â  
The trial court found the microfiche records the Bank presented to show it â€œclosed outâ€ the account on December 7, 1990, did not show that any specific action was taken on that date, but merely indicated that no activity was recorded on the account after that date.Â  The trial court noted that the CD renewed automatically, and the only other evidence demonstrated that Derrick had the original CD in her possession.Â  Therefore, the trial court found the breach occurred when Derrick attempted to redeem the CD in September 2001 and the Bank refused to make payment.Â  Because Derrick filed the suit five months later, the trial court found the statute of limitations did not bar the claim.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
According to our standard of review, the trial judgeâ€™s findings of fact are equivalent to a juryâ€™s finding in a law action, and the appellate court will not disturb the trial courtâ€™s findings of fact unless the findings are wholly unsupported by the evidence.Â  King v. PYA/Monarch, Inc., 317 S.C. 385, 388-89, 453 S.E.2d 885, 888 (1995); Gordon v. Colonial Ins. Co., 342 S.C. 152, 155, 536 S.E.2d 376, 378 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  The appellate court will not disturb the trial judgeâ€™s findings of fact that depend on the credibility of the witnesses.Â  Cherry v. Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 525, 280 S.E.2d 541, 542 (1981); see also Kiriakides v. Atlas Food Sys. & Servs., Inc., 343 S.C. 587, 594, 541 S.E.2d 257, 261 (2001) (â€œIt is not for the appellate court to weight the evidence.â€).Â  
Our review of the record indicates there is evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s findings.Â  Graham, the Bankâ€™s representative, testified regarding the microfiche records.Â  Graham stated she had no direct knowledge regarding the entry made on the microfiche, and that she was interpreting the microfiche codes using a key.Â  The microfiche record showed that the account history ended on December 7, 1990, and Graham opined the account was â€œclosed outâ€ on that date; however, the evidence did not conclusively show what action the Bank took on that date.Â  Additionally, even if the Bank closed the account in 1990, there was no evidence that Taylor or Derrick received notice.Â  Although Graham testified that the Bank routinely sends out statements and tax forms for CDs, there is no evidence in the case at bar that any such documents were ever provided to Taylor or Derrick.Â Â Â  
Accordingly, we find no error in the trial courtâ€™s finding that the statute of limitations clock for Derrickâ€™s claim began to run in September 2001 when she received notice of the Bankâ€™s breach of the contract.Â  Derrick filed the instant action in February 2002; therefore, the three year statute does not bar the claim.Â  
II. Burden of Proof
 The Bank argues the trial court erred in shifting the burden of proving payment of the CD to the Bank.Â  We disagree.
Payment is an affirmative defense that must be pled by the party asserting it.Â  Rule 8(c), SCRCP; First Serv. Corp. of S.C. v. Cape, 299 S.C. 147, 150, 382 S.E.2d 919, 921 (1989).Â  When a defendant asserts an affirmative defense, he becomes the actor in the suit as to that matter; therefore, he has the burden of proving it by a preponderance of the evidence.Â  Cole v. S.C. Electric and Gas, 355 S.C. 183, 195, 584 S.E.2d 405, 412 (Ct. App. 2003) (citation omitted).Â Â  Â 
It is clear from our review of the record that Bank was essentially asserting the affirmative defense of payment by arguing the CD was redeemed in 1990.Â  Although the trial court did not expressly mention the affirmative defense of payment in its order, the trial court implicitly applies the doctrine in reaching its decision.Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â 
In a breach of contract action the plaintiff must prove: (1) a binding contract entered into by the parties, (2) a breach or failure to perform the contract, and (3) damage suffered by the plaintiff as a direct and proximate result of the beach.Â  Fuller v. Eastern Fire & Cas. Ins. Co., 240 S.C. 75, 85, 124 S.E.2d 602, 610 (1962).Â  The trial court found Derrick made out a prima facie case for breach of contract.Â  Derrick had a valid contract as evidenced by the CD, which she had in her possession, the bank refused to perform its duty to pay when she presented the CD for redemption, and she lost over $15,000 as a result.Â  Once Derrick met the burden of proving each element of breach of contract, Bank had the burden of proving the affirmative defense that it paid the debt, and the Bankâ€™s only witness, Graham, testified that she had no information Derrick or Taylor ever received the funds from the CD. Â Therefore, we find no error in the trial courtâ€™s ruling requiring the Bank to prove payment as an affirmative defense.Â Â Â Â  Â Â 
CONCLUSION
We hold the trial court properly found the statute of limitations did not bar Derrickâ€™s cause of action.Â  Additionally, we hold the trial court correctly applied the burden of proof with respect to payment of the CD.Â  Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s order is 
AFFIRMED.
KITTREDGE, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Graham interpreted the microfiche using a list of codes the trial court would not admit into evidence.Â  
[2]Â  The Bank noted in its brief that Federal Regulations only require it to maintain records of closed CD accounts for five years.Â  See 31 CFR Â§ 103.38(d).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Cynthia Smith, Defendant, and Ruby Rice d/b/a R&R Bail Bonding, and Safety National Casualty Corporation, as Surety, of whom Ruby Rice d/b/a R&R Bail Bonding is Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-291
Submitted June 1, 2006 â€“ Filed June 22, 2006

AFFIRMED 


  
    
      
        David Lloyd Thomas, of Greenville, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General David Spencer, all of Columbia; Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Ruby Rice d/b/a/ R&R Bail Bonding (Rice) contends the circuit court erred in ordering a partial estreatment of Cynthia Smithâ€™s bond.Â  We affirm.[1] Â Â Â 
FACTS
In March 2001, Cynthia Smith was arrested for and charged with multiple counts of forgery.Â  Smith was released on a surety bond in the amount of $15,000 posted by Rice.Â  
On January 24, 2002, Rice was notified to have Smith appear in court on February 4, 2002; Smith failed to appear.Â  A bench warrant was issued for the arrest of Smith for her failure to appear in court.Â Â Â  
On February 19, 2003, a bond estreatment hearing was held.Â  Rice argued the bond should not be forfeited because Smithâ€™s disposition on the forgery charges was dismissed.Â  After a recess, the State informed the court the cases were still outstanding, and the disposition stating the cases were dismissed was based on an error by the clerkâ€™s office.Â  The circuit court ordered forfeiture for $10,000 of the $15,000 bond.Â  
Rice filed a Motion to Reconsider the Estreatment of Bonds on March 4, 2003, arguing the circuit court should reconsider its opinion because the charges against Smith were dismissed.Â  The circuit court denied Riceâ€™s motion.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Rice contends the circuit court erred in failing to consider the costs to the state in its determination of whether bond forfeiture should be remitted.Â  This issue is not preserved for our review. 
 â€œIn order for an issue to be preserved for appellate review, it must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge.â€ State v. Dunbar, 356 S.C. 138, 142, 587 S.E.2d 691, 693 (2003).Â  â€œIf the losing party has raised an issue in the lower court, but the court fails to rule upon it, the party must file a motion to alter or amend the judgment in order to preserve the issue for appellate review.â€Â  Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 422, 526 S.E.2d 716, 724 (2000).Â  In the absence of such a motion, the matter is not preserved and the appellate court cannot consider the argument on appeal.Noisette v. Ismail, 304 S.C. 56, 58, 403 S.E.2d 122, 124 (1991); see also Townsend v. City of Dillon, 326 S.C. 244, 247, 486 S.E.2d 95, 97 (1997).Â  Â Â Â Â 
The record reflects Rice made no argument that the court failed to consider costs to the state at the bond hearing or in her â€œMotion to Reconsider Estreatment of Bonds.â€Â  Therefore, we find the issue was not properly preserved for our review.Â  Â 
Accordingly, the order of the circuit court is 
AFFIRMED.Â  
SHORT, WILLIAMS, JJ., AND CURETON, A.J., CONCUR.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument, pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.Â
