title: Polson v. Johnson
text:
The South Carolina Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Ricky and Tammy Polson, Appellants,
v.
William and Wendy Johnson, Respondents.
      
    
  

The Honorable Jane D. Fender
Spartanburg County
Trial Court Case No.Â Â  2003-DR-41-03900

ORDER 

PER CURIAM:Â  On June 23, 2006, this court issued Opinion No. 2006-UP-292, which reversed the order of the family court and remanded the matter for further proceedings.Â  Respondent William Johnson has filed a petition for rehearing in this case.Â  Appellants Ricky and Tammy Polson have moved to expedite the docketing of the petition on the ground that one of the children will be starting school in August 2006 and this circumstance warrants a prompt resolution of the matter.Â  
We grant Appellantsâ€™ motion for expedited docketing of the petition for rehearing.Â  After careful consideration of the petition for rehearing, we order that Opinion No. 2006-UP-292, filed in this appeal on June 23, 2006, be withdrawn and the following opinion substituted therefore.Â  Notwithstanding this substitution, we have not discovered any material fact or principle of law that has been either overlooked or disregarded.Â  Because we find no basis to support a rehearing, we deny the petition.Â  
Pursuant to Rule 16, SCRFC, the family court has continuing jurisdiction to address further concerns from any party in this matter. 
AND IT IS SO ORDERED.

   
     
     
      _____Kaye G. Hearn,             
        C.J.
        
        _____C. Tolbert Goolsby,       
           J.
        
        _____Ralph King Anderson, Jr., J.
    
  

Columbia, South Carolina
Date:Â  ___July 26, 2006____
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Ricky and Tammy Polson, Appellants,
v.
William and Wendy Johnson, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â Jane D. Fender, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-292
Submitted June 1, 2006 â€“ Filed June 23, 2006
Withdrawn, Substituted and Refiled July 26, 2006

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
James Fletcher Thompson, of Spartanburg, for Appellants.
Philip W. Jamieson, of Rock Hill, Â for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Ricky and Tammy Polson (the Polsons) appeal the grant of custody of their two grandchildren to William Johnson.Â  We reverse and remand.[1]Â  
FACTS
Johnson married the Polsonsâ€™ daughter, Wendy, on October 31, 2001.Â  On November 7, 2001, Wendy gave birth to Hannah. 
The Polsons believed Hannahâ€™s biological father was Chad Edwards.Â  They advised Wendy to name Edwards as the father on Hannahâ€™s birth certificate; however, a health department employee informed the family the birth certificate had to name Johnson as the father because he and Wendy were legally married at the time of Hannahâ€™s birth.Â  Â Â 
Wendy and Hannah lived with the Polsons for several months after Hannah was born.Â  Apparently, this living arrangement came about so the Polsons could help with child care while both Wendy and Johnson were working.Â  During this time, Wendy would go home with Johnson on her days off and, at times, Johnson, with the Polsonsâ€™ consent, would stay at their home to be with Wendy.Â  In February 2002, Wendy and Hannah moved back to their home with Johnson.
On July 13, 2002, police were called to Johnsonâ€™s house and charged him with criminal domestic violence for striking Wendy.Â  After the incident, Wendy and Hannah went to live with the Polsons.Â  While they were staying with the Polsons, Johnson persuaded Wendy to drop the charges against him.Â  Wendy and Hannah returned to live with Johnson on December 29, 2002.
Wendy gave birth to a second child, Sarah, on August 17, 2003.[2]Â  Hannah and Sarah lived with Johnson and Wendy until November 7, 2003, when, after Hannahâ€™s second birthday party, Wendy and Johnson again became entangled in another altercation.Â  As a result of the incident, Wendy was charged with criminal domestic violence and taken to a hospital for a psychiatric evaluation.Â  While Wendy was away from the family for her evaluation, Johnson sent Sarah to live with his sister in Pennsylvania and sent Hannah to live with the Polsons. 
Approximately two weeks later, Wendy was released from the hospital and took Hannah from the Polsonsâ€™ home to live with her and Johnson.Â  Upon her return, Johnson informed Wendy that he was going to Pennsylvania to retrieve Sarah from his sister.Â  Wendy did not want Johnson to leave, and this dispute resulted in another physical incident between them. Â About a week after this incident, after Johnson informed the Polsons that Wendy was â€œacting up,â€ the Polsons brought Hannah to their home.Â  Shortly after Hannah went to live with the Polsons, Wendy also moved in with them.Â  
Sarah remained in Pennsylvania with Johnsonâ€™s sister while the Polsons commenced separate actions seeking custody of Hannah and Sarah.Â  By order dated January 9, 2004, the family court consolidated the actions under a single docket number and granted the Polsons temporary custody of both Hannah and Sarah. 
The final hearing took place July 19, 2004.Â  On August 25, 2004, the family court issued an order in which it found Johnson to be the father of both children.Â  Based on the investigation by the guardian ad litem, the court also found Johnson was a fit parent.Â  Noting Wendyâ€™s testimony that she was not capable of caring for the children and the absence of any showing that Johnson was an unfit parent, the court concluded the Polsons lacked standing to claim custody and it was in the best interests of Hannah and Sarah that they be placed in Johnsonâ€™s custody. 
The Polsons submitted post-trial motions under Rules 59(e) and 60 of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.Â  On December 6, 2004, the family court heard argument on the motions.Â  By order dated January 4, 2005, the family court made a finding that Johnson â€œis not the biological father of Hannah Lee Johnsonâ€ and granted Wendy, who was incarcerated at the time of the final hearing, visitation with the children â€œwhenever allowed by the jail and someone can take them there to see herâ€; however, the other provisions of the prior decision were left intact.Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court may find facts according to its own view of the preponderance of the evidence,[3] but â€œthis broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings.â€[4]Â  We need not, however, decide whether the evidence supports the family courtâ€™s findings of fact when these findings â€œare so tainted by
errors of law as to require us to reverse the courtâ€™s decision and remand the case for a new hearing.â€[5]
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  We agree with the Polsons that the family court erred in its application of the presumption of legitimacy to hold Johnson is Hannahâ€™s father because he and Tammy were married at the time of her birth. 
â€œThe presumption of legitimacy, although rebuttable, is one of the strongest known to the law.â€[6]Â  A child born in lawful wedlock is presumed to be legitimate; however, clear evidence that it was impossible for the husband to have been the father of the child can rebut this presumption.[7]
We agree with the Polsons that they presented clear evidence to rebut the presumption that Johnson is Hannahâ€™s father.Â  Ricky Polson testified at trial that Wendy was in a relationship with Chad Edwards at the time she became pregnant with Hannah and did not begin a relationship with Johnson until a later time.Â  Although Edwards never took a paternity test and died before the final hearing, the Polsons and Edwardsâ€™s mother testified to their belief that Edwards was Hannahâ€™s biological father.Â  Edwards was at the hospital when Hannah was born, and, even after his death, his family continued to acknowledge Hannah, visit her, and give her gifts.Â  Wendy herself told Tammy Polson Edwards was Hannahâ€™s father.Â  No one, including Johnson himself, offered any testimony to challenge these assertions. Â Moreover, the Polsons presented an e-mail Johnson had sent to them shortly after Hannahâ€™s birth in which he seemed to admit he was not Hannahâ€™s biological father and asserted he would never â€œfight forâ€ Hannah if he and Wendy ever separated as long as he did not have to pay child support for Hannah. 
2.Â  Based on the foregoing, we hold the family court, in determining who should have custody of Hannah, incorrectly required the Polsons to prove Johnson was an unfit parent.[8]Â  In determining who should be granted custody of Hannah, the family court should have based its determination on whether it was in Hannahâ€™s best interest to live with the Polsons or with Johnson rather than whether Johnson was a fit parent.[9]Â  In other words, the family court should have used a â€œbest interest of the childâ€ standard as between two third parties and not as between a parent and a third party.
3.Â  We also agree with the Polsons that, in determining who should receive custody of Sarah, the family court failed to apply the test the supreme court adopted in Moore v. Moore.[10]
In Moore, the supreme court acknowledged â€œa rebuttable presumption that it is in the best interest of any child to be in the custody of its biological parent.â€[11] Notwithstanding this presumption, however, the court recognized that â€œ[t]he best interest of the child is the primary and controlling consideration of the Court in all child custody controversies.â€[12]  
In balancing these two principles, the court stated that, at least with respect to parents who relinquish custody of their children to third parties and seek to regain custody at a later time, â€œ[t]he rebuttable presumption standard requires a case by case analysis.â€[13]Â  In addition, the court set forth the following criteria to be considered in custody determinations when a parent seek to reclaim custody from a third party:Â  (1) the parentâ€™s fitness and ability to care for the child and provide a good home; (2) the amount of contact, in the form of visits, financial support, or both, that the parent had with the child while the child was in the third partyâ€™s care; (3) the circumstances under which the parent relinquished custody; and (4) the degree of attachment between the child and the third-party custodian.[14]
The appealed order addresses only the first criterion, but fails to make findings of fact concerning the remaining three factors.Â  Given the compelling arguments by both sides as to the salient facts in the application of a Moore v. Moore analysis to this case and our consensus that the strengths of these arguments depend largely on credibility determinations, we decline to make our own findings regarding who should have custody of Sarah.Â  Accordingly, we reverse family courtâ€™s decision to grant custody of Sarah to Johnson and remand this issue to the family court.
CONCLUSION
We reverse the family courtâ€™s finding regarding Hannahâ€™s paternity and hold there was clear evidence to rebut the presumption that Johnson is her father.Â  Because this holding impacts the determination of who should receive custody of Hannah, we reverse the grant of custody of Hannah to Johnson and remand this issue to the family court.Â  On remand, the family court shall apply a â€œbest interest of the childâ€ standard in determining whether to grant custody of Hannah to Johnson or to the Polsons.Â  We also reverse the family courtâ€™s decision to award Johnson custody of Sarah and remand this issue for a Moore v. Moore analysis.
As a result of our reversal of the family courtâ€™s decisions regarding custody of Hannah and Sarah, temporary custody of both children will resume with the Polsons pursuant to the temporary order of January 9, 2004, and continue while the remand is pending.Â  
The Polsons raise several other issues for this court to consider on appeal, including newly discovered evidence concerning Johnsonâ€™s fitness as a parent and their request for visitation in the event that custody continues with Johnson.Â  Because of our disposition of the case, we do not address these issues.Â  On remand, however, the family court may consider any new evidence properly before it, including testimony concerning developments since the final merits hearing and the advisability of separating the children from each other.[15]
 REVERSED AND REMANDED.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] A paternity test has confirmed Johnson is Sarahâ€™s biological father.
[3]Â  Lanier v. Lanier, 364 S.C. 211, 215, 612 S.E.2d 456, 458 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  
[4]Â  Id.
[5]Â  Callen v. Callen, 365 S.C. 618, 623-24, 620 S.E.2d 59, 62 (2005).
[6]Â  Barrâ€™s Next of Kin v. Cherokee, Inc., 220 S.C. 447, 464, 68 S.E.2d 440, 447 (1951), superseded by statute for separate issue of law, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-956 (1985 and Supp. 2005).
[7]Â  Brown v. Ryder Truck Rental, 300 S.C. 530, 534, 389 S.E.2d 161, 163 (Ct. App. 1990).
[8]Â  See Kay v. Rowland, 285 S.C. 516, 517, 331 S.E.2d 781, 781-82 (1985) (stating there is a presumption that a natural parent, unless unfit, will prevail over a third party for custody of a child).Â  
[9]Â  During the hearing on the Polsonsâ€™ post-trial motions, an affidavit from the guardian ad litem was submitted in which he recounted that the family court in chambers, before the call of the case, instructed counsel that the custody decision would be based on Johnsonâ€™s fitness and not the â€œbest interest of the childâ€ standard and that he believed it is in the best interest of both children that they be placed with the Polsons.
[10] 300 S.C. 75, 386 S.E.2d 456 (1989).
[11] Id. at 79, 386 S.E.2d at 458. 
[12] Id. at 78-79, 386 S.E.2d at 458 (emphasis added).
[13] Id. at 80, 386 S.E.2d at 458.
[14] Id. at 80, 386 S.E.2d 458-59.
[15] See, e.g., Cole v. Cole, 274 S.C. 449, 454-55, 265 S.E.2d 669, 671 (1980) (â€œ[T]o punish all four children . . . by dividing custody [two older siblings with one parent and two younger siblings with the other parent] and removing the younger ones from their now accustomed environment . . . is no solution and contrary to the childrenâ€™s best interest, the paramount consideration.â€).

PER CURIAM: In January, 2003, Emory Michau, Jr., while incarcerated, filed a grievance against the South Carolina Department of Corrections.Â  Michau was unsatisfied with the result and filed an appeal with the South Carolina Administrative Law Judges Division.Â  The administrative law judge dismissed the appeal on October 28, 2003 due to Michauâ€™s failure to file a brief.Â  Michau filed a notice of appeal with the circuit court.Â  The circuit court judge required Michau to pay a filing fee or to move to proceed in forma pauperis.Â  Michau moved to proceed in forma pauperis, and the circuit court judge denied his motion on July 18, 2004.Â  Michau argues this denial was in error.Â  We disagree.
After reviewing the record on appeal, we find no error in the circuit courtâ€™s denial of Michauâ€™s motion to proceed in forma pauperis.Â  We base this decision on the following authorities: Ex parte Martin, 321 S.C. 533, 535, 471 S.E.2d 134, 135 (1995) (holding that absent a statutory waiver of filing fees, motions to proceed in forma pauperis may only be granted where specifically authorized by statute or required by constitutional provisions);Â  Sullivan v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Corrs., 355 S.C. 437, 446, 586 S.E.2d 124, 128 (2003) (holding that an inmate was not entitled to proceed in forma pauperis on his appeal from an Administrative Law Judgeâ€™s dismissal because there is no statutory provision allowing the waiver of filing fees for appeals brought under the Administrative Procedures Act).
AFFIRMED.[1]
Kittredge, Short, and Williams, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

        Cleveland Ridge Homeownerâ€™s Association, Inc., Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        State Farm Fire and Casualty Company and State Farm General Insurance Company, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-295
Submitted June 1, 2006 â€“ Filed June 26, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Joel F. Geer, of Greenville, for Appellant.
        Charles R. Norris, of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Cleveland Ridge Homeownerâ€™s Association (Cleveland Ridge) appeals the trial courtâ€™s order granting State Farm Fire and Casualty Company and State Farm General Insurance Companyâ€™s (collectively â€œState Farmâ€) motion for summary judgment.Â  We affirm.Â Â  
FACTS
Cleveland Ridge is the homeownerâ€™s association of a Greenville condominium complex and the named insured of a property and liability insurance policy with State Farm (Policy).Â  The Policy excludes loss caused by (1) â€œthe pressure or weight of . . . waterâ€; (2) â€œearth movement, meaning the sinking, rising, shifting, expanding or contracting of earth, all whether combined with water or notâ€; or (3) a â€œlatent defect or any quality in the property that causes it to damage or destroy itself.â€Â Â Â Â  Â 
On August 4, 2003, a concrete retaining wall behind the condominium complex failed after a heavy rain.Â  The next day, Cleveland Ridge reported the incident to State Farm, who sent an agent to examine the damage.Â  The agent informed Cleveland Ridge the Policy did not cover the retaining wall damage and, on August 21, 2003, denied the claim. Â Â 
Three months later, Cleveland Ridge, through legal counsel, advised State Farm of its opinion that the Policy covered the retaining wall damage. Â Â State Farm hired a structural engineer, Jack McCaskill, to inspect the retaining wall.Â  McCaskill determined the retaining wall â€œmost likely collapsed due to excessive water pressure,â€ which created a â€œhydrostatic force too large to be contained by the non-reinforced hollow masonry unit wall.â€Â  After the inspection, State Farm again denied Cleveland Ridgeâ€™s claim. 
In May 2004, Cleveland Ridge sued State Farm for breach of contract,Â  declaratory relief, violation of the South Carolina Unfair Trade Practices Act (SCUTPA), S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 39-5-10 to 560 (1976 & Supp. 2005), and bad faith for refusing to pay the claim.Â  State Farm answered and ultimately filed a motion for summary judgment, asserting the Policy excluded Cleveland Ridgeâ€™s claim, SCUTPA exempted unfair trade practices involving the insurance business, and State Farm did not act in bad faith because it had a reasonable basis to deny Cleveland Ridgeâ€™s claim.Â  In January 2005, the trial court granted State Farmâ€™s motion.Â  
In February 2005, Cleveland Ridge filed a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion, which the trial court denied.Â  The trial court found Cleveland Ridge did not comply with Rule 59(e), SCRCP, because Cleveland Ridge did not file its Rule 59(e) motion within ten days of its receipt of the trial courtâ€™s order.Â  The trial court also concluded Cleveland Ridge did not comply with Rule 59(g), SCRCP, because Cleveland Ridge did not provide the trial court with a copy of its Rule 59(e) motion within ten days after Cleveland Ridge filed it.Â  The trial court, however, denied Cleveland Ridgeâ€™s Rule 59(e) motion on the merits.Â  Cleveland Ridge appeals. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, the appellate court applies the same standard that governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  Pittman v. Grand Strand Entmâ€™t, Inc., 363 S.C. 531, 536, 611 S.E.2d 922, 925 (2005).Â  Summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Id.Â  On appeal, all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence must be viewed in a light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Id.Â  Once a defendant moving for summary judgment shows an absence of evidence to support the plaintiffâ€™s case, under Rule 59(e), SCRCP, the plaintiff must come forward with affidavits or other supporting documents setting forth specific facts that demonstrate the existence of a genuine issue for trial.Â  Montgomery v. CSX Transp., Inc., 362 S.C. 529, 542, 608 S.E.2d 440, 447 (Ct. App. 2004) (citing Doe v. Batson, 345 S.C. 316, 320, 548 S.E.2d 854, 856 (2001)).Â  â€œThe construction and enforcement of an unambiguous contract is a question of law for the court, and thus can be properly disposed of at summary judgment.â€Â  Hansen ex rel. Hansen v. United Servs. Auto. Assâ€™n, 350 S.C. 62, 67, 565 S.E.2d 114, 116 (Ct. App. 2002) (citing Middleborough Horizontal Prop. Regime Council of Co-Owners v. Montedison S.p.A., 320 S.C. 470, 477, 465 S.E.2d 765, 770 (Ct. App. 1995)).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
 Cleveland Ridge raises six issues on appeal; four relate to the trial courtâ€™s grant of State Farmâ€™s summary judgment motion and two relate to the trial courtâ€™s denial of Cleveland Ridgeâ€™s Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion. 
I.Â Â State Farmâ€™s Motion for Summary Judgment 
Cleveland Ridge argues the trial court erred in granting State Farmâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  We disagree.Â  
A.Â Â Ambiguity of the Policy 
Cleveland Ridge first asserts the Policy is ambiguous.Â  

  The foremost rule in interpreting an insurance contract is to give effect to the intent of the parties as shown by the language of the contract itself.Â  When the contract language is clear and unambiguous, the language alone determines the contractâ€™s force, and terms must be construed to give effect to their â€œplain, ordinary, and popular meaning.â€

Dorman v. Allstate Inc. Co., 332 S.C. 176, 178, 504 S.E.2d 127, 129 (Ct. App. 1998) (citing Gray v. State Farm Auto. Ins. Co., 327 S.C. 646, 650, 491 S.E.2d 272, 274 (Ct. App. 1997)).Â  The meaning of an insurance contract should not be tortured to allow for coverage that was not intended by the parties.Â  Torrington Co. v. Aetna Cas. & Sur. Co., 264 S.C. 636, 643, 216 S.E.2d 547, 550 (1975).Â  Thus, an unambiguous policy â€œmust be construed according to the terms the parties have used.â€Â  Century Indem. Co. v. Golden Hills Builders, Inc., 348 S.C. 559, 565, 561 S.E.2d 355, 358 (2002).Â  We find the Policy clearly and unambiguously excludes loss caused by (1) â€œthe pressure or weight of . . . waterâ€; (2) â€œearth movement, meaning the sinking, rising, shifting, expanding or contracting of earth, all whether combined with water or notâ€; or (3) a â€œlatent defect or any quality in the property that causes it to damage or destroy itself.â€Â  Accordingly, if any one of these three events caused the retaining wall loss, the Policy excludes it.Â  
B.Â Â Genuine Issues of Material Fact
Cleveland Ridge next asserts a genuine issue of material fact exists as to whether water pressure, earth movement, or a latent defect caused the retaining wall loss.Â  State Farm offered an affidavit from McCaskill, a structural engineer, who inspected the retaining wall in November 2003.Â  Based on this inspection, McCaskill attested that (1) â€œ[t]he retaining wall most likely collapsed due to excessive water pressureâ€; (2) â€œ[t]he water pressure and the movement of earth against the retaining wall caused it to failâ€; and (3) â€œthe retaining wall was defectively constructed and had a latent defect in that it contained no steel reinforcement and did not contain an adequate drainage system to allow ground water to be adequately drained away from behind the wall.â€Â  In response, Cleveland Ridge offered an affidavit from Richard Kapp, also an engineer.Â  Kapp attested â€œthat there are numerous possible causes for the retaining wall failure[,] [a]ny one of which could have been responsible alone for the failure or could have contributed jointly to the retaining wall failure.â€Â Â Â  
We find the trial court did not err in granting State Farmâ€™s motion for summary judgment because Kappâ€™s affidavit fails to set forth any specific facts showing a genuine issue for trial.Â  Rule 59(e), SCRCP; Russell v. Wachovia Bank, 353 S.C. 208, 220, 578 S.E.2d 329, 335 (2003) (citing Baughman v. Am. Tel. & Tel. Co., 306 S.C. 101, 115, 410 S.E.2d 537, 545 (1991)) (â€œWhen opposing a summary judgment motion, the nonmoving party must do more than â€˜simply show that there is a metaphysical doubt as to the material facts but must come forward with specific facts showing that there is a genuine issue for trial.â€™â€).Â  Although Kapp claims there are â€œnumerous possible causesâ€ for the retaining wall loss, he does not put forth what any of these â€œpossible causesâ€ might be.Â  He does suggest that these â€œpossible causesâ€ are something other than water pressure, earth movement, or a latent defect.Â  He is not even sure whether these â€œpossible causesâ€ most probably led to the retaining wall loss.Â  Consequently, as a matter of law, Kappâ€™s affidavit fails to show a genuine issue of material fact exists that water pressure, earth movement, or a latent defect did not cause the retaining wall loss.Â  
C.Â SCUTPA Claim 
Cleveland Ridge further asserts the trial court erred in granting State Farmâ€™s motion for summary judgment on Cleveland Ridgeâ€™s SCUTPA action.Â  Unfair trade practices involving the insurance business are regulated by the Insurance Trade Practices Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 38-57-10 to -320 (2002).Â  Section 39-5-40(c) of the South Carolina Code expressly exempts from the scope of SCUTPA unfair trade practices covered and regulated by the Insurance Trade Practices Act.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 39-5-40 (c) (Supp. 2005).Â  Thus, Cleveland Ridgeâ€™s claim is not covered by SCUTPA.
Cleveland Ridge, however, rationalizes SCUTPA does not exempt its cause of action because section 39-5-40(c) refers to Chapter 55, which concerns the conduct of insurance business, rather than Chapter 57, which is the Insurance Trade Practices Act.Â  Section 39-5-40(c) does, in fact, refer to Chapter 55 rather than Chapter 57, but such obstinate literality belies the legislative intent.Â  As the District Court of South Carolina observed, the Insurance Trade Practices Act, which was codified as Chapter 55, was recodified as Chapter 57 in 1987, and section 39-5-40(c) was not revised to reflect that change.Â  See Trs. of Grace Reformed Episcopal Church v. Charleston Ins. Co., 868 F. Supp. 128, 131 (D.S.C. 1994).Â  Clearly, the legislature intended SCUTPA to exempt cases of unfair trade practices regarding the insurance business because the Insurance Trade Practice Act specifically covers such cases.Â  See id. at 130-31 (â€œSCUTPA, through Â§ 39-5-40(c), provides a clear exemption for the practices covered by Chapter 57[;] [t]herefore, all unfair trade practices regarding the insurance business are regulated by the Insurance Trade Practices Act . . . and are exempt from the coverage of SCUTPA.â€).Â  Therefore, the trial court properly granted State Farmâ€™s motion for summary judgment on this cause of action.
D.Â Bad Faith Claim
Cleveland Ridge finally asserts the trial court erred in granting State Farmâ€™s motion for summary judgment on its bad faith cause of action.Â  Under South Carolina law, an insurer acts in bad faith when there is no reasonable basis to support the insurerâ€™s decision.Â  Cock-N-Bull Steak House, Inc. v. Generali Ins. Co., 321 S.C. 1, 6, 466 S.E.2d 727, 730 (1996); Crossley v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 307 S.C. 354, 360, 415 S.E.2d 393, 397 (1992).Â  Here, there is no evidence in the record to suggest State Farm unreasonably denied coverage for the retaining wall loss.Â  Thus, the trial court correctly granted State Farmâ€™s motion for summary judgment on this cause of action. 
II.Â Cleveland Ridgeâ€™s Rule 59(e) Motion
Finally, Cleveland Ridge argues the trial court erred in denying its Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion for failing to comply with the procedural requirements of Rule 59(e) and (g).Â  We disagree.Â  Although the trial court found Cleveland Ridge failed to comply with the procedures set forth by Rules 59(e) and (g), the trial court nevertheless addressed and rejected its Rule 59(e) motion on the merits.Â  Accordingly, we discern no prejudice to Cleveland Ridge.Â  Â Â 
CONCLUSION
The trial court correctly granted State Farmâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  Further, Cleveland Ridge was not prejudiced by the trial courtâ€™s denial of its Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion.Â  Therefore, the trial courtâ€™s order is
AFFIRMED.[1]
SHORT, WILLIAMS, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE. IT SHOULD NOT BE CITIED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Allen Marty Cornwell, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â JohnÂ  L.Â  Breeden, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-296
Heard May 11, 2006 â€“ Filed June 26, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor John Gregory Hembree, of Conway, Â for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Allen Marty Cornwell appeals his conviction for voluntary manslaughter.Â  Cornwell argues the trial judge erred in allowing the State to elicit a prior bad act and in refusing to direct a verdict on the charge of voluntary manslaughter.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS
In May 1997, Tyson Wolf and his family visited Cornwell, his step-grandfather, at Cornwellâ€™s apartment in North Myrtle Beach.Â  Wolf and Cornwell consumed alcohol at the family gathering.Â  At some point in the evening, Wolf was slapped by his mother for talking back to her.Â  Shortly thereafter, the police arrived in response to a domestic disturbance report.Â  After a brief investigation, the police left.Â  Cornwell then went into his bedroom and closed the door. 
The family members became angry when they discovered Cornwell had called the police and used Wolfâ€™s step-fatherâ€™s name instead of his own to report the domestic dispute.Â  Wolf began sobbing, went to the guest bedroom, and closed the door.Â  The other family members remained in the living room.Â  Moments later, Cornwell opened his bedroom door and had a gun in his hand.Â  Then, Wolf opened the guest bedroom door and said something to Cornwell. Cornwell shot Wolf in the chest.Â  Wolf later died from the wound. Â Â 
At trial, Cornwell testified that he, fearing for his life, shot Wolf.Â  Cornwell said Wolf charged him while he was sitting on his bed.Â  The trial judge charged the jury with self-defense and voluntary manslaughter.Â  The jury convicted Cornwell of voluntary manslaughter and the judge sentenced him to seventeen years imprisonment.Â  Cornwell appeals. 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Cornwell argues the trial judge erred in allowing the State to elicit a prior bad act and in refusing to direct a verdict on the charge of voluntary manslaughter.Â  We disagree. 
A.Â Â Prior Bad Act
Cornwell asserts the trial judge erred in allowing the State to question him about a crime he committed two weeks prior to the crime he was charged with at trial.Â  The trial judgeâ€™s ruling on the admissibility of evidence will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion that results in prejudice to the defendant. State v. Sosebee, 284 S.C. 411, 413, 326 S.E.2d 654, 656 (1985); State v. Hamilton, 344 S.C. 344, 352, 543 S.E.2d 586, 591 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the trial judgeâ€™s ruling is based on an error of law.Â  State v. McDonald, 343 S.C. 319, 324, 540 S.E.2d 464, 467 (2000).Â  The trial judge may exclude relevant evidence if its â€œprobative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice, confusion of the issues, or misleading the jury, or by considerations of undue delay, waste of time, or needless presentation of cumulative evidence.â€Â  Rule 403, SCRE; State v. Alexander, 303 S.C. 377, 382, 401 S.E.2d 146, 148 (1991); State v. Hess, 279 S.C. 14, 18, 301 S.E.2d 547, 550 (1983). Â The trial judgeâ€™s Rule 403, SCRE, ruling will be reversed by the appellate court only in exceptional circumstances.Â  State v. Horton, 359 S.C. 555, 568, 598 S.E.2d 279, 286 (Ct. App. 2004).
Two weeks before the shooting, Cornwell pled no contest to the crime of simple assault and battery.Â  Cornwell struck his wifeâ€™s friend multiple times after she slapped him.Â  Cornwell argued the trial judge should exclude the simple assault as overly prejudicial.Â  The State, however, argued that if Cornwell claimed he did not have the strength to defend himself against Wolf, the simple assault should be admitted as evidence Cornwell had the strength to defend himself.Â  The trial judge allowed the State to question Cornwell about the simple assault, but only if Cornwell first testified that he was unable to defend himself because he lacked the strength to do so.Â  Ultimately, the trial judge allowed the State to elicit the simple assault because Cornwell testified that he shot Wolf because he lacked the strength to fight him. Â Â 
Although we might have ruled differently, particularly because Cornwellâ€™s ability to defend himself against his wifeâ€™s friend appears to have little bearing on his ability to defend himself against his entire family, we do not find the trial judge erred in declining to exclude this evidence as overly prejudicial.Â  Hamilton, 344 S.C. 344, 358, 543 S.E.2d 586, 593-94 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œA trial judgeâ€™s balancing decision under Rule 403 should not be reversed simply because an appellate court believes it would have decided the matter otherwise because of a differing view of the highly subjective factors of the probative value or the prejudice presented by the evidence.â€).Â  Moreover, even if the trial judge erred, the error was harmless in light of the fact it could not have reasonably affected the outcome of this case.Â  State v. Key, 256 S.C. 90, 93, 180 S.E.2d 888, 890 (1971).Â  
B.Â Directed Verdict
Cornwell next asserts the trial judge erred in denying his directed verdict motion because there was no evidence he committed voluntary manslaughter.Â  On appeal from the denial of a directed verdict, the appellate court views the evidence in the light most favorable to the State.Â  State v. Lollis, 343 S.C. 580, 583, 541 S.E.2d 254, 256 (2001).Â  If there is any direct evidence or any substantial circumstantial evidence that reasonably tends to prove the defendantâ€™s guilt, the appellate court must find the case was properly submitted to the jury.Â  Id.Â  A defendant is entitled to a directed verdict when the State fails to produce evidence of the offense charged.Â  Id.Â  However, â€œwhen the defendant presents testimony, he loses the right to have the court review the sufficiency of the evidence based on the [S]tateâ€™s evidence alone.â€Â  State v. Harry, 321 S.C. 273, 277, 468 S.E.2d 76, 79 (Ct. App. 1996). 
The crime of voluntary manslaughter is defined as the intentional killing of a human being in the sudden heat of passion resulting from sufficient legal provocation.Â  State v. Nichols, 325 S.C. 111, 118, 481 S.E.2d 118, 122 (1997).Â  The provocation necessary to support a voluntary manslaughter charge must come from some act of the victim in order to constitute sufficient legal provocation.Â  State v. Tucker, 324 S.C. 155, 171, 478 S.E.2d 260, 269 (1996).Â  â€œWords alone, no matter how opprobrious, are not sufficient to prove legal provocation when a deadly weapon is used.â€Â  State v. Locklair, 341 S.C. 352, 361, 535 S.E.2d 420, 424 (2000); State v. Gardner, 219 S.C. 97, 104, 64 S.E.2d 130, 134 (1951).Â  Rather, when death is caused by the use of a deadly weapon, the opprobrious words must be accompanied by the appearance of an assault that could have produced the heat of passion.Â  State v. Lowry, 315 S.C. 396, 399, 434 S.E.2d 272, 274 (1993).Â  Â Â 
Here, there is evidence in the record Wolf provoked Cornwell beyond the mere use of opprobrious words.Â  Cornwell testified Wolf was about to initiate a physical encounter with him.Â  Cornwell said Wolf charged him while Cornwell sat on his bed.Â  Cornwell told the jury:

  [Wolf] just continued to cuss me and then he said, [â€˜]Iâ€™ll just kill you now, you son of a bitch[â€™] and started and came through my door [], charging me as hard as he could go and when I shot him the bullet just stood him up and stopped him.Â  He spun and run out . . . .

(emphasis added).Â  In light of Cornwellâ€™s testimony, we believe there is evidence in the record to support the charge of voluntary manslaughter.Â  Accordingly, the trial judgeâ€™s order is 
AFFIRMED.
Kittredge, Short, and Williams, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Employers Insurance of Wausau, Plaintiff,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Robert J. Moran and Eric C. Hansen, Defendants.
      
    
  



  
    
      
        Eric C. Hansen, Third-Party Plaintiff,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Caldwellâ€™s Diving Co., Inc., Third-Party Defendant,
        Of whom Eric C. Hansen is the, Appellant,
      
    
  


  
    
      
        And Employers Insurance of Wausau, Robert J. Moran and Caldwellâ€™s Diving Co., Inc., are the, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Georgetown County
Â James E. Lockemy, Circuit Court Judge
Â Paula H. Thomas, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-297
Submitted June 1, 2006 â€“ Filed June 26, 2006

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        Eric C. Hansen, of Tuckerton, N.J.; Pro Se.
        John S. Wilkerson, III, Troy G. Thames, and R. Hawthorne Barrett, all of Charleston, Pope D. Johnson, III, of Columbia and Robert W. Achurch, III, and Mary Bass Lohr, both of Beaufort; for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Employers Insurance of Wausau (Wausau) sued attorney Robert J. Moran and Moranâ€™s former client Eric C. Hansen to recover funds in Moranâ€™s escrow account on which it claimed a lien for benefits paid to Moran under the Federal Longshore and Harbor Workers Compensation Act.[1]Â  In his responsive pleadings, Hansen filed counterclaims against Wausau and cross-claims against Moran.Â  After the trial court granted Moranâ€™s request to interplead the disputed funds into the court, it granted summary judgment to Moran on Hansenâ€™s cross-claims, dismissed some of Hansenâ€™s counterclaims against Wausau, and dismissed third-party claims that Hansen later brought against Caldwellâ€™s Diving (Caldwell), his former employer.Â  Hansen appeals.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.[2]
FACTS
On April 17, 1991, Hansen, while working for Caldwell as a commercial diver, was seriously injured when a crane became detached and fell on him.Â  Although Hansen resided in New Jersey, the accident occurred at the Port Royal Sound in Beaufort, South Carolina.Â  
Wausau provided insurance for Caldwell, including coverage under the LHWCA and the Jones Act.[3]Â  Pursuant to the LHWCA, Wausau, on Caldwellâ€™s behalf, paid Hansen voluntary medical and disability benefits totaling $181,160.04.
 In November 1993, after Hansen applied for compensation under the LHWCA, Moran sued Caldwell on Hansenâ€™s behalf in the Beaufort County Court of Common Pleas alleging Caldwell was negligent under the Jones Act and breached certain duties relating to seaworthiness.Â  After this action was filed, Wausau discontinued paying Hansen LHWCA benefits.[4]
The parties settled the lawsuit in 1996.Â  Under their agreement, Hansenâ€™s total settlement was $1,320,325.88.Â  This amount included a waiver by Wausau of a lien it claimed on $181,160.04 that it had paid to Hansen under the LHWCA.Â  The waiver of the lien, however, was contingent on approval of the settlement by the United States Department of Labor pursuant to Â§ 908(i) of the LHWCA.[5] 
Hansen received $1,139,165.84, representing the â€œcashâ€ portion of the settlement after the deduction of counsel fees and costs. Â Moran retained $181,160.04, the amount of the lien, in his escrow account pending approval of the settlement by the Department of Labor.Â  
Hansen executed the necessary documents to effect the settlement; however, the district director of the Department of Labor â€œtolledâ€ the approval period because of insufficient information.Â  Later, however, Hansen informed the director he was not ready to settle the claim, prompting the director to â€œshelveâ€ the settlement approval pending submission of a new petition and Hansenâ€™s agreement to proceed. 
Moran later ceased acting as Hansenâ€™s attorney, but retained the $181,160.04 in his escrow account pending resolution of Wausauâ€™s claimed lien.Â  Moran claimed he was properly withholding the disputed funds under the South Carolina Rules of Professional Conduct.Â  Moranâ€™s law firm produced an attorney-client settlement statement detailing fees and costs and reducing the amount disbursed to Hansen by these amounts.Â  The fees were calculated based on the total amount of the settlement, including the escrowed funds.
By order dated August 7, 1998, a federal administrative law judge in Camden, New Jersey, found Hansen was not entitled to benefits or attorney fees under the LHWCA because he was classified as a seaman.Â  The order did not address Wausauâ€™s prior payments or the claimed lien.Â  On or about November 26, 2001, the United States Supreme Court denied certiorari on Hansenâ€™s appeal of this order, thus in effect upholding the determination that Hansen was ineligible to recover under the LHWCA.
By letter dated April 17, 2001, the Department of Labor disapproved the settlement and further advised Hansen the funds in Moranâ€™s escrow account â€œmust be repaid to the employer/insurer as a result of their lien due to benefits paid voluntarily under the [LHWCA].â€Â  On January 15, 2003, however, the Department sent another letter stating â€œour office has no authority to determine the proper ownership of those funds.Â  Therefore, it was a regrettable error when we advised Mr. Hansen . . . that the $181,000 held in escrow from the Jones Act settlement must be repaid to the employer/carrier.â€Â  The Department further advised in the second letter that â€œthe [LHWCA] does not have any provision for recoupment of benefits erroneously paid, except as a credit against future compensation payable.â€ 
On December 5, 2002, Wausau commenced this action in the Georgetown County Court of Common Pleas against Hansen and Moran to recover the escrowed funds.Â  Hansen hired a new attorney and counterclaimed against Wausau, alleging causes of action for collection, breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act, and unfair trade practices.Â  Hansen also filed a cross-claim against Moran, alleging causes of action for collection, breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act, negligence, breach of trust, and unfair trade practices.
On December 16, 2003, Circuit Judge Paula Thomas held a hearing on various motions in the case, including Hansenâ€™s motion for judgment on the pleadings and Moranâ€™s requests for interpleader and permission to deposit the escrowed funds into the court.Â  At the hearing, the parties consented to the withdrawal of Moranâ€™s motion to deposit the funds because the funds were earning interest in Moranâ€™s escrow account.Â  By order dated December 18, 2003, Judge Thomas noted the motion was withdrawn and informed the parties she was taking Hansenâ€™s motion for judgment on the pleadings under advisement.
On January 26, 2004, Judge Thomas issued an order granting Hansenâ€™s motion for judgment on the pleadings, finding Hansen was entitled to judgment on both Wausauâ€™s claim for the $181,160.04 in Moranâ€™s escrow account and his counterclaim for these funds.Â  According to Judge Thomas, â€œ[Wausau] has no cause of action under South Carolina law, and therefore no remedy in a South Carolina Court.Â  Essentially, [Wausau] is attempting to create a state court remedy where there is none.â€Â  Judge Thomas further statedÂ  â€œ[t]he issues raised by [Wausau] would appear to be better addressed to the Federal Courts and to the administrative agency concerned with the [LHWCA],â€ finding â€œthere is no provision of [the LHWCA] or the Jones Act which gives [Wausau] the remedy it seeks. . . . There is also no indication that Congress intended to provide employers or their insurers with a state or federal court remedy to recoup erroneously paid benefits.â€
Judge Thomas further held the only means by which Wausau could conceivably obtain a lien on the funds would be under the provisions of the LHWCA or the Jones Act, but noted â€œCongress has clearly spoken on this issue.Â  It is not the role of a state court to create such a remedy under these facts.â€Â  Ultimately, Judge Thomas concluded â€œWausau has no right to a lien against the proceeds of Hansenâ€™s settlementâ€ and ordered Moran to release the funds in his escrow account to Hansen.
In her order, Judge Thomas specifically addressed the issues raised by the parties and analyzed the relevant state and federal law applicable to Wausauâ€™s lien claim.Â  She concluded Wausau â€œarticulated no salient cause of action andÂ  . . . this claim should not proceed further.â€Â  Although Judge Thomas acknowledged the issues Wausau raised in its pleadings â€œwould appear to be better addressed to the Federal Courts and to the administrative agency concerned with the [LHWCA],â€ she granted Hansenâ€™s motion for judgment on the pleadings based on her determination that Wausau â€œhas no remedy under the facts alleged.â€ As we read her order and consider it in its entirety, Judge Thomas never specifically ruled the South Carolina state courts lacked subject matter jurisdiction to adjudicate the matter.Â  Â Â 
Wausau moved to alter or amend Judge Thomasâ€™s decision.Â  Specifically, Wausau alleged error in the trial courtâ€™s failure to find it had a judicially created lien against the settlement funds in the amount it erroneously paid to Hansen.Â  Wausau also maintained the court did not have authority to order disbursement of the money held in escrow because the order appeared to indicate that the federal court was the appropriate forum to decide such claims.
On February 18, 2004, Judge Thomas issued an order denying Wausauâ€™s post-trial motion on the issue of the judgment on the pleadings.Â  Wausau did not appeal this portion of the order.Â  
As to release of the funds; however, the order provided as follows:Â  

  The Motion to Reconsider with regards to the deposit of funds is hereby GRANTED due to the fact that this motion was withdrawn by the attorney for the Defendant at the hearing before the court.Â  This is evidenced in the Form Order signed by this Court on December 18, 2003.Â  Thus there is no outstanding motion regarding the funds upon which a ruling is necessary.

Judge Thomas issued an amended order on February 20, 2004, in which she deleted information about the motion being withdrawn and stated the following:Â  

  The Motion to Reconsider with regard to the deposit of funds is hereby GRANTED, therefore, that portion of the Order requiring disbursement of the funds is stricken.Â  The court finds that issue was not before it for determination.Â  This is evidenced in the Form Order signed by this Court on December 18, 2003.Â  Thus there is no outstanding motion regarding the funds upon which a ruling is necessary.

On March 2, 2004, Hansen filed a motion to compel the release of the funds.Â  Pursuant to this motion, Judge Thomas issued an order dated March 9, 2004, in which she stated â€œ[t]his Court did not order the funds to be held in escrow and therefore, will not order them released.Â  This Court did, in a previous order, dismiss the pending claim due to lack of jurisdiction of this Court.â€[6]
Subsequently, numerous motions came before Circuit Judge James Lockemy, including Hansenâ€™s motion to file a third-party complaint against Caldwell and Moranâ€™s motions for summary judgment and for leave to deposit the funds into the court. On April 5, 2004, Judge Lockemy issued a form order granting Hansenâ€™s motion to bring Caldwell into the lawsuit, addressing certain concerns not at issue in this appeal, and taking other motions under advisement.
On September 23, 2004, Judge Lockemy issued a final order granting Moranâ€™s motion for summary judgment on all Hansenâ€™s claims against him and Moranâ€™s motion to deposit the escrowed funds into the court.Â  In granting summary judgment, Judge Lockemy found the statute of limitations barred Hansenâ€™s cross-claims against Moran.
On the same date, Judge Lockemy issued a second order dismissing Hansenâ€™s claims against Wausau and Caldwell without prejudice.Â  In this order, Judge Lockemy interpreted Judge Thomasâ€™s orders of January 26, 2004, and March 9, 2004, to dismiss Wausauâ€™s claim against Hansen â€œfor lack of jurisdiction, for that claim to be addressed in federal court.â€Â  Judge Lockemy further found as follows:Â  

  Mr. Hansenâ€™s claims against Wausau and the third-party defendant arise out of and pertain to the application of the [LHWCA] and those depend or may depend on the federal courtâ€™s determination of Wausauâ€™s claim.Â  I find that Mr. Hansenâ€™s claims against Wausau and the third-party defendant should be decided by the federal court.Â  Having those claims decided in the federal court would insure that there was proper subject matter jurisdiction as to all claims and would eliminate the risk of inconsistent results and avoid unnecessary duplication of time and expense on the part of the court systems and the litigants.

Judge Lockemy also ordered the Georgetown County Clerk of Court to â€œhold the funds on deposit pending an Order of the United States District Court or any other court of competent jurisdiction, authorizing and directing the release of the funds, or an agreement of Mr. Hansen and Wausau authorizing and directing the release of the funds.â€Â  Finally, Judge Lockemy relieved Hansenâ€™s attorney of any further responsibility to represent Hansen in the matter once counsel delivered a copy of the order to Hansen.
In October 2004, Hansen, proceeding pro se, filed a â€œMotion for reconsideration and to withdraw, alter or amend both of the September orders issued by Judge Lockemy.Â  In addition, he moved for sanctions, costs, and fees.Â  By orders dated December 14, 2004, and January 19, 2005, Judge Lockemy denied Hansenâ€™s motions.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS[7]
1.Â  Hansen contends Judge Lockemy erred in holding his claims against Moran were untimely.Â  We disagree.
In reviewing the grant of summary judgment, this court applies the same standard that governs the trial court:Â  i.e., summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.[8]Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all inferences that can be reasonably drawn from the evidence must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.[9]Â  â€œOn appeal from an order granting summary judgment, the appellate court will review all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence in a light most favorable to the nonmoving party below.â€[10]Â  
All Hansenâ€™s claims against Moran fall under a three-year statute of limitations.[11]Â  Under the discovery rule, the three-year limitations period begins to run from the date the injured party either knows or should know by â€œthe exercise of reasonable diligenceâ€ that a cause of action exists for the wrongful conduct.[12] 
In the present case, the record clearly demonstrates Hansen knew or should have known of his potential claims against Moran in 1996, when Moran retained his fees out of the settlement and retained part of the settlement funds in his escrow account rather than disburse them to Hansen.[13]Â  Hansen failed to take any action on those claims until 2003, when he filed his cross-claims against Moran in this action, almost seven years after Moran placed the disputed funds into escrow and withheld attorney fees and costs.Â  
2.Â  Hansen contends the trial court erred in granting Moranâ€™s motion for interpleader and leave to deposit the disputed funds with the clerk of court.Â  We disagree.Â  Hansen, through his attorney, consented to the funds being entrusted to the clerk of court and is bound by his counselâ€™s action.[14] 
John S. Wilkerson represented Moran and David B. Marvel represented Hansen at the hearing before Judge Lockemy. The following colloquy occurred:

  THE COURT: . . . What other issues are there on your behalf now at this time, Mr. Wilkerson?
  MR. WILKERSON: The only other one that I have, Your Honor, I donâ€™t think thereâ€™s going to be a dispute about this. We just need the Courtâ€™s assistance on this. Is that Mr. Moran has continued to maintain these funds in an interest bearing escrow account. . . . Â We filed a[n] interpleader asking if we be allowed to interplead the funds into the court or the Court to rule on whoâ€™s entitled to the money.
  . . . I have here a certified check from the Bank of America in the total amount of $232,092.48 made payable to the clerk of court of Georgetown County. We would like to have the Court order that that money be . . . accepted by the clerk of court and held until further order of the Court so that these other parties can resolve their issues as to who is entitled to this money. . . .
  THE COURT: Mr. Marvel, you object to the amount file[d] with the clerk of court? 
  MR. MARVEL: No, Your Honor.
  THE COURT: All right, your motionâ€™s granted.
  MR. WILKERSON: Thank you, Your Honor. So, should I present to the Court an order to the effect that the money is being received by the clerk of court pursuant to this courtâ€™s order to be - - - Â 
  THE COURT: Without objection from the co-defendant.
  MR. WILKERSON: - - - to be held until further order of the Court.
  THE COURT: Thatâ€™s fine.
  MR. WILKERSON: Thank you, Your Honor. I am at this point presenting to the clerk of court that certified check.

Furthermore, under the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure, â€œ[a]ny party seeking interpleader, . . . may deposit with the court the amount claimed . . . .Â  The court may thereupon order such party discharged from liability as to such claims, and the action continued as between claimants of such money or property.â€[15]Â  In the present case, Moranâ€™s answer to Hansenâ€™s cross-claims contained a request for the court to allow Moran to deposit the funds with the clerk of court.Â  Moran was merely the party holding the money and, once summary judgment was granted in his favor on all of Hansenâ€™s claims, he no longer had any interest in the action.Â  
3.Â  We agree, however, with Hansenâ€™s argument that Judge Lockemy improperly dismissed his claims for lack of jurisdiction in the state court and in favor of having the claims heard in federal court.
Subject-matter jurisdiction is the â€œ â€˜power to hear and determine cases of the general class to which the proceedings in question belong.â€™ â€[16]Â  Both Wausauâ€™s claim and Hansenâ€™s first counterclaim were collection actions to recover the money in Moranâ€™s escrow account.Â  Such actions are within the subject matter jurisdiction of the state courts,[17] as are Hansenâ€™s remaining causes of action for breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act and unfair trade practices.[18]Â  
The fact that Hansenâ€™s claims â€œarise out of and pertain toâ€ or were brought under either the Jones Act or the LHWCA does not deprive the South Carolina State courts of jurisdiction to decide them.Â  Under, the United States Constitution, federal judicial power â€œshall extend . . . to all cases of admiralty and maritime jurisdiction.â€[19] Â â€œFederal-court jurisdiction over such cases, however, has never been entirely exclusive.â€[20] 
â€œA suit under the Jones Act to recover damages for injury to or death of a seaman may be brought in either a federal or a state court.â€[21]Â  Such an action, when commenced in a state court, is not subject to removal even when there is diversity of citizenship.[22] Â Moreover, the state and federal courts have concurrent jurisdiction over many claims under the LHWCA.[23]Â Â Â  
Furthermore, in an action that Hansen and his wife filed in the United States District Court in New Jersey against Caldwell, United States District Judge Mary L. Cooper issued a memorandum opinion on June 7, 2005, declining to consider the Hansensâ€™ claims in that action because of the pending appeal before this court. Â We find particularly instructive footnote 3 of Judge Cooperâ€™s order, in which she explained as follows:

  The South Carolina Court of Common Pleas seems to have erred in finding [the Hansensâ€™] claim arising out of the LHWCA should be resolved by a federal court. . . . Third party actions under [the] LHWCA may be tried by state courts. See Kermarec v Compagnie Generale Transatlantique, 3[5]8 U.S. 625, 628 (1959) (â€œIf this action [an action by a guest of a crew member for injuries sustained on a vessel brought in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York] had been brought in state court, reference to admiralty law would have been necessary to determine the rights and liabilities of the parties.â€); Paxos v. Jarka Corp., 171 A. 468, 469 (Pa. 1934) (â€œAdmittedly, practice in the federal courts does not control in the courts of this state, but we [the Pennsylvania Supreme Court] will enforce the substantive rights given all parties here of record by the federal [LWHCA].â€).

Moreover, state courts may decide actions for maintenance and cure and â€œare bound to proceed in such manner that all substantial rights of the parties under controlling federal law will be protected.â€[24] 
 We therefore reverse the trial courtâ€™s determination that it lacked authority to hear Hansenâ€™s claims against Wausau and Caldwell and remand these claims for a decision on the merits.[25]Â  
4.Â  In addition, we hold Judge Lockemyâ€™s dismissal of Hansenâ€™s collection claim against Wausau was improper.Â  In her order, Judge Thomas addressed the merits of Wausauâ€™s claim for the escrowed funds and Hansenâ€™s counterclaim for collection of the money.Â  Although Judge Thomas stated Wausauâ€™s claims â€œwould appear to be better addressed to the Federal Courts and to the administrative agency concerned with the LHWCA,â€ she nevertheless addressed the merits of these claims after considering the relevant state and federal law and held Wausau â€œhas articulated no salient cause of action and that this claim should not be allowed to proceed further.â€ Â Contrary to Judge Lockemyâ€™s interpretation of Judge Thomasâ€™s order, Judge Thomas did not dismiss the claims for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  Rather, Judge Thomas granted Hansen judgment on the pleadings on Wausauâ€™s lien claim, thus ruling he was entitled to the disputed funds once the court acquired jurisdiction to disburse them.Â  Because Judge Thomas had already ruled on the merits of those claims, the subsequent issuance of a contrary ruling by another trial judge was error.[26]Â  
5.Â  Hansen contends the trial court erred in failing to enforce the judgment granted in his favor for the money that Moran had held in escrow.Â  
To the extent this argument concerns Judge Thomasâ€™s orders, we hold Judge Thomas properly ruled that she did not have jurisdiction over the money to order its release because it had not been interpleaded into the court.[27]Â  In addition, we find Hansen failed to preserve any issues concerning Judge Thomasâ€™s rulings for review on appeal.[28]Â  
Subsequently, however, Judge Lockemy granted Moranâ€™s request for interpleader and permission to deposit the money with the clerk of court.Â  Once the money was deposited, the court obtained jurisdiction over it and could order its release.[29]Â  Because Wausau did not appeal Judge Thomasâ€™s rulings that it had no right to recover the money improperly paid to Hansen, that Hansen was entitled to prevail on his counterclaim for payment the escrowed funds, Judge Thomasâ€™s decision is the law of this case.[30]Â  Accordingly, the trial court should have issued an order releasing the money deposited with the clerk of court to Hansen pursuant to Judge Thomasâ€™s order of January 26, 2004.
6.Â  Hansen raises issues on appeal related to various form orders the trial court issued in this case.Â  These form orders have been superseded by formal orders.Â  â€œ â€˜A case becomes moot when judgment, if rendered, will have no practical legal effect upon [the] existing controversy.Â  This is true when some event occurs making it impossible for [the] reviewing Court to grant effectual relief.â€™ â€[31]Â  This court will only address those issues on appeal pertaining to the final formal orders by the trial court.
CONCLUSION
We affirm the trial courtâ€™s decision to allow Moran to deposit the escrowed funds into the court and the grant of summary judgment on Hansenâ€™s claims against Moran.Â  We reverse the trial courtâ€™s findings that it lacked subject matter jurisdiction to hear Hansenâ€™s claims and remand these proceedings to the trial court for (1) entry of an order directing the clerk of court, pursuant to Judge Thomasâ€™s order granting Hansen judgment on the pleadings, to disburse to Hansen the funds deposited by Moran, and (2) consideration of Hansenâ€™s remaining causes of action against Wausau and Caldwell. 
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, and REMANDED. 
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  33 U.S.C. Â§ 901-950 (hereinafter referred to as LHWCA).
[2]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[3] Â 46 U.S.C. app. Â§ 688.
[4]Â  According to Wausau, coverage under the Jones Act is mutually exclusive of that under the LHWCA.
[5]Â  Under this section, â€œ[n]o liability of any employer, carrier, or both for medical, disability, or death benefits [under the LHWCA] shall be discharged unless the application for settlement is approved by the deputy commissioner or administrative law judge.â€Â  33 U.S.C. Â§ 908(i)(1).
[6] We interpret the term â€œpending claimâ€ to refer to Hansenâ€™s motion for immediate possession of the disputed funds, the matter that prompted the issuance of the order of March 9, 2004.Â  The orders of February 18, 2004, and February 20, 2004, superseded the provision in Judge Thomasâ€™s order of January 26, 2004, in which she directed Moran to release the funds to Hansen.Â  Both of the later orders reference either expressly or by implication the withdrawal of Moranâ€™s motion for interpleader with the consent of all parties at the hearing on December 16, 2003, as documented in a form order Judge Thomas signed on December 18, 2003.Â  In both the February 18 and February 20 orders, Judge Thomas concluded â€œthere is no outstanding motion regarding the funds upon which a ruling is necessary,â€ indicating she was unable to exercise jurisdiction over disbursement of the money given the procedural posture of the case at the time.
[7] Â Hansen raised a total of 25 issues on appeal in his 75-page brief.Â  We have consolidated the issues for purposes of this opinion.
[8] Â Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Baughman v. Am. Tel. & Tel. Co., 306 S.C. 101, 114-15, 410 S.E.2d 537, 545 (1991).Â  
[9] Â Strother v. Lexington County Rec. Commâ€™n, 332 S.C. 54, 61, 504 S.E.2d 117, 121 (1998).Â  
[10] Osborne v. Adams, 346 S.C. 4, 7, 550 S.E.2d 319, 321 (2001).
[11] See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-530(1) (2005) (providing a three-year limitations period for â€œan action upon a contract, obligation, or liability, express or implied); id. Â§ 15-3-530(5) (providing for a three-year limitations period for injuries â€œnot arising on contract and not enumerated by lawâ€); and Â§ 39-5-150 (1985) (prohibiting claims under the South Carolina Unfair Trade Practices Act if brought â€œmore than three years after discovery of the unlawful conduct which is the subject of the suitâ€).Â  Although Hansen alleged a cause of action for breach of trust against Moran, he stated it was based on an alleged breach of fiduciary duty.Â  
[12] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-535 (2005); Dean v. Ruscon Corp., 321 S.C. 360, 363, 468 S.E.2d 645, 647 (1996); Berry v. McLeod, 328 S.C. 435, 444-45, 492 S.E.2d 794, 799 (Ct. App. 1997).Â Â  
[13] In correspondence dated May 20, 1996, Hansen pointedly alleged Moran had mishandled his claim and expressed his intent to sue Moran for legal malpractice.
[14] See Koutsogiannis v. BB&T, 365 S.C. 145, 149, 616 S.E.2d 425, 428 (2005) (â€œIn the attorney-client relationship, clients are generally bound by their attorneysâ€™ acts or omissions during the course of the legal representation that fall within the apparent scope of their attorneysâ€™ authority.â€); Shelton v. Bressant, 312 S.C. 183, 185, 439 S.E.2d 833, 834 (1993) (reaffirming â€œthe long standing rule that a client is bound by his attorneyâ€™s actions in the settlement of a caseâ€); State v. McCrary, 242 S.C. 506, 509, 131 S.E.2d 687, 688-89 (1963) (holding that, because the appellant consented to be tried on two indictments at the same time and failed to object to the mode of trial, â€œhe is not in position to assert error hereâ€).
[15] Rule 22(b), SCRCP.
[16] Dove v. Gold Kist, 314 S.C. 235, 237-38, 442 S.E.2d 598, 600 (1994) (quoting Bank of Babylon v. Quirk, 472 A.2d 21, 22 (Conn. 1984)).
[17] See, e.g., Regions Bank v. Schmauch, 354 S.C. 648, 582 S.E.2d 432 (Ct. App. 2003) (concerning action to collect amounts owed on loans allegedly guaranteed by the appellant); Maddux Supply Co. v. A-C Elec. Co., Inc., 321 S.C. 182, 467 S.E.2d 448 (Ct. App. 1996) (regarding suit on overdue accounts and counterclaim for breach of contract).Â  
[18] See, e.g., Conner v. City of Forest Acres, 348 S.C. 454, 465-66, 560 S.E.2d 606, 612 (2002) (discussing breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act); Daisy Outdoor Adver.Â  Co. v. Abbott, 322 S.C. 489, 493, 473 S.E.2d 47, 49 (1996) (deciding a case under the South Carolina Unfair Trade Practices Act).
[19] U.S. Const., Art. III, Â§ 2, cl. 1.
[20] American Dredging Co. v. Miller, 510 U.S. 443, 446 (1994).
[21] 32B Am. Jur. 2d Federal Employersâ€™ Liability, etc. Â§ 57, at 910 (1996).
[22] Id. at 911.
[23] See Stevedoring Servs. v. Prudential Lines, Inc., 181 Cal. App. 3d 154, 158 (Cal. Ct. App. 1986) (â€œState courts have concurrent jurisdiction with federal courts over claims arising under the LHWCA and general maritime law.â€).
[24] 78A C.J.S. Seamen Â§ 134, at 634 (1995); see also Gaar v. Quirk, 86 F.3d 451, 453-54 (5th Cir. 1996) (noting the LHWCA does not completely preempt state law); Moss v. Dixie Mach. Welding and Metal Works, 617 So.2d 959, 961 (1993), (noting the wrongful discharge remedy under the LHWCA does not preempt â€œa similar state remedy and cause of actionâ€), cert. denied, 510 U.S. 976 (1993).Â  We note that, in his third-party complaint against Caldwell, Hansen alleged he was entitled to â€œmaintenance and cureâ€ as a result of his on-the-job injury while working as a seaman.
[25] If necessary for a determination of the rights of the parties, a state court can always rely on federal law.Â  See, e.g., Montgomery v. CSX Transp., Inc., 362 S.C. 529, 544, 608 S.E.2d 440, 448 (Ct. App. 2004) (making reference to federal law in a FELA case brought in state court).
[26] See Charleston County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Father, Stepmother, and Mother, 317 S.C. 283, 288, 454 S.E.2d 307, 310 (1995) (â€œThere is a long-standing rule in this State that one judge of the same court cannot overrule another.â€) (citing Tisdale v. Am. Life Ins. Co., 216 S.C. 10, 56 S.E.2d 580 (1950)).
[27] See Johnson v. Serv. Mgmt., Inc., 319 S.C. 165, 168, 459 S.E.2d 900, 902 (Ct. App. 1995) (holding money in a bank account â€œcould not be reached through execution and levy, but only through supplemental proceedingsâ€), affâ€™d, 324 S.C. 198, 478 S.E.2d 63 (1996).
[28] See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).
[29] See Rule 67, SCRCP (â€œMoney paid into the court under this rule . . . shall be withdrawn only upon the check of the clerk of court in favor of the party to whom the order of the court directs.â€).
[30] See S.C. Coastal Conserv. League v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health and Envtl. Control, 363 S.C. 67, 76, 610 S.E.2d 782, 487 (2005) (holding an unappealed ruling, whether correct or not, is the law of the case).
[31] Curtis v. State, 345 S.C. 557, 567, 549 S.E.2d 591, 596 (2001) (quoting Mathis v. S. C. State Highway Depâ€™t, 260 S.C. 344, 346, 195 S.E.2d 713, 715 (1973)).Â Â

PREHEARING REPORT

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Marcus K. Wilson, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â Clifton Newman, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-298
Submitted June 1, 2006 â€“ Filed June 27, 2006Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Jack B. Swerling, of Columbia and Katherine Carruth Link, of W. Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster,Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., Office of the Attorney General, of Columbia, Warren Blair Giese, Fifth Circuit Solicitorâ€™s Office, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â Marcus K. Wilson appeals the trial courtâ€™s acceptance of his guilty plea and denial of his motion for a new trial.Â  We affirm. 
FACTSÂ Â Â Â Â  
From October 2003 until November 2003, Wilson had contact with a younger female (Victim).Â  During this time, Wilson drugged Victim, engaged in sex acts with her, and took photos of her in â€œsexyâ€ posses and of her genitals.Â  On November 23, 2003, Victimâ€™s family reported Wilsonâ€™s conduct to the police.Â  Victimâ€™s family stated Victim was sixteen years old when Wilson engaged in the conduct with Victim.Â  This claim was supported by a birth certificate (Certificate One) showing Victimâ€™s date of birth as March 15, 1987. Â Â 
During his preparation for trial, Wilson obtained a birth certificate (Certificate Two) that he claimed stated Victimâ€™s date of birth as March 2, 1985.Â  Wilson claimed this proved Victim was eighteen when he engaged in the conduct with her.Â  However, there were discrepancies between the names of the child, mother, and father listed on Certificate Two and the names of Victim, Victimâ€™s mother, and Victimâ€™s father.Â  A copy of Certificate Two was sent to the solicitorâ€™s office on August 23, 2004.Â  Due to the discrepancy in the dates on the two birth certificates, Wilson sought authentication.Â  Victim is originally from the Republic of Liberia, and both certificates purported to be issued by Liberian officials.Â  In early September, Wilson contacted the Embassy of the Republic of Liberia about authenticating Certificate Two.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
On September 20, 2004, Wilson pleaded guilty to sexual exploitation of a minor in the third degree and to contributing to the delinquency of a minor.Â  Pursuant to North Carolina v. Alford, 400 U.S. 25 (1970), he also pleaded without admitting guilt to criminal sexual conduct in the third degree.Â  Wilson was sentenced to ten years for criminal sexual conduct in the third degree, five years for sexual exploitation of a minor in the third degree to be served consecutively with the criminal sexual conduct sentence, and three years for contributing to the delinquency of a minor to be served concurrently with the criminal sexual conduct sentence. Â Â Â Â Â 
On September 21, 2004, the Embassy of the Republic of Liberia certified Certificate Two as being authentic.Â  On September 24, 2004, Wilson moved to have his sentence reconsidered and reduced.Â  On October 18, 2004 the Embassy of the Republic of Liberia issued a letter to Wilson declaring Certificate One to be null and void. Â Based on the authentication of Certificate Two and the declaration that Certificate One was null and void, Wilson, on November 23, 2004, moved for a new trial based on after-discovered evidence. Â Â Â Â 
The motions were argued to the court on December 10, 2004.Â  Victimâ€™s father testified that Victim was born March 15, 1987. Â Victimâ€™s Uncle testified that the first time he saw Victim was in February 1989, and Victim appeared, at that time, to be a child of two years old or younger.Â  On February 8, 2005, the court denied Wilsonâ€™s motion for a new trial and modified his sentence so all convictions would run concurrently. Â Wilson appeals this denial and appeals the trial courts acceptance of his guilty plea claiming that it was not made knowingly, intelligently, or voluntarily.
ANALYSIS
A.Â  After-Discovered Evidence
Wilson argues the authentication of Certificate Two is after-discovered evidence, and therefore, the trial court should have granted his motion for a new trial.Â  We disagree.Â  
The denial of a motion for a new trial will not be reversed absent an abuse of discretion.Â  State v. South, 310 S.C. 504, 507, 427 S.E.2d 666, 668 (1993).Â  To be successful, the party seeking a new trial based on after-discovered evidence must show that the evidence: 1) would probably change the result if a new trial is had; 2) has been discovered since trial; 3) could not have been discovered before trial; 4) is material to the issue of guilt or innocence; & 5) is not merely cumulative or impeaching.Â  State v. Spann, 334 S.C. 618, 619, 513 S.E.2d 98, 99 (1999). 
Wilson had Certificate Two since early August 2004, and he sought authentication from the Embassy of the Republic of Liberia in early September 2004. Â Therefore, he had certificate two before he plead guilty on September 20, 2004.Â  The only thing that Wilson received after he plead was certification that Certificate Two was authentic as to the person listed on it.Â  
If Wilson wished to put the issue of the validity of Certificate One or Two before the court, he should have moved for a continuance.Â  He was well aware of the discrepancies between the birth certificates, and instead of asking for additional time he decided to plea guilty and enter an Alford plea.Â  Therefore, Wilson can not show that the evidence has been discovered since trial or that it could not have been discovered before trial. Â Â 
B.Â  The Guilty Plea
Wilson argues his plea was not entered into knowingly, intelligently, or voluntarily and is void as a violation of due process because he did not know certificate two would be authenticated by the Republic of Liberia.Â  We disagree.
Pleas are void as a violation of due process unless they are entered into knowingly, intelligently, and voluntarily.Â  Boykin v. Alabama, 395 U.S. 238, 89 S.Ct. 1709 (1969); Burnett v. State, 352 S.C. 589, 591, 576 S.E.2d144, 145 (2003).Â  Absent a timely objection during the plea proceeding, the unknowing and involuntary nature of a plea can only be attacked through the channel of Post Conviction Relief.Â  State v. McKinney, 278 S.C. 107, 108, 292 S.E.2d 598, 599 (1982).
Wilson claims that his plea could not have been entered into knowingly, intelligently, or voluntarily and is void as a violation of due process because he did not know certificate two would be authenticated by the Republic of Liberia.Â  The State correctly points out that Wilson failed to object during the plea proceedings.Â  Therefore, Wilson has waived consideration of this issue on appeal.Â  Absent an objection at the plea proceeding, the unknowing and involuntary nature of a guilty plea will not be considered on appeal.Â  Id. Â See also State v. Barton, 325 S.C. 522, 481 S.E.2d 439 (Ct. App. 1997) (stating the proper avenue through which to challenge a guilty plea which was not objected to at the time of its entry is through post-conviction relief).Â  Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s order is 
AFFIRMED.
KITTREDGE, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, J.J., concur.
