THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        John E. Kelley, Jr. and Mary V. Kelley, Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Sandra P. Herman and the Home Place, d/b/a Americaâ€™s Home Place, Defendants,
        of whom Sandra P. Herman is the, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Laurens County
Â Wyatt T. Saunders, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-299
Submitted June 1, 2006 â€“ Filed June 29, 2006Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Max Thomas Hyde and Donald Coggins, Jr., of Spartanburg, for Appellants.
        John Michael Turner, of Laurens, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â The plaintiffs, John E. Kelley, Jr. and Mary V. Kelley, appeal from an order granting summary judgment to the defendant, Sandra P. Herman. Â The action arises out of a real estate purchase in which the Kelleys claim Herman misrepresented which lot she was selling them.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
We review, as we must, the evidence and all reasonable inferences in the light most favorable to the Kelleys.Â  In early 2001, the Kelleys, a deaf couple, contacted The Home Place, Inc., a home builder with offices in Greenville, South Carolina, about their desire to purchase or build a home in Laurens County, South Carolina.Â  The Home Place put them in touch with Herman, who resided in the Hickory Forest subdivision of Laurens County and owned several lots there.Â  
Mr. Kelleyâ€™s mother contacted Herman, who told her that she had several pieces of property for sale.Â  Subsequently, the Kelleys, accompanied by Mr. Kelleyâ€™s parents, rode out to the subdivision late one afternoon at dusk to look at the property.Â  Hermanâ€™s lots were on a cul-de-sac at the end of Hickory Forest Drive.Â  As the Kelleys drove out of the cul-de-sac, they encountered Herman, who lived in the area and was approaching the cul-de-sac from the opposite direction.Â  They both stopped their cars in front of an empty lot (the Level Lot) that was owned by the Friendship Presbyterian Church.Â  Herman owned Lot A, which is located next door to the Level Lot.Â  Â Â 
Herman spoke to Mr. Kelleyâ€™s parents and the Kelleys observed her point in the direction of the Level Lot.Â  Herman allegedly told Mr. Kelleyâ€™s parents that this was â€œLot Aâ€ and was available for sale.Â  Herman also gave the Kelleys and Mr. Kelleyâ€™s parents a copy of a plat indicating â€œLot Aâ€ was available for sale.Â  Mr. Kelleyâ€™s parents communicated in American Sign Language with the Kelleys.Â  The Kelleys did not understand the conversation Herman had with Mr. Kelleyâ€™s parents, but his parents interpreted for them.Â  
On or about February 22, 2001, the Kelleys entered into a contract of sale with Herman to purchase land described as â€œLot A, Hickory Forest Drive, Laurens, South Carolina 29360â€ for the stated sum of $26,908.00.Â  Prior to the closing, the Kelleys paid for a survey of Lot A that was prepared on April 30, 2001.Â  The survey showed Lot A, totaling 3.99 acres, was situated on a cul-de-sac and had a creek running across the property.Â  The closing occurred on May 11, 2001.Â  In describing the property, the deed referenced the April 30, 2001 survey.Â  
The Kelleys, who had signed a contract with The Home Place for the construction of a home, visited the Level Lot numerous times and had the lot staked out and a sign installed by a representative of The Home Place indicating a home was to be built on the site.Â  Although Herman lived within view of the Level Lot, she never advised the Kelleys that they were attempting to build on the wrong lot.Â  According to the Kelleys, they first became aware they had purchased Lot A instead of the Level Lot when they tried unsuccessfully to obtain a septic tank permit after the closing.Â  They contend without a permit the land is unsuitable for building, at least at the projected cost they had anticipated.Â Â  Â Â 
The Kelleys instituted this action against Herman, alleging, among other things, that she committed fraud by misleading them regarding the property that she was selling.[2]Â  The trial court granted Hermanâ€™s motion for summary judgment, finding as a matter of law that the Kelleys had not established a claim for fraud as they had no justifiable right to rely on any representations made by Herman.Â  The court observed â€œ[t]he Kelleys had a duty to read the contents of the documents before signing them and a duty to exercise reasonable care to protect themselves.â€Â  The court noted the Kelleys â€œcan read and write to some degree and Mr. Kelley is capable of comprehending drawings and blueprints, which he does in his work.â€[3]Â  Further, â€œ[t]he Kelleys had three months between the signing of the contract and the closing to review the property and plans.â€Â  Finally, the court noted the Kelleys had an interpreter at the closing and they were represented by an attorney.Â  The Kelleys appeal.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Under the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure, summary judgment is appropriate when â€œthe pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; see also Standard Fire Ins. Co. v. Marine Contracting & Towing Co., 301 S.C. 418, 421, 392 S.E.2d 460, 462 (1990).Â  When reviewing the grant of a motion for summary judgment, an appellate court applies the same standard applied by the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 567 S.E.2d 857 (2002).Â  The evidence and all reasonable inferences that can be drawn therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the party opposing the motion.Â  Summer v. Carpenter, 328 S.C. 36, 42, 492 S.E.2d 55, 58 (1997).
LAW/ANALYSIS
The Kelleys contend the trial court erred in granting summary judgment to Herman because there are questions of fact for a jury regarding whether Herman â€œacted fraudulently in connection with the sale of Lot A to [them]â€ and whether they had a justifiable â€œright to rely on [Hermanâ€™s] representations.â€Â  They contend Herman misled them regarding the lot she was selling because they purchased property designated as â€œLot A,â€ which is a hilly, less desirable lot arguably unsuitable for building at the price they expected, and they were led to believe they were purchasing the Level Lot.
To prove fraud, one must show, among other things, a representation and the hearerâ€™s right to rely thereon.Â  First State Sav. & Loan v. Phelps,  299 S.C. 441, 446-47, 385 S.E.2d 821, 824 (1989).Â  â€œFraud must be proven by clear, cogent and convincing evidence.â€Â  Id. at 447, 385 S.E.2d at 824.Â  
â€œIt is well settled in this State that one cannot complain of fraud in the misrepresentation of the contents of a written instrument in his possession when the truth could have been ascertained by his reading the instrument.â€ Doub v. Weathersby-Breeland Ins. Agency, 268 S.C. 319, 326, 233 S.E.2d 111, 114 (1977).Â  â€œOne entering into a contract should read it and avail himself of every reasonable opportunity to understand its contents and meaning.â€Â  Id.Â  
â€œA person who signs a contract or other written document cannot avoid the effect of the document by claiming he did not read it.â€Â  Regions Bank v. Schmauch, 354 S.C. 648, 663, 582 S.E.2d 432, 440 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  â€œOne who signs a written instrument has the duty to exercise reasonable care to protect himself.â€Â  Id. at 440, 582 S.E.2d at 664.Â  â€œThis rule is subject to the exception that if the party is ignorant and unwary, his failure to read the document may be excused.â€Â  Id.Â  This exception is very strictly construed, however, and â€œ[i]n determining whether a party can be classified as ignorant and unwary, an individualâ€™s education, business experience and intelligence are all considered.â€Â  Id.
The allegations of fraud made by the Kelleys rest upon the actions of Herman at the partiesâ€™ initial meeting and at two subsequent meetings.Â  First, the Kelleys argue Herman at their initial meeting â€œclearly indicated by gesturing and pointing that the Level Lot directly across from where they were parked was available for sale.â€Â  They say they were not able to read the plat Herman offered them as it was late in the afternoon, dusk, and they also have some trouble reading and writing English. Â Next, the Kelleys assert that at a meeting with Herman on February 10, 2001 to go over the sales contract, the Kelleys â€œgestured to make sure that the land was flat,â€ and Herman â€œassured us and said yes,â€ indicating the lot was flat.Â  Finally, the Kelleys contend that at the closing, they asked questions about whether the land was flat and about the creek on the property and was again assured by Herman that â€œeverything was fine, that the land was buildable, that we would be able to build on the land.â€Â  The Kelleys did not speak directly to Herman as she was in a waiting room next door during the closing, but the Kelleys had an interpreter present and relayed their questions through their attorney, who did speak to Herman.Â Â Â 
The Kelleys rely on Slack v. James, 364 S.C. 609, 614 S.E.2d 636 (2005), in which our supreme court held that questions about whether a buyerâ€™s reliance on the sellersâ€™ misrepresentations was reasonable should be determined by a jury, even though the falsity of the alleged misrepresentation could have been ascertained by examining the public records.Â  In that case, the buyers were affirmatively told by the sellersâ€™ real estate agent that there were no easements on the property before entering into a sales contract.Â  Id. at 612, 614 S.E.2d at 637.Â  After executing the contract, the buyers conducted a title search and discovered a sewer easement on the property, so they refused to go forward with the closing and make the purchase.Â  Id.Â  The supreme court noted that a â€œsewer line easement is not easily discoverable without research by an expert such as an attorney.â€Â  Id. at 615, 614 S.E.2d at 639.Â  Further, because of the speed of real estate transactions, it was not expected that a title search would have been conducted prior to the execution of a sales contract, and that a jury question was created regarding whether their reliance was reasonable as the explicit assurance might have induced the buyers to refrain from discovering the true facts regarding whether there were any easements prior to entering into a contract.Â  Id. at 615-16, 614 S.E.2d at 639-40.
Although we are sympathetic to the Kelleysâ€™ plight, we find no error in the trial courtâ€™s conclusions.Â  The Kelleys could have easily ascertained the lot they were purchasing by simply reading or having explained to them the contents of the deed, plat, and other documents presented for their signature, all of which identified Lot A and described the property in detail.Â  The Kelleys had the assistance of Mr. Kelleyâ€™s parents, an interpreter, and an attorney in making their purchase.Â  Lot A, the hilly property the Kelleys actually purchased, was shown on a plat given to them as being located in a cul-de-sac, and it had a creek running across it.Â  The lot the Kelleys claim they wanted was level and was shown on the plat as being located next to Lot A.Â  It was not located on the cul-de-sac and did not have a creek running across it.Â  Â Â 
There is nothing in the record indicating the Kelleys did not have the opportunity to view the lot, make a complete review of the public records, or request a detailed survey of the property before purchasing it.Â  See LoPresti v. Burry, 364 S.C. 271, 612 S.E.2d 730 (Ct. App. 2005) (noting one with knowledge of the truth or the means to acquire it by reasonable diligence cannot claim to have been misled).Â  
We have previously noted that â€œ â€˜[t]he law imputes to a purchaser of real estate notice of the recitals contained in the written instruments forming his chain of title and charges him with the duty of making such reasonable inquiry and investigation as is suggested by the recitals and references contained therein.â€™ â€ Â Id. at 276, 612 S.E.2d at 732-33 (citations omitted) (emphasis in original); see also Thomas v. Jeffcoat, 230 S.C. 126, 94 S.E.2d 240 (1956) (holding there was no jury question presented regarding fraud where a buyer claimed he relied upon representations by the sellerâ€™s agents that the property was high in front, but level, the court stating the buyer viewed the lot and if he failed to examine it as closely as he should have, it was a matter of his own volition); Reid v. Harbison Dev. Corp., 285 S.C. 557, 561, 330 S.E.2d 532, 535 (Ct. App. 1985) (stating â€œthe true test of the hearerâ€™s right to rely on misrepresentations as to matters of record is whether or not he acted with reasonable prudence in so doingâ€ (quoting 37 C.J.S. Fraud Â§ 34c (1943))).
In the current case, the plat, deed, and other documents presented to the Kelleys clearly identified the property for sale and they went forward with the closing even though three months elapsed between the execution of the sales contract and the closing. Â We find this situation distinguishable from Slack, in which the buyers discovered the falsity of a representation by checking the public records and then refused to go forward with the closing.Â  The Slack court noted the timing of real estate transactions normally prevents a detailed records search prior to the execution of a sales contract.Â  Here, in contrast, the Kelleys had time to perform a detailed investigation of the property and relevant legal documents and did not make any attempt to invalidate the agreement until sometime after the closing.Â  Based on the foregoing, we find no error in the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment.
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Â The Kelleys also sued The Home Place, but consented to a dismissal, without prejudice, of those claims.Â  
[3]Â  Mrs. Kelley can read and write and has a B.A. degree in deaf education.Â  Mr. Kelley can read, but not well, and he can write in American Sign Language; he has one year of college.Â  He reads blueprints and drawings for his job making cabinets for airplanes at a nearby airport. Â He has previously obtained loans and purchased automobiles, and he handles his own bank accounts and writes checks.Â

title: Michau v. Cannon
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE. IT SHOULD NOT BE CITIED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Emory Alvin Michau, Jr., Appellant,
v.
J. Al Cannon, Sheriff of Charleston County, Henry McMaster, Attorney General of South Carolina,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-300
Submitted May 1, 2006 â€“ Filed June 30, 2006

REVERSED and REMANDED


  
    
      
Emory Alvin Michau, Jr., of Charleston, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Deborah R. J. Shupe, Office of the Attorney General, of Columbia.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: In February, 2001, Emory Michau, Jr. was convicted of participating in the prostitution of a minor and sentenced to three years.Â  The State, at the completion of Michauâ€™s sentence, petitioned for a probable cause hearing pursuant to the South Carolina Sexually Violent Predator Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-10 (2002).Â  On April 9, 2003, The Honorable Victor A. Rawl found there was probable cause to believe that Michau was a sexually violent predator under the statute.Â  The circuit court ordered Michau to be held in a secure facility and to undergo a mental examination to see if he was likely to engage in sexually violent acts if released.Â  Michau refused to cooperate in the mental examination, and the commitment case was continued until Michau cooperated.
On March 30, 2004, Michau filed a petition for a writ of habeas corpus with the Charleston County Clerk of Court.Â  In his petition, Michau asserted that he was indigent and unable to pay court fees and asked for a waiver of any fees.Â  On April 28, 2004, The Honorable R. Markley Dennis, Jr. denied Michauâ€™s petition to proceed in forma pauperis.Â  Â Michau argues this denial was in error.Â  We agree.
After reviewing the record on appeal, we find error in the circuit courtâ€™s denial of Michauâ€™s motion to proceed in forma pauperis.Â  We base this decision on the following authorities: Ex parte Martin, 321 S.C. 533, 535, 471 S.E.2d 134, 135 (1995) (citing Smith v. Bennett, 365 U.S. 708 (1961) (an indigent prisoner may not be required to pay a filing fee for petitioning for a writ of habeas corpus)); Lakes v. State, 333 S.C. 382, 385, 510 S.E.2d 228, 230 (Ct. App. 1998)(holding the judge should have allowed Lakes to proceed in forma pauperis in his petition for a writ of habeas corpus because he was an indigent, incarcerated individual).
Although we are reversing the circuit court on this issue, we express no opinion as to whether Michau is entitled to habeas relief.Â  He still bears the burden of showing that he is entitled to relief based on the facts of his case.Â  We simply hold that it was improper for the circuit court to deny Michauâ€™s motion to proceed in forma pauperis.Â  Â 
REVERSED and REMANDED.[1]
Kittredge, Short, and Williams, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: State v. Keith
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Cornelius Keith, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Â Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-301
Heard April 6, 2006 â€“ Filed June 30, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Deborah R. J. Shupe, Office of the Attorney General, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Cecil Kelly Jackson, of Sumter, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Cornelius Keith appeals his conviction for kidnapping.Â  He argues the circuit court erred in admitting evidence of prior bad acts and in denying his motion for directed verdict.Â  We affirm.Â Â  
FACTS
    On June 13, 2003, three days after her husbandâ€™s suicide, Tammy Atkinson received a phone call from a man who identified himself as â€œMr. Pinckney.â€Â  The caller, later identified as Keith, told Atkinson he knew her husband and referred to her husbandâ€™s family members by name.Â  Keith further informed Atkinson that her husband had helped him out when he was in trouble, and now he wanted to provide financial support for her. 
    Keith asked Atkinson to come to his home in Sumter so that she could meet his family and be presented with a check.Â  Keith told Atkinson that he wanted to give her some financial help after her husbandâ€™s death. Atkinson went to Sumter, and after calling Keith from a convenient store as he had requested, she was invited to come across the street to his apartment.Â  Atkinson drove over to Keithâ€™s apartment and observed him standing in his doorway waving to her.
    Atkinson entered the apartment and stood by the open door.Â  Keith immediately began walking in and out of rooms in the apartment as he asked Atkinson questions regarding her knowledge of other local families.Â  Atkinson could hear Keith opening and closing drawers in another room, and she walked away from the open door into the apartment in an attempt to see him.Â  When Atkinson turned back around to face the open door, she observed Keith close and lock the door.Â  Atkinson immediately announced, â€œIâ€™m out of here,â€ rushed to the door which she unlocked and opened, and exited the apartment. 
    Keith never threatened Atkinson or told her she could not leave.Â  Atkinson admitted that Keith was close enough to grab her when she was opening the door and exiting the apartment, but he never attempted to grab her or hinder her ability to leave.Â  Keith never made any physical contact with Atkinson, and after she exited the apartment, he stood in the doorway and told her he would call her later.
    Atkinson drove to the police station and reported what had happened.Â  The police provided Atkinson with a photo line-up and she picked out Keith as the man she had just seen.[1]Â  The police then drove to Keithâ€™s apartment and placed him under arrest.
    After transporting Keith to the police station, the police attained a search warrant for his apartment. Â The police executed the warrant and found a notebook in a dresser drawer.Â  In the notebook were written entries containing names and ages of deceased men and contact information for their family members.Â  The police were later able to match the information in the notebook with newspaper obituaries found in Keithâ€™s apartment which contained the same information.Â  Additionally, the police found a newspaper in the trash that contained Atkinsonâ€™s husbandâ€™s obituary. 
    At trial, the State produced two witnesses to testify regarding phone calls they had received from a man who identified himself as â€œMr. Pinckney.â€Â  At the time of the phone calls, both witnesses were recently widowed, and they were each listed in entries written in the notebook found in Keithâ€™s apartment.Â  The two women testified that the caller told them he knew their husbands and that he wanted to help them financially.Â  Neither woman ever agreed to the callerâ€™s request to meet nor did they ever receive a check from him.
    A Sumter County grand jury indicted Keith on a single count of statutory kidnapping by inveiglement or decoy.Â  After trial, the jury convicted Keith of kidnapping, and the trial court sentenced him to ten years imprisonment.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â Â  
    LAW/ANALYSIS 
      I.Â  Admission of Evidence
        Keith contends the trial court erred in admitting evidence of prior bad acts in violation of State v. Lyle[2] and Rules 403 and 404(b), SCRE.Â  We disagree.
        In criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  On appeal, we are limited to determining whether the trial judge abused his discretion.Â  State v. Bowie, 360 S.C. 210, 216, 600 S.E.2d 112, 115 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the trial courtâ€™s ruling is based on an error of law.Â  State v. Foster, 354 S.C. 614, 621, 582 S.E.2d 426, 429 (2003).Â  This Court does not reassess the facts based on its own view of the preponderance of the evidence but simply determines whether any evidence supports the trial judgeâ€™s ruling.Â  Wilson, 345 S.C. at 6, 545 S.E.2d at 829.
        A.Â  Rule 404(b)
        South Carolina Rule of Evidence 404(b) states:Â  

        Evidence of other crimes, wrongs, or acts is not admissible to prove the character of a person in order to show action in conformity therewith. It may, however, be admissible to show motive, identity, the existence of a common scheme or plan, the absence of mistake or accident, or intent.

        We note that Rule 404(b), SCRE, differs from the federal rule of evidence.Â  â€œ[U]nlike the federal rule, which does not limit the purposes for which evidence of other crimes may be admitted, the South Carolina rule limits the use of evidence of other crimes, wrongs, or acts to those enumerated in State v. Lyle, 125 S.C. 406, 118 S.E. 803 (1923).â€Â  Rule 404(b), SCRE, Advisory Committee Notes.Â  This incorporation of Lyle into the South Carolina rule renders differentiation between a prior bad actâ€™s admissibility under Lyle and its admissibility under Rule 404(b), SCRE, unnecessary to our analysis.
        The State presented two witnesses who testified that they had received phone calls that were virtually identical to the call Atkinson received from Keith.Â  Keith objected to the admission of this testimony as inadmissible prior bad acts.Â Â  The State maintained it was entering the evidence to show Keithâ€™s common plan or scheme. 
        To determine the admissibility of evidence to show a common plan or scheme by the defendant, the court must determine â€œwhether the particular conduct circumstantially tends to prove the design or plan.â€Â  State v. Bell, 302 S.C. 18, 28, 393 S.E.2d 364, 370 (1990).Â Â Â Â  The connection between the prior bad act and the crime being tried must be more than just a general similarity.Â  State v. Cutro, 332 S.C. 100, 103, 504 S.E.2d 324, 325 (1998).Â  â€œThe acid test of admissibility is the logical relevancy of the other crimes.â€Â  Id.
        In his analysis of this issue, the trial judge compiled a spreadsheet to illustrate the connection between Keithâ€™s prior bad acts and the alleged kidnapping.Â  The link between the phone calls made to the two testifying widows and the phone call made to Atkinson can be seen: all three calls came within days of the deaths of the womenâ€™s husbands; in each case the caller identified himself either as â€œMr. Pinckneyâ€ or a relative of Bill Pinckney; the reason given for each of the calls was to offer financial support to the widow; and during each call, the caller attempted to set up a meeting with the widow.Â  The trial judge effectively illustrated the connection between the phone calls in terms of the time of the call, the identity of the caller, the reason for the call, and the request for a meeting.Â  We find this evidence provides a sufficient connection between the prior bad acts and the current crime and circumstantially tends to prove a common plan or scheme.
        Establishing a sufficient connection between the prior bad acts and the current crime does not end our analysis.Â  â€œTo be admissible, proof of prior bad acts must be clear and convincing.â€Â  State v. Smith, 300 S.C. 216, 218, 387 S.E.2d 245, 247 (1989).Â  However, our standard of review on appeal of these matters is limited.

        [W]e do not review a trial judgeâ€™s ruling on the admissibility of other bad acts by determining de novo whether the evidence rises to the level of clear and convincing.Â  If there is any evidence to support the admission of the bad act evidence, the trial judgeâ€™s ruling will not be disturbed on appeal.

        State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).
        There is certainly some circumstantial evidence in the record on which the trial judge could have based his decision.Â  Under this â€œany evidenceâ€ standard, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s admission of this testimony regarding prior bad acts.
         B.Â  Rule 403, SCRE
        Keith further contends the above noted testimony and the notebook found in the search of his home should have been excluded under Rule 403, SCRE.Â  We disagree.
        South Carolina Rule of Evidence 403 states: â€œAlthough relevant, evidence may be excluded if its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice, confusion of the issues, or misleading the jury, or by considerations of undue delay, waste of time, or needless presentation of cumulative evidence.â€
        Prejudice must be determined based on the entire record and the result will generally turn on the facts of each case.Â  Wilson, 345 S.C. at 7, 545 S.E.2d at 830.Â  A trial judgeâ€™s decision regarding the comparative probative value and prejudicial effect of evidence should be reversed only in exceptional circumstances.Â  State v. McLeod, 362 S.C. 73, 81, 606 S.E.2d 215, 220 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œWe review a trial judgeâ€™s decision regarding
        Rule 403 pursuant to the abuse of discretion standard and are obligated to give great deference to the trial courtâ€™s judgment.â€Â  State v. Horton, 359 S.C. 555, 569, 598 S.E.2d 279, 286 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  
        In light of the Stateâ€™s reliance on circumstantial evidence to prove decoy or inveiglement, we find the witnessesâ€™ testimony and the notebook to be especially probative.Â  We do not find that exceptional circumstances exist to reverse the trial courtâ€™s admission of the testimony or the notebook.Â  We find no abuse of discretion by the trial court because this evidence was more probative than it was prejudicial.Â  
        II.Â  Directed Verdict
        Keith contends the trial court erred in denying his motion for directed verdict.Â  Keith maintains that he neither kidnapped Atkinson, nor committed any illegal act.Â  We disagree.Â  
        When ruling on a motion for a directed verdict, the trial court is concerned with the existence or nonexistence of evidence, not its weight.Â  State v. Cherry, 361 S.C. 588, 593, 606 S.E.2d 475, 477-78 (2004).Â  When reviewing a denial of a directed verdict, this Court must view the evidence and all reasonable inferences in the light most favorable to the state.Â  State v. Burdette, 335 S.C. 34, 46, 515 S.E.2d 525, 531 (1999). If there is any direct evidence or any substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused, an appellate court must find the case was properly submitted to the jury.Â  Cherry, 361 S.C. at 593-94, 606 S.E.2d at 478. See State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 564 S.E.2d 87 (2002) (on an appeal from trial courtâ€™s denial of a motion for a directed verdict, appellate court may only reverse the trial court if there is no evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s ruling).
        South Carolinaâ€™s kidnapping statute requires proof of an unlawful act taking one of several alternative forms, including seizure, confinement, inveiglement, decoy, kidnapping, abduction, or carrying away.Â  State v. East, 353 S.C. 634, 637, 578 S.E.2d 748, 750 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Section 16-3-910 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) states:

        Whoever shall unlawfully seize, confine, inveigle, decoy, kidnap, abduct or carry away any other person by any means whatsoever without authority of law, except when a minor is seized or taken by his parent, is guilty of a felony and, upon conviction, must be imprisoned for a period not to exceed thirty years unless sentenced for murder as provided in Section 16-3-20. 

        Under the interpretation of the statute set out in East, the act of inveigling or decoying alone satisfy the unlawful act requirement for proof of statutory kidnapping.Â  Inveigling has been defined as â€œenticing, cajoling, or tempting the victim, usually through some deceitful means such as false promises,â€ and decoy is defined as â€œto lure successfully.â€Â  State v. Stokes, 345 S.C. 368, 373, 548 S.E.2d 202, 204 (2001) (citing United States v. Macklin, 671 F.2d 60, 66 (2d Cir. 1982) and New Websterâ€™s Dictionary and Thesaurus 250 (1993)).
        In this case, the State presented evidence that would allow a reasonable jury to find Keith inveigled or decoyed Atkinson into traveling to and entering his apartment.Â  The State presented Atkinsonâ€™s testimony of the events surrounding her phone conversation and meeting with Keith and the testimony of two other witnesses who had received virtually identical phone calls.Â  None of the women ever received any financial assistance.Â  Also, the State presented the notebook found in Keithâ€™s apartment that contained information about several deceased men and their families.Â  Thus, we find sufficient evidence was presented to support a finding of inveigling or decoy.Â Â Â Â  
        In addition to proving a defendant has violated the kidnapping statute, the State has the burden of proving that the statute was violated knowingly. State v. Jefferies, 316 S.C. 13, 19, 446 S.E.2d 427, 430-31 (1994).Â  There was certainly some circumstantial evidence in the form of the testimony regarding previous phone calls to other women and the notebook found in Keithâ€™s home that could reasonably show Keith knew he was inveigling or decoying Atkinson.
        In response, Keith argues that Atkinson came to his home voluntarily.Â  However, the fact that one is inveigled or decoyed into going somewhere negates, in legal contemplation, the voluntariness of his or her participation.Â  Stokes, 345 S.C. at 373, 548 S.E.2d at 204.Â  If Keith lured Atkinson to his home under the false pretense that she was to receive financial assistance, then her voluntariness would be negated. Â Furthermore, the fact that Keith locked the door after Atkinson entered his apartment casts doubt on his claim that she was there voluntarily. Â Â 
        In summary, Keithâ€™s alleged actions of luring Atkinson to his home under false pretenses qualifies as inveiglement or decoy and negates her voluntariness.Â  The inveiglement or decoy alone has been interpreted as meeting the necessary requirement of an unlawful act, and there was some circumstantial evidence to submit to the jury that could show Keith knowingly inveigled or decoyed Atkinson.Â  Therefore, we find there was evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s denial of Keithâ€™s directed verdict motion.
        AFFIRMED.
        BEATTY, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] The police had a photo of Keith on file because of his prior criminal conduct.Â  Keith has an extensive criminal record including a 2002 conviction for criminal sexual conduct in the third degree.
[2] State v. Lyle, 125 S.C. 406, 118 S.E. 803 (1923).

title: Erwin v. Ryanâ€™s Family Steakhouses
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Richard B. Erwin, Appellant,
v.
Ryanâ€™s Family Steakhouses, Inc., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-302
Submitted June 1, 2006 â€“ Filed June 30, 2006

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
W. Andrew Arnold and Brian E. Arnold, both of Greenville, for Appellant.
L. Gray Geddie, Donald A. Cockrill and Jeffrey P. Dunlaevy, all of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.:Â  In this employment dispute, Richard Erwin appeals the trial courtâ€™s order compelling arbitration between Erwin and Ryanâ€™s Family Steakhouses, Inc. (Ryanâ€™s).Â  We reverse and remand.Â  
FACTS
In 1980, Erwin began working at Ryanâ€™s.Â  In 1992, Ryanâ€™s implemented an arbitration program through Employment Dispute Services, Inc. (EDSI), a third-party arbitration service provider.Â  After Ryanâ€™s implemented the arbitration program, it required all new employees sign an arbitration agreement with EDSI; a signatory of this agreement assented to arbitrate all employment disputes with Ryanâ€™s in an EDSI forum dictated by EDSI rules and procedures.Â  Ryanâ€™s afforded all current Ryanâ€™s employees the option of signing the arbitration agreement, and Erwin opted not to sign it.Â  
In August 2001, Erwin entered into a Regional Partnership Agreement (Agreement) with Ryanâ€™s.Â  The Agreementâ€™s purpose was to â€œarrange an independent compensation method in which both [Erwin] and Ryanâ€™s have the opportunity to benefit as a result of the financial improvement of the restaurants which are supervised by [Erwin].â€Â  In addition to base salary, Erwin would earn a percentage of the profits made by the restaurants he supervised.Â  The Agreement contained an arbitration clause, which provided:

ARBITRATION.Â  Ryanâ€™s and [Erwin] agree that their relationship remains that of employer and employee.Â  Any employment related dispute must be resolved through the use of Ryanâ€™s previously established arbitration system.

On October 17, 2003, Ryanâ€™s terminated Erwin and cancelled the Agreement.Â  
Two months later, Erwin sued Ryanâ€™s for inter alia wrongful termination and breach of contract.Â  Ryanâ€™s moved to compel arbitration based on the Agreementâ€™s arbitration clause.Â  The trial court compelled arbitration but questioned whether Erwin agreed to arbitrate under the EDSI program.Â  Therefore, the court decided Erwin and Ryanâ€™s should select arbitration panel members in accordance with section 15-48-30 of the South Carolina Code (2005) rather than the EDSI program.[1]Â  The parties selected an arbitration panel (â€œPanelâ€), which heard Erwinâ€™s case in March 2005.Â  Â 
Two months later, the Panel issued an arbitration award in favor of Ryanâ€™s.Â  Ryanâ€™s then moved the trial court to confirm the arbitration award, which the trial court granted.Â  Erwin appeals this ruling.[2]  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Erwin argues the trial court erred in granting Ryanâ€™s motion to compel arbitration.Â  We agree. 
Whether a claim is subject to arbitration is a matter of judicial determination, unless the parties stipulate otherwise.Â  Chassereau v. Global-Sun Pools, Inc., 363 S.C. 628, 631, 611 S.E.2d 305, 307 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  â€œThere is a strong presumption in favor of the validity of arbitration agreements because of the strong policy favoring arbitration.â€Â  Towles v. United HealthCare Corp., 338 S.C. 29, 37, 524 S.E.2d 839, 844 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  The trial court should determine whether an arbitration agreement exists between the parties before determining whether the case should be arbitrated.Â  Hous. Auth. of the City of Columbia v. Cornerstone Hous., LLC, 356 S.C. 328, 334, 588 S.E.2d 617, 620 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  This determination is a matter to be â€œforthwith and summarily triedâ€ by the trial court.Â  Jackson Mills, Inc. v. BT Capital Corp., 312 S.C. 400, 404, 440 S.E.2d 877, 879 (1994).Â  
The trial court should apply ordinary state-law principles that govern the formation of contracts in evaluating whether an arbitration agreement exists.Â  Cornerstone Hous., 356 S.C. at 335, 588 S.E.2d at 621.Â  In construing a contract, the trial court should not look beyond the four corners of the contract if the text is free of ambiguity.Â  Barnacle Broad., Inc. v. Baker Broad., Inc., 343 S.C. 140, 146-47, 538 S.E.2d 672, 675 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  In such a case, as a matter of law, the trial court should enforce the contact as written.Â  Century Indem. Co. v. Golden Hills Builders, Inc., 348 S.C. 559, 568, 561 S.E.2d 355, 359 (2002).Â  It is black-letter law that the formation of a contract requires a â€œmeeting of the minds between the parties with regard to all essential and material terms of the agreement.â€Â  Player v. Chandler, 299 S.C. 101, 105, 382 S.E.2d 891, 893 (1989); Gaskins v. Blue Cross-Blue Shield of S.C., 271 S.C. 101, 105, 245 S.E.2d 598, 600 (1978).
Erwin contends he and Ryanâ€™s did not agree to arbitrate.Â  The crux of this dispute is the Agreementâ€™s arbitration clause, which provides, â€œ[a]ny employment related dispute must be resolved through the use of Ryanâ€™s previously established arbitration system.â€Â  Both parties concede the â€œpreviously established arbitration systemâ€ is the EDSI arbitration program implemented in 1992.Â  There are no other signed documents concerning arbitration between the parties.Â  Therefore, if Erwin and Ryanâ€™s agreed to arbitrate Erwinâ€™s employment related claims, they necessarily agreed to arbitrate them under the EDSI program.Â  Thus, the parties either agreed to arbitrate under the EDSI program, or they did not agree to arbitrate.Â  The arbitration clause offers no alternative.Â Â  
We conclude it was error for the trial judge to order arbitration under the South Carolina statutory scheme.Â  Section 15-48-10 of the South Carolina Code (2005) specifically states that the arbitration method described in Section 15-48-30 will â€œnot apply to . . . (2) Arbitration agreements between employers and employees . . . unless the agreement provides that this chapter shall apply.â€Â  Because the arbitration clause did not reference Section 15-48-30, the court clearly erred by ordering arbitration pursuant to the statutory scheme.
The trial court found the parties executed an arbitration agreement covering the dispute in question, but also that â€œit is not clear . . . Richard Erwin agreed to arbitration under Ryanâ€™s EDSI arbitration plan.â€Â  The nature of the Agreementâ€™s arbitration clause dictates a finding that either (1) the parties agreed to arbitrate under the EDSI system or (2) the parties did not agree to arbitrate.Â  The trial judge essentially found an agreement to arbitrate, but no clear agreement to use the EDSI system. Â These two findings are diametrically opposed.Â  
Consequently, the trial court erred in granting Ryanâ€™s motion to compel arbitration.Â  Accordingly, we reverse and remand to determine whether Erwin and Ryanâ€™s agreed to arbitrate under the EDSI arbitration program as provided by the Agreementâ€™s arbitration clause.Â  The trial courtâ€™s order is 
REVERSED AND REMANDED.[3] 
SHORT, J., concurs.
KITTREDGE, J., concurring in part and dissenting in part:
I concur in part and dissent in part.Â  The trial court held the Agreement clearly and unambiguously compels arbitration.Â  I agree with the experienced trial judge and respectfully dissent from the majority opinion in this regard.Â  In my view, the error occurred only in the method of arbitration.Â  The parties clearly agreed to arbitrate under EDSI.Â  Ordering arbitration under section 15-48-10 of the South Carolina Code (2005) was inappropriate for the reasons set forth in the majority opinion.Â  Accordingly, I would remand for a determination of whether Erwin was prejudiced by the trial courtâ€™s erroneous selection of the statutory arbitration method.Â  If the court finds prejudice resulted from this error, the court would then order arbitration as agreed by the parties under EDSI.Â  If the error did not prejudice Erwin, then the underlying judgment should stand affirmed.

[1]Â  Section 15-48-30 of the South Carolina Code provides that the three-member arbitration panel should be comprised of one arbitrator â€œchosen by the party making the demand for arbitration, one chosen by the party against whom demand is made and [the] third being chosen by those two chosen by the parties.â€Â  The EDSI program provides that a three-member arbitration panel should be comprised of one employer, one employee, and one attorney, retired judge, â€œor other competent legal professional not associated with either party.â€Â  
[2]Â  Erwin also moved to vacate the arbitration award, which he did on the same day the trial court confirmed the award.Â  
[3] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: State v. Dinkins
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Timothy Dinkins, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Brooks P. Goldsmith, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-303
Heard June 6, 2006 â€“ Filed June 30, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Alexandre Thomas Postic and Melissa Jane Reed Kimbrough, both of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, and Solicitor Warren Blair Giese, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Timothy Dinkins appeals his conviction for drug trafficking.Â  He asserts the trial judge erred in failing to suppress evidence obtained pursuant to a defective search warrant and in refusing to provide the jury with an additional charge on actual knowledge.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS
On April 15, 2002, Narcotics Agent John Lutz received a tip from a first-time confidential informant about suspected drug activity conducted by Dinkins in a Richland County apartment.Â  The informant indicated he had verbal confirmation from Dinkins that Dinkins had a large amount of cocaine in his possession and that he had sold some.Â  The informant also provided information regarding the type of vehicle or vehicles Dinkins used.Â  Based upon that tip, Lutz set up surveillance of the apartment.Â  Later that day, Lutz and another narcotics agent watched Dinkins drive up to the apartment in a vehicle fitting the description provided by the informant, drop off some dry-cleaning, and depart. Â According to Lutz, Dinkins was then observed traveling on Interstate 20 at a high rate of speed.Â  Dinkins was stopped by another police officer for the traffic offense, and Lutz, who had been surveilling Dinkins, arrived shortly thereafter. Â At the traffic stop, Lutz asked Dinkins where he lived.Â  Dinkins told Lutz he lived in Bishopville and did not mention the apartment.Â  
After the traffic stop, Lutz submitted to the magistrate an affidavit in support of a search warrant for the apartment.Â  The affidavit included the informantâ€™s tip and police officersâ€™ confirmation of Dinkinsâ€™ residence and the cars he might be driving.Â  The affidavit also contained Dinkinsâ€™ criminal record, which included prior convictions for illegal drug possession, and the fact that, according to Lutz, Dinkins lied about where he lived and his activities immediately prior to the traffic stop.Â  Based on Lutzâ€™s affidavit, the magistrate issued a search warrant for the apartment.Â  Lutz executed the search warrant and found a large quantity of cocaine in the apartmentâ€™s laundry room closet.Â  
Before opening statements, Dinkins moved to suppress the cocaine alleging the search warrant lacked probable cause. Â The trial judge denied the motion, finding probable cause supported issuance of the search warrant.Â  After the presentation of all evidence, the judge submitted the case to the jury.Â  During deliberations, the jury asked the trial judge whether proof of knowledge was required to convict Dinkins of trafficking.Â  At that time, Dinkins requested an additional charge on actual knowledge, which the State contested.Â  The trial judge did not provide this additional charge, but sent his written instructions to the jury room.Â  
The jury convicted Dinkins of drug trafficking, and the judge sentenced him to twenty-seven years imprisonment.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Dinkins raises two issues on appeal:Â  (1) whether the trial judge erred in denying Dinkinsâ€™ motion to suppress drug evidence recovered pursuant to a defective search warrant; and (2) whether the trial judge erred in refusing to provide the jury with an additional charge on actual knowledge. 
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Motion to Suppress 
Dinkins argues the search warrant is defective for lack of probable cause.Â  We disagree.[1]Â  
In criminal cases, an appellate court sits only to review errors of law. State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  â€œIn an appeal from a motion to suppress evidence based on Fourth Amendment grounds, an appellate court may conduct its own review of the record to determine whether the evidence supports the circuit courtâ€™s decision.â€Â  State v. Abdullah, 357 S.C. 344, 349-50, 592 S.E.2d 344, 347 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  
A search warrant may be issued only upon a finding of probable cause.Â  State v. Bellamy, 336 S.C. 140, 143, 519 S.E.2d 347, 348 (1999).Â  An appellate court reviewing the magistrateâ€™s decision to issue a search warrant determines whether the magistrate had a substantial basis for concluding probable cause existed.Â  State v. Weston, 329 S.C. 287, 291, 494 S.E.2d 801, 803 (1997); State v. Dupree, 354 S.C. 676, 683, 583 S.E.2d 437, 441 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  â€œThis review, like the determination by the magistrate, is governed by the â€˜totality of the circumstancesâ€™ test.â€Â  Id.Â  
The task of a magistrate in determining whether to issue a warrant is to make a practical, common sense decision as to whether, under the totality of the circumstances set forth in the affidavit, there is a fair probability that evidence of a crime will be found in a particular place.Â  Illinois v. Gates, 462 U.S. 213, 238 (1983); State v. Baccus, 367 S.C. 41, 50, 625 S.E.2d 216, 221 (2006).Â  This decision includes consideration of the veracity of the person supplying the information and the basis of his or her knowledge. Â Id. Â The affidavit must contain sufficient underlying facts and information upon which the magistrate may make a determination of probable cause.Â  State v. Smith, 301 S.C. 371, 373, 392 S.E.2d 182, 183 (1990); State v. Philpot, 317 S.C. 458, 461, 454 S.E.2d 905, 907 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  
We believe, under the totality of the circumstances, the search warrant was properly issued.Â  First, Lutzâ€™s affidavit presented the magistrate with the informantâ€™s tip that Dinkins was â€œa major supplier of crack cocaineâ€ who manufactured crack at the apartment.Â  Furthermore, it indicated that the vehicle information provided by the informant was corroborated by police surveillance.Â  Second, the affidavit referenced Dinkinsâ€™ prior convictions for illegal drug possession, including possession of crack cocaine and possession with intent to distribute marijuana.Â  See U.S. v. Melvin, 419 F.2d 136, 141 (D.S.C. 1969) (holding that evidence of prior convictions of similar crimes should be afforded some weight in a probable cause determination although standing alone such convictions may not sustain a warrant).Â  Third, the affidavit indicated that Dinkins lied to Lutz about his residence and his activities prior to the traffic stop.Â  
We recognize the tip in this case came from a first-time informant.Â  Typically, when seeking a warrant based on information from an informant, there is a recitation that the informant is deemed reliable.Â  Obviously, that is not possible in the case of a first-time informant.Â  However, here, as a result of the information provided, surveillance of the apartment revealed that at least a portion of the information was accurate.Â  Additionally, the information from the informant was just one of numerous factors that, taken together, support a finding of probable cause for the issuance of the search warrant for the apartment.Â  We therefore find the magistrate did not err in issuing the search warrant, nor did the trial judge in refusing to suppress the evidence obtained as a result of its execution.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Jury Charge
Dinkins argues the trial judge erred in refusing to make an additional charge on actual knowledge.Â  We disagree. 
An appellate court will not reverse the trial judgeâ€™s decision regarding jury instructions absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Clark v. Cantrell, 339 S.C. 369, 389, 529 S.E.2d 528, 539 (2000).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when the trial judgeâ€™s ruling is based on an error of law or, when grounded in factual conclusions, is without evidentiary support.â€Â  Id.Â  Jury instructions must be read in light of the entire charge and the facts of the case.Â  Cole v. S.C. Elec. & Gas, Inc., 355 S.C. 183, 191, 584 S.E.2d 405, 410 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  If the charge as a whole is reasonably free from error, isolated portions of the charge that might be misleading do not constitute reversible error.Â  Id.Â  The trial judgeâ€™s refusal to give a requested jury instruction must be both erroneous and prejudicial to warrant reversal.Â  State v. Burkhart, 350 S.C. 252, 261, 565 S.E.2d 298, 303 (2002). 

S.C. Code Â§ 44-53-370(c) (2002) provides:
  
It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly or intentionally to possess a controlled substance unless the substance was obtained directly from, or pursuant to a valid prescription or order of, a practitioner while acting in the course of his professional practice, or except as otherwise authorized by this article.
  

Possession may be proved by direct or circumstantial evidence, and it may be actual or constructive.Â  State v. Mollison, 319 S.C. 41, 45, 459 S.E.2d 88, 91 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  â€œActual possession occurs when the drugs are found to be in the actual physical custody of the person.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œConstructive possession occurs when the person charged with possession has dominion and control over either the drugs or the premises upon which the drugs were found.â€Â  Id.Â  

The trial judge charged the jury as follows:
  
[Y]ou must determine if the State has proved beyond a reasonable doubt that the defendant was knowingly in actual or constructive possession of 400 grams or more of cocaine . . . .Â  I will now define to you certain terms.Â  Knowingly is defined as with knowledge, consciously, or willfully.Â  Actual or constructive possession.Â  Proof of possession requires more than proof of mere presence at the place where the thing allegedly possessed is found.Â  The State must prove beyond a reasonable doubt that the accused had both[,] one, the power, that is the actual or constructive control; and, two, the intent to control its disposition or use. . . .Â  Constructive control occurs when the person charged with possession has dominion and control over either the object or the premises upon which it is found.Â  It is enough for constructive control that the accused has the right to exercise dominion and control over the thing allegedly possessed. . . .Â  Each element of the offense must be proved beyond a reasonable doubt in order to find this defendant guilty of the crime charged.
  

After the judge issued this charge, the jury deliberated.Â  Before rendering a verdict, however, the jury asked the judge the following question: Â â€œIs any proof of knowledge required?â€Â  
At this juncture, Dinkins requested the trial judge give the jury an additional charge on actual possession.Â  The trial judge refused, but provided the jury a written version of his instructions.Â  In light of the fact that the written instructions clearly indicate knowledge is an element of trafficking that the State must prove beyond a reasonable doubt, as well as the propriety of the jury charge as whole, the judge did not abuse his discretion in refusing to give the jury an additional charge on actual knowledge.Â  Accordingly, the trial judgeâ€™s order is 
 AFFIRMED.
 HUFF, STILWELL, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1]  As an initial matter, there is some question whether this issue is preserved for appeal.Â  Although Dinkins objected to the introduction of the drug evidence before trial, he did not make a contemporaneous objection to the introduction of the drug evidence at trial.Â  â€œHowever, where a judge makes a ruling on the admission of evidence on the record immediately prior to the introduction of the evidence in question, the aggrieved party does not need to renew the objection.â€Â  State v. Forrester, 343 S.C. 637, 642, 541 S.E.2d 837, 840 (2001).Â  The evidence sought to be excluded was brought in through the Stateâ€™s first witness and the only evidence introduced prior to the admission of the cocaine was photographs of the apartment and the various related drug paraphernalia contained therein.Â  Because Dinkinsâ€™ objection was arguably preserved, we address the merits of his appeal. Â

title: Bethards v. Parex
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

Appeal From Charleston County
Â DanielÂ  F. Pieper, Circuit Court Judge


  
    
      
John Phillip Bethards, Appellant,
v.
Parex, Inc., Jeff Thomas d/b/a Thomas Construction, Mike Tenny d/b/a Synco Enterprise, Charleston Gypsum n/k/a CSR America, and Weather Shield Mfg., Inc.,
Defendants,
Of Whom Mike Tenny d/b/a Synco Enterprise and Weather Shield are
Respondents.
      
    
  


AFFIRMED

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-304
Heard March 7, 2006 â€“ Filed June 30, 2006
Withdrawn, Substituted and Refiled August 30, 2006


  
    
      
Justin O'Toole Lucey, of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellant.
John L. McCants, of Columbia and Trent M. Kernodle and Christine C. Varnado, both of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:  This case involves negligence and breach of warranty claims by a homeowner, John Bethards, against Mike Tenny d/b/a Synco Enterprises (Synco), a contractor, and Weather Shield Manufacturing, a window manufacturer.Â  The trial court judge granted a directed verdict in favor of Synco and Weather Shield on Bethardsâ€™ claims for negligence and breach of the implied warranty of fitness for a particular purpose.Â  A jury found for Weather Shield on the remaining breach of the implied warranty of merchantability claim.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Bethards hired an architect, Thomas Smith (Architect), and a general contractor, Jeff Thomas d/b/a Thomas Construction, to design and build a home in Isle of Palms, South Carolina.Â  Part of Bethardsâ€™ contract with Architect included site visits by Architect to the home.Â  
Bethardsâ€™ home was built using an Exterior Insulation Finish System (EIFS) (synthetic stucco), which Synco allegedly installed. Â The windows and sliding glass doors for the home were manufactured by Weather Shield and bought at Southern Lumber and Millwork Corp.Â  (Southern Lumber). Â 
Bethards testified he began experiencing problems with the sliding doors soon after he moved into the home in 1996.Â  At Bethardsâ€™ request, Thomas Construction contacted Southern Lumber about the problems.Â  Bethards testified that either a Southern Lumber or a Weather Shield representative went to the home and repaired the sliding doors using parts Weather Shield apparently sent to Southern Lumber.Â  Bethards claims when the representative left, the sliding glass doors were in working order and he did not experience problems with them again until 2001.Â  The representative only examined the sliding doors; he did not have any interaction with the windows.Â  
In 1999, the home was damaged by Hurricane Floyd.Â  Bethards submitted a claim to his insurance company for the damage.Â  The insurance company sent an engineer to the house to assess the damages, and he determined two windows were damaged by the hurricane but a third was likely damaged by someone trying to open the window without unlocking it.Â  The engineer also pointed out a water stain in the second floor sunroom that was unrelated to the hurricane.Â  
In 2000, after hearing of some problems in the area with stucco, Bethards became concerned about the EIFS on his home.Â  In 2002, Bethards had his home inspected by a professional engineer who determined that the EIFS on the home had failed.Â  His engineer also determined the home had roof leaks and improperly installed flashing at the roof and around the windows and doors.Â  All of these factors and the hurricane led to water damage in the home.Â  
In 2001, Bethards began experiencing the same problems with the sliding doors as he had in 1997.Â  He testified the sliding doors leaked when it rained and caused water damage and electrical problems.Â  He also testified that the locks on the sliding doors rusted and could not be locked.Â  
In 2001, Bethards brought suit against Parex, Inc.
